sites.description: Whether you need to warm up or cool down [Starbucks](http://www.starbucks.com/store/6663/us/presidio-letterman/1-letterman-drive-building-c-san-francisco-ca) has you covered.
sites.name: Starbucks Coffee

sites.description: Overlooking Seal Rocks and the wide Pacific, [Louis' Restuarant](http://louissf.com/index.html/menu.html) has been a San Francisco tradition for over 75 years. Open everyday from 6:30 A.M.- 6:00 P.M.
sites.name: Louis' Restaurant

sites.description:
Updrafts over the coastal bluffs make Fort Funston one of the best hang-gliding sites on planet Earth, especially between March and October, but conditions are enviable year-round. 

Anyone interested in getting in the air must contact the [Fellow Feathers](http://www.flyfunston.org/) of Fort Funston for more information.
sites.name: Hang Glider Viewing Platform

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: "Sand" Francisco
The wayside faces north, on the northern side of the trail.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
This panel stands along the bayside of the San Francisco Bay Trail. Directly in front of you is a fenced off section of dunes, mostly covered in dark green coastal scrub plants. Further out are the waters of the bay and the Marin Headlands. To the north west, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge.
 
The text reads:
 
These revitalized coastal dunes are a small remnant of an extensive ecosystem that once covered about one-third of the area that is now San Francisco. The sandy soil sustained a mosaic of native grasses, wildflowers, shrubs and oak  trees adapted to a climate of mild, wet winters and summer drought. This coastal dune scrub community supported a diversity of animals from insects to grizzly bears. The transformation to cityscape has been devastating to both the dune habitat and its native wildlife.
 
This panel features a photograph of thick plant cover on a white sand dune. The plants are low to the ground, with yellow and pink blossoms. Their tendrils spread over the sand, extending their reach across the dune.
 
The text reads:
 
Adapted to desert-like conditions of low nutrients, high winds and extreme water loss, native plants stabilize the dunes. Growing in a patchwork, the plants capture moving sand and their lengthening root systems help hold the sand in place.
 
"CPR" for Dunes
 
The development and use of Crissy Field destroyed its natural dunes and decimated its native plant communities. Ecological restoration of the native dune system here has included the reintroduction of native plants grown in park nurseries and planted by park volunteers. A generous grant from the California Coastal Conservancy helped fund this project, and sustained CPR--community-based preservation and restoration--will assure long-term protection and care for these improvements.
 
This panel features a photograph of a young woman and boy crouching on bare soil, facing each other. They're wearing work gloves, and the woman has a baseball cap on that's shading her face from the sun. They're both holding onto a small plant with long, thin tendrils above a small dug out hole in the soil. Behind them are more people crouching in the dirt, which extends far into the distance.
 
The text reads:
 
Thousands of volunteers helped restore Crissy Field. They removed countless invasive exotic plants and placed more than 100,000 native plants in the ground to help the ecosystem get established.
 
In the lower portion of this panel are several illustrations of plants. The first illustration is of a plant with a white blossom with six petals around a light yellow center. Its green leaves grow in threes, and are rounded except for the front edge which is serrated. It grows along a pinkish-red vine.
 
The text reads:
 
Beach strawberry spreads rapidly by runners and forms dense mats that stabilize the soil. Its waxy leaves retard water loss.

The next illustration shows a plant that also grows on a vine, but has a more vertical structure to its blossom. The blossom is pink and round like a sphere, the petals growing in more of a three dimensional pattern. The green triangle-shaped leaves with rounded edges grow above and below the flower.
 
The text reads:
 
The pink sand verbena's sticky succulent stems store water and trap windblown sand. Sand buildup stimulates the continued growth of this mat-forming perennial.
 
The next illustration shows a vertical plant with five small, round blue blossoms at the top of its stalk. Lower down on the stalk are five crinkly looking leaves, and at the very bottom, a dense section of smaller leaves growing close together.
 
The text reads:
 
Silky hairs on the silver bush lupine's leaves reflect heat and protect them from drying out. Capable of fixing nitrogen from the air, an advantage in nutrient-poor sand, these plants can live many decades.
 
The final illustration is of another plant with a long stalk with small round blossoms growing on both sides all the way to the tip, which is bent slightly to the right. At the plant's base are green, serrated leaves and spiky, yellow blossoms growing at intervals along the center of the stalk.
 
The text reads:
 
The thick roots of the beach bur stabilize the sand that builds up around the fast-growing stems. Its seeds have spines that resist movement in the shifting sand and enable the seeds to take root.
 
End text.
 
End.
 
Walk west a little over one tenth of a mile and you'll arrive at the next wayside on the southern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 11

sites.description: Seal Rocks is a bit of a misnomer, as the name arose from the Steller's and California sea lions who at one time hauled out on the rock. True seals are not known to have sat on these picturesque sandstone rocks jutting out of the sea just off the coast from the Cliff House. From the right angle you can even see an arch in one.

information.description: Lands End has been a long time in the making. Geologists have found the sandstone in the vicinity of Sutro Baths and the Cliff House to be 80 million years old. Radiometric dating of zircon crystals, a kind of mineral found in the sand, indicates that the grains came from an eroded ancient mountain range in Idaho. The zircon crystals from that range formed between 1 and 2 billion years ago were uplifted and eroded, then carried by a river from Idaho to Northern California around 80 million years ago. That river formed a large delta in the present Sacramento Valley and dumped sediment into a deep sea subduction trench in the San Francisco area.
information.name: Minerals talk

sites.name: Seal Rocks

sites.description: The original  Alcatraz lighthouse, constructed in 1854,  was the first lighthouse built on the US West Coast.  The lighthouse served as a navigational aid for over 50 years. The cottage style lighthouse building was replaced by the taller 95 foot structure you see before you in 1909 because it was no longer tall enough to shine over the new cellhouse. In 1963, when the penitentiary closed, the lighthouse became automated and a modern beacon was added.
sites.name: Alcatraz Lighthouse

sites.description: Julius Kahn, or JK for those in the know, is the place to be for the whole family. With a playground for the kiddies and athletic fields and courts for tennis and basketball. Run by San Francisco Recreation and Parks, JK is a happening place for you to get your hustle on.
sites.name: Julius Kahn Park

sites.description:
Tennessee Cove is a popular destination for a picnic or for a casual hang at the end of Tennessee Valley. The cove boasts a broad beach surrounded by high, rocky bluffs. A short side trail will take you up a bluff for excellent views from old coastal defense observation posts. 

If you venture near the water, be careful and use caution. Never turn your back on the ocean.

information.description: The SS _Tennessee_ was the first American steamship reassigned for service in the Panama to San Francisco run. On her first Pacific voyage in 1849, she carried only 15 passengers because of rough storms, but in March of 1850, she arrived in Panama after 57 days at sea to a waiting throng of 3,000 seeking passage to San Francisco. The _Tennessee_ brought thousands of gold-seeking fortune hunters to the city for three more years until a fateful, foggy day in March, when she ran aground in the Headlands. All souls were lost and the site of the wreck was renamed Tennessee Cove to honor those lost.
information.name: Tragedy at sea

information.description: Tennessee Cove is made up of the sedimentary rock, chert. The rocks here at the cove are chock full of radiolaria fossils. 'Radiolaria' is a big word for ocean faring single-celled organisms. These little guys are smaller than a grain of sand and come in a variety of symmetrical shapes that survive for hundreds of millions of years embedded in the rocks as fossilized mineral skeletons. You can see them in the rocks with a standard magnifier.
information.name: Geology of Tennessee Cove

sites.name: Tennessee Cove and shipwreck

sites.description:
Pollution and draining of wetlands has led to a decline in San Francisco garter snake and California red-legged frog populations, making these species particularly sensitive to future habitat disruption. Climate change may further harm these species. Sea level rise due to global warming could allow saltwater to intrude into the low lying freshwater ponds where the frogs and snakes live. These ponds are protected by a levee, but they are so low that water from them has to be pumped up to the ocean. 

Rising temperatures may also promote the spread of invasive plants and animals that could alter habitats or outcompete the frogs and snakes. Restoring the habitat here provides more protection and resilience for these threatened species.
sites.name: Sea level rise

sites.description:
Completed in 1900, Battery Crosby was armed with 6-inch guns and designed to protect the underwater minefields outside the Golden Gate. They were to protect against minesweepers and fast moving boats trying to navigate through the minefields.
Across the water, under and beyond the Golden Gate Bridge, you can see Fort Baker, established in 1901. This post played a prominent role in the San Francisco harbor defenses during WWII, including being the base of operations for planting and maintaining the offshore minefield. An antisubmarine net also spanned the bay entrance from Fort Baker to the Presidio during that war.
sites.name: Battery Crosby: Guarding the minefield

sites.audio_description:
Down the hill from the Great Meadow and across a public pay parking lot accessible from Marina Boulevard, is Fort Mason Center. Once the gateway to the Pacific for many soldiers from the late 19th century through WWII, in its modern incarnation, Fort Mason Center is home to many non-profit programs including museums, theater groups and centers for the arts and yummy food places. Housed within the Landmark Buildings, five rectangular cream colored brick and red Spanish tiled roofed edifices labeled A, B, C, D and E, the non-profits include the SF MOMA Artists Gallery, Children’s Art Center, Magic Theatre and Blue Bear School of Music, all of which offer a variety of cultural programs in the form of theater performances, concerts and art exhibits.

Building A is two stories tall, and the closest of the five to Marina Boulevard. It contains the Fort Mason Center Convention Center and Main Office. Buildings B, C, D and E are each three stories. All five buildings are accessible by stairs and ramps at the center of their longer, interior sides that parallel the parking lot between buildings C and D. The lobbies to each building contain elevators and a corner corridor stairwell with access to women’s restrooms on the first floor, and male/female restrooms on the second. Buildings B and C are linked by a skyway on the second and third floors, as are buildings D and E. In addition to the non-profits, the Landmark Buildings house Reader’s bookstore, Goody Café and Greens Restaurant.
The Herbst Pavilion is stands upon pier 2, between and beyond both the parking lot and buildings  C and D. Facing the San Francisco Bay, pier 3 is to the right of pier 2, which holds the larger Festival Pavilion.

On clear days, Fort Mason Center offers pristine views of the Golden Gate Bridge which spans the northern narrows of the Bay, leading into the high hills of the Marin Headlands. Also visible and closer in than the bridge is Alcatraz Island, with its blocky, sand-blonde façade, square windows and lighthouse rising in sharp relief against the Bay’s blue-green waters.
sites.description: Fort Mason Center for Arts & Culture's mission is to engage and connect people with arts and culture on a historic waterfront campus. They inspire and foster creativity by providing a vibrant gathering place and a home for thought-provoking programs, events and organizations, including galleries, theaters, performance spaces, museums, arts education facilities, nonprofit offices, meeting rooms and various sized event venues.
sites.name: Fort Mason Center

sites.description: The Great Meadow is a cool hang. Full of palm trees for shade, grassy hills for naps and paved paths for walkers, joggers and cyclists! Dog friends welcome to frolic, too.
sites.name: The Great Meadow

sites.description: With barbecue pits, bathrooms, space to park all a stone's throw from Fort Point and the San Francisco Bay Promenade, it's no secret that West Bluff is a great place for a picnic. Get there early if you plan to grill out, or you may be waiting to cook some dogs!
sites.name: West Bluff beach

sites.description:
Kiosk Description

The kiosk is a four-sided metal structure with three interpretive panels located to the east of the Whalen Building, along the western side of Pope Road, near the intersection with MacArthur Avenue.
View from the kiosk:
 
The wayside faces a large, three-story building with cream colored walls and a green roof; the Whalen Building.
 
Kiosk Panel: Exploring Fort Mason
 
This panel features a detailed map of Fort Mason. In the south eastern corner of the area labeled "Upper Fort Mason" are the words "You Are Here." A network of trails in the south eastern corner show how to get from the Park Offices to the Great Meadow further west.
 
This panel features a photo of a cannon pointed out over a low wall.
 
The text reads:
 
Historic Rodman cannon on display at Black Point Battery on the bluffs behind the hostel
 
History Walk
 
A free self-guiding history booklet may be obtained at building 201 (park headquarters), inside the front entrance, during business hours; open Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. (except holidays).
 
Bicycling
 
Fort Mason is the doorway to San Francisco. Ride from here across the Great Meadow to the Marina Green and on to Crissy Field promenade, Fort Point and the Golden Gate Bridge.
 
Bicycle etiquette
 
Share paths safely. Bicycles may not exceed 15 m.p.h. and must slow to 5 m.p.h. around corners and when passing other path users. Yield right of way to pedestrians, strollers and wheelchairs.
 
Accessibility
 
Nearly all of the paths at Fort Mason are wheelchair accessible. Enjoy the Great Meadow or visit the Black Point Batter picnic area and historic site by following a route behind the hostel.
 
Community Gardens
 
A restful island in the bustling city open for public enjoyment, flowers, veggies, birds and butterflies thrive here, along with neighborhood gardeners. Please respect their peace and privacy. No picking. Entrance on Franklin St.
 
This panel features an aerial photograph of a large, outdoor garden complex with paths between planted sections and a small glass greenhouse.
 
The text reads:
 
Fort Mason Community Gardens.
 
Below the photo of the garden is another photo, this one of four young people, two men and two women, smiling and studying a map together.
 
The text reads:
 
Free information about San Francisco is available in the hostel nearby.
 
Fisherman's Wharf Hostel
 
Gain a greater understanding of the world and its people through hosteling. For American and international budget travelers. Follow Pope St. to the end. Located at the end of Franklin St. Shared or private rooms. Café Franco serves 3 meals a day. For information visit www.SFHostels.com.
 
On the right side of the center of the panel is a photograph of a ship with three masts anchored along a wharf in the distance. On the nearby shore are people sitting on a grassy hill, a white pickup truck on a path next to trees and light poles.
 
The text reads:
 
Historic ships at San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park.
 
Where Are the Historic Ships?
 
To reach San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park at Hyde St. Pier,
 
On foot: There are two options: 1st-Follow Pope St. north to the hostel and around its west side. Take the path to MacDowell Rd. and follow the Bay Trail “promenade” to the east—0.9 miles. Or take the stairs! Follow Franklin St. north to the end. Continue through Black Point Battery and down to Aquatic Park. About one mile and 15 minutes walk.
 
By car: Left out of the main entrance onto Bay Street. Left onto Van Ness. Right onto North Point. Left at Polk.
 
Restrooms & Drinking Water
 
Across the street at southwest corner of the Great Meadow. Stay to your left.
 
Stay Safe and Comfortable
 
Bring layered clothing. Weather can turn windy, foggy and cold very fast.
 
Fort Mason is an urban park. Be aware of your surroundings. Exercise common sense, especially after dark. Do not leave valuables in your car.
 
Dog Walking

Dogs are allowed on leash throughout Fort Mason.
 
Dog Regulations
 
Federal Law requires dogs to be on leash at all times in all national parks. (36 CFR Part 2) Dog walkers must obey regulations and pick up after their pets.
 
Emergency Information
 
In an emergency call the Park Communications Center at (415) 561-5510, or dial 911. Cell phone users call (415) 472-0911.
 
Directions to Fort Mason Center, Herbst and Festival Pavilions, and Cowell Theater
 
How do I get to …
 
Herbst and Festival Pavilions? Cowell Theater? Greens Restaurant? You may be looking for Fort Mason Center, just west of here, and located on the waterfront.
 
By Car: 3 rights: Right out of main entrance onto Bay Street. Get in right lane. Right at the second stoplight onto Laguna, curve left onto Marina. Hard right at Buchanan (across from the Safeway store).
 
On foot: Go to back west corner of this building. Take path to the west. After curve look for the large brown sign, that says, “Piers”, and take the long, steep set of stairs down to Fort Mason Center. A 10-minute walk from here. To avoid the steep stairs follow the alternate route shown on map.
 
End text.
 
[End tone]
 
Kiosk Panel: A Settled Land
The panel faces south.
Several nations have claimed this site
 
For thousands of years Native American people, now known as Ohlone, lived in permanent and seasonal villages throughout the area surrounding the San Francisco Bay. Cooking hearths and other cultural remains from an Ohlone village were discovered not far from where you stand.
 
In 1776, Spanish soldiers, settlers, and missionaries claimed the San Francisco peninsula for Spain. They used this bluff as a lookout for ships, and in 1797 built a small gun battery, Batteria de San Jose, to protect a ship anchorage on the east side of the point.
 
Eventually, California passed from Spain to Mexico and then to the United States. In 1850 President Millard Fillmore reserved this area for military use. The army ignored the site for many years, but hurried to fortify the point in 1863 when the Civil War raised concerns about a Confederate or British invasion of San Francisco's harbor. Renamed Fort Mason in 1882, the post remained an active military installation for over a century.
 
The panel features four black and white photographs arranged in rows of two and two. The first photo, in the top left of the bottom half of the panel, shows a house with a pointed roof surrounded by many trees and garden plants arranged along a path bordering the house.
 
The text reads:
 
Officers' housing
 
In the 1850s, a number of civilians built homes and planted gardens on the point. They were illegal squatters, but they were also some of the city's best known and wealthiest citizens, including John C. Fremont. Nonetheless, the army evicted them in 1863. Some of the historic squatters' homes remain in use today.
 
To the right of the photo of the house is an aerial photo of a street and field side by side. Telephone poles can be seen at the center of the image. On the field are several tents, and in the street, horse-drawn carriages. In the distance is a water tower rising above a Eucalyptus stand.
 
The text reads:
 
Earthquake refugee camp
 
Devastated San Franciscans fled to Fort Mason after the 1906 earthquake. Having lost their homes to the quake or the fires that followed, they lived in military tents and ate army rations.
 
The bottom left photo shows several rows of women, dressed in army uniforms with hats, jackets and knee-length skirts, saluting an American flag being raised on a flagpole.
 
The text reads:
 
Military women stationed at Fort Mason during World War II played an indispensable role in the post's coordination of troop and supply movement.
 
To the right of the photo of the army women is another more modern street scene. People line the street as cars and buses drive past. A few American flags can be seen being held by onlookers in the bottom of the frame.
 
The text reads:
 
Wounded and sick soldiers and survivors of the Bataan death march received a hero's welcome when they returned to Fort Mason in 1945. During World War II, the post was the army's West Coast headquarters for troop and supply transport to the Pacific. Soldiers went to war from here, and this was their first stop when they came home.
 
The panel features a map of the San Francisco Bay Area, including San Francisco and San Mateo County to the south, San Pablo Bay to the east and Marin County to the north. Labeled are many Golden Gate National Recreation Area and state park sites including Muir Woods, Angel Island, Mount Tamalpais, Tennessee Valley, Alcatraz Island, Fort Mason, Milagra Ridge and Mori Point.
 
To the right of the map is an aerial photo of San Francisco's northern border and the bay.
 
The text reads:
 
In 1972 Fort Mason became part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area—established to protect natural, cultural, and historic treasures in an urban area.
 
End text.
 
[End tone]
 
Kiosk Panel: A Vanished Landscape
The panel faces west.
 
The text reads:
 
Sandy wilderness surrounded by early Fort Mason
 
You are standing in a vastly transformed landscape, on a broad bluff that projects out into the bay. Try to picture the miles of sand dunes that once stretched to the south and west, giant mounds sculpted by northwesterly winds. Imagine the tidal marsh and natural cove that the native Ohlone people knew on the bluff's west side—long since filled in, built over, and bordered by a modern marina.
 
All of San Francisco has been profoundly altered. The dunes have disappeared beneath buildings, roads, and nonnative plants and trees. The shoreline along the bay—both east and west of here—has been reshaped with fill and construction. Only a small stretch of Fort Mason's rocky shoreline remains in its natural state, supporting intertidal habitats that look much as they did when the Ohlone harvested shellfish from them centuries ago.
 
This panel features an illustration of a cliff side coast line, dotted with green scrub plants in an otherwise sandy landscape. A network of square buildings appear on either side of a roadway that hugs the coast, leading to a denser cluster of buildings in the distance with an American flag at their center.
 
The text reads:
 
Spanish soldiers and settlers that arrived here in 1776 called this bluff Punta Medanos de Arenas-Sand Dune Point. This painting depicts the American army post as it appeared in 1866.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a rocky coastal bluff covered in scrub brush leading down to the water’s edge.
 
The text reads:
 
A rugged shoreline.
 
When the U.S. Army claimed this area in 1850, dense scrub, buckeye and bay laurel trees crowded the shoreline. The dark bay trees contrasted so sharply with the area's sand dunes, civilian residents called the bluff's eastern ridge Black Point. The laurels and all but one buckeye are gone.
 
This panel features four photos of wildlife, three of them are of birds and one is of a butterfly.  Three of the four birds appear in a row of photos. The bird in the left-most photo is black, with a long neck and a flat, stubby tail. To its right is a bird with a long, thin beak inside of a flower, its tiny wings flapping so fast they appear as a blur. On the right is a photo of a pair of birds perched on a branch, with light brown and white coloration. From left to right, the birds are: Brandt's cormorant, Phalaerocorax penicillatus, Anna's hummingbird, Calypte anna, and the white-crowned sparrow, Zonotrichia leucophrys.
 
Below the photos of the birds is one of a brown butterfly resting on the ground. It has a pattern of dark spots along the outer edge of its wings, and a series of light stripes highlighting its darker body.
 
This is a photo of a buckeye butterfly, Junonia coenia.
 
The text reads:
 
Native residents still live here
 
A variety of trees and plants grow at Fort Mason today, providing habitat for birds, butterflies and other creatures. Here are just a few of the species you might see here today.
 
This panel features a map of the waterfront along the Presidio and Fort Mason. Outlined in red is the estuary that feeds into the bay and hugs the coast.
 
The text reads:
 
The cove and marsh west of this bluff were filled to provide a site for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition of 1915. You can get a sense of the vanished landscape by visiting the restored marshland and dunes at Crissy Field, west of the San Francisco Yacht Club.
 
To the right of the map is a photograph of a colorful bird perched on a branch. Its head is a bright red, and its beak, yellow. It has a green body and claw-like talons that are wrapped around the branch.
 
The text reads:
 
Red-headed conure, Aratinga erythrogenys
 
Maybe you’ve caught sight of Fort Mason's brilliant green parrots and wondered whether your eyes deceived you. They didn't. A flock of wild parrots, descended from escaped pets, moves between Fort Mason and other San Francisco neighborhoods. Most of the birds are red-masked conures, but the flock also included mitered conures and hybrid offspring.
 
End text.
 
[End tone]
 
To reach the next wayside, walk south about 20 feet then turn right. Walk another 95 feet, turn right and you'll arrive at the wayside 9 feet away.
 
The next wayside is just a few feet to the west about 10 feet to the right of the sidewalk on a small brick walkway.
 
Wayside Panel: Headquarters
The panel faces north west, just before the corner of Pope Road and MacArthur Avenue.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
The wayside faces a large, three-story building with cream colored walls and a green roof; the Whalen Building. The Whalen Building is preceded by a green lawn and sidewalk running north to south along the building's eastern most side that cuts left and parallels the building's main façade leading up to the entrance. The Whalen Building's two tallest sections have pointed roofs. The closest section of the building is shorter. There's a large, brown sign in between two granite pillars along the sidewalk that leads to the main entrance that says "Park Headquarters."
 
The text reads:
 
Critical Logistics Center for the Army's Pacific Operations
 
From its start in 1902 as an army hospital, built to accommodate twelve patients, this building went on to become the U.S. Army's headquarters for troop and supply transport to the Pacific.
 
By 1906, most of Fort Mason's sick soldiers were sent to the Presidio's larger facility and much of the hospital here was used for temporary barracks, storage and other non-critical functions. Then in 1912 the army established a major troop and cargo depot along Fort Mason's shoreline and the building's future was set—the old hospital became the new shipping center's headquarters.
 
The depot, which was renamed the San Francisco Port of Embarkation in 1932, dispatched more than 1.6 million soldiers and over 23 million tons of supplies during World War II alone. Transport and shipping operations continued at Fort Mason into the early 1960s. By the time operations ceased, this modest building had long been an important site in the nation's historic rise to international power.
 
The panel features two black and white photographs side by side in its top right corner. The photo on the left is of soldiers in uniform carrying several American flag standards in front of the Whalen Building's front entrance. To the right is a photo of two men walking down the steps of the Whalen Building, talking to each other. They're dressed similarly, in officer's brimmed hats.
 
The text reads:
 
At times, celebration, ceremony, and high-ranking visitors like General Eisenhower were the order of the day at Fort Mason. But day in and day out, the men and women who worked in this building coordinated the movement of soldiers and supplies to and from the Pacific.

In the bottom left corner of the is a black and white photograph of a row of tents on a field. Many people are walking about in front of the tents. Behind the tents, the top of a tall, dark building can be seen.
 
The text reads:
 
After the earthquake and fire in 1906, this site at Fort Mason was one of several civilian emergency relief camps established by the army on military lands around San Francisco. Not that the top of the post hospital building (today's park headquarters above the tents.
 
At the bottom of the panel is a ship packed with soldiers on its decks. Hanging off the side of the ship are life preserving boats. Behind the men a striped smoke stack can be seen.
 
The text reads:
 
Vast numbers of soldiers shipped out for Pacific destinations from the San Francisco Port of Embarkation at Fort Mason.
 
On the far right side of the panel are two maps, one on top of the other. The map on top shows the entire San Francisco Bay area, including San Rafael and Sausalito to the north, San Francisco to the south and Oakland and Richmond to the east. Fort Mason is labeled in the north of the San Francisco peninsula.
 
The text reads:
 
In addition to the Fort Mason warehouses and piers, the Port of Embarkation staff managed port activities at the Embarcadero, Alameda, and Benicia Piers, the Oakland Army Base, Emeryville Ordnance Shops, and other locations.
 
End text.
 
The map in the lower right of the panel shows Fort Mason and the Great Meadow. Dotted lines show the network of paths through the meadow.
 
End.
 
The next wayside is about 750 feet away. Head east on the sidewalk, cross Pope Road, turn left and head north 160 feet along the sidewalk. The wayside is to the left of the sidewalk.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 4

sites.description: China Beach is a great place to get away from the city without ever leaving. Tucked away in a cozy cove between Lands End and Baker Beach in the Sea Cliff neighborhood, you’ll find a relaxing place to picnic, sunbathe and play, with scenic views of the Marin Headlands and Golden Gate Bridge.

information.description: For a long time, locals have referred to this beach as China Beach or China Cove. While the origin of the name is unknown, there have been claims that it referenced Chinese immigrants who arrived in San Francisco during the Gold Rush. Chinese immigrant camps were common, but no evidence points to China Beach as a camp. It's possible the beach was used as a launch site for Chinese fishing vessels.
information.name: A mysterious name

information.description:
Chinese immigrants came to California beginning in 1849 seeking fortunes in the Sierra Nevada gold mines. Despite the US' inclusive rhetoric, the populace and laws were extremely hostile to non-whites. Because they were easily identifiable and willing to work for low wages, Chinese immigrants were more susceptible to discrimination and treated exceptionally poorly.

19th century politicians benefitted from anti-Chinese platforms, including San Francisco Mayor James D. Phelan, for whom China Beach was named for from 1933 to 1974.

Exclusionary practices forced Chinese out of the gold mines. Many returned from the mountains to the San Francisco Bay where they established a fishing industry.Their main catch was shrimp. 

The historical relationship between Chinese fishermen and China Beach is unclear. While we have no clear physical evidence of the beach being used as a campsite, anecdotal evidence points to a Chinese fishermen presence here. Foggy cove conditions aren't suitable for drying shrimp, but the beach may have served as an abalone harvesting site as well as a safe landing just beyond the Golden Gate. 

When China Beach came into the park's possession, the original name was restored to honor the popular history of this place.
information.name: Chinese immigration during the Gold Rush

information.description: For many years, China Beach was privately owned. In 1929, a local movement encouraged the city to purchase the land but the plan was unsuccessful. In 1933, the city and state successfully reached a deal, and plans were made to develop China Beach into a decadent public bath. This plan, however, ended in a development quagmire, remaining stagnant for decades. Not until 1950 did the city start constructing a bath house, though by this time, the grand vision of the ‘30s was reduced to a more practical one. Five years later, the China Beach Bath House was finally opened to the public. In 1977, the city transferred the beach to GGNRA.
information.name: Developing China Beach

information.description:
No pet friends on China Beach, please. Same goes for glass containers and fires.
 
Because there are no lifeguards on duty here, and surf conditions are unpredictable, swimming is not recommended.
information.name: Rules and Regs

information.description:
Avoid the wind as you lounge by taking advantage of the small deck on top of the lifeguard equipment pick-up station.
 
During low-tide, a walk from China Beach to Baker Beach will have you spying starfish, anemones and mussels hanging out on the rocky nooks and crannies of the cliffs. But, as with all GGNRA beach locations, be careful in the surf and never turn your back on the ocean.
 
In the area above the beach, you'll find grills and picnic tables. There's no way to reserve them, the early bird gets the worm out here.
 
Restrooms are open sunrise to sunset.
information.name: China Beach pro tips

sites.name: China Beach & Bathhouse

sites.description: A private monument to the legacy of the early Chinese community in San Francisco that has helped shape and grow the city's culture and industry since the 1850s.
sites.name: China Beach Monument

sites.description: From here you can take a 4.3 mile loop up the Dias Ridge Fire Road to the Miwok Trail, Coyote Ridge Trail and back on the Coastal Fire Road. There are some brief steep inclines climbing the ridge, but it is mostly fairly easy going. Total elevation gain along the hike is 900 feet. You'll be walking on dirt fire roads and trails, and the way is fairly exposed for the majority of the loop, so bring a hat and sun protection. Dog friends are cool to hang, but keep them on a leash.

information.description:
In the 1880s, this area was California's largest producer of fresh milk and butter, and dairies were a prosperous business. Much of their success was the result of a happy coincidence: the arrival of experienced Portuguese dairy farmers. Originally from the Azores, an archipelago of eight rural islands west of Iberian Portugal, these men emigrated to California aboard whaling ships. 

After a long time at sea, arriving in California and the allure of the Gold Rush prompted many Azoreans to "jump ship" in search of a better life. Those who didn't find their fortune in gold were able to use their native dairy experience to get jobs in Marin's newly-established dairy ranches.

Dairy farming was no joke. It took hard work from everyone who lived on the farms--women, men and children--to keep an operation running. Until electricity came in the 1930s, the cows were milked by hand twice a day, at 4 AM and 4 PM. Depending on the number of cows, each milking time could take up to three hours. In between milking sessions, there was no shortage of chores, from sanitizing and preparing milk for transport, to cleaning barns and equipment, mending fences to fieldwork, gardening, canning and tending livestock.
information.name: Golden Gate Dairy: A Remnant of the dairy farming days

sites.name: Dias Ridge Trailhead

sites.description:
A Geologic Tale-Wayside Panel
The wayside faces south west out over the wide expanse of the Pacific Ocean.
 
The panel is located about 80 feet south of the parking lot, just before the convergence of the forking paths that come together just south of the WWII fire control station bunker. It is the right-most of three panels stand side-by-side facing south west.
 
View from the wayside:
 
To your left, is the railed path leading down to the overlook, on a small spit of land lined with coastal scrub and a few cypress trees. To the north, the coast curves around to a point, forming a half-circle in the space between where you stand and the point, before curving a second time, forming another half-circle further up the coast.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
The text reads:
 
Reading the landscape
 
This in-and-out, scalloped coastline holds clues to both ancient and ongoing stories. The landscape around you contains coastal bluffs, rocky coastline, sandy beaches, mountain ridges, valleys, and peninsulas extending out into the sea. Each part tells a geologic tale.
 
The Rocks
 
Sticking out of the water, near shore, jagged “sea stacks” of hard basalt have endured pounding waves for millennia, as the sea eroded the bluffs around them. On land, much of the landscape is mélange, part of the defining geology in the Bay Area, the Franciscan complex formation. Melange is a crushed jumble of ancient sea floor deposits and lava erupting along cracks underwater. Massive boulders dotting the rolling landscape are its clues. Like nuts in cookies, these harder greywacke sandstone and greenstone basalts emerge from undistinguishable rubble of crushed rock and softer seabed materials to create the picturesque California coastal landscape.
 
This panel features a photograph of rocky, coastal cliffs on the right and blue ocean waters stretching out to the left. 
 
The text reads:
 
View from here looking north. Bolinas juts out into the sea in the upper middle of the picture. You are standing on the North American Plate; Bolinas and Point Reyes, faintly visible on clear days, are on the Pacific Plate.
 
This panel features a photograph of a dark, craggy rock jutting out from calm ocean waters.
 
The text reads:
 
Basalt “sea stacks” near shore.
 
To the right of the photo of the basalt formation is a second photo, of light-colored rocks on a hillside nestled amongst green scrub plants.
 
The text reads:
 
Boulders of greenstone basalt and greywacke sandstone stick out of the eroded surface rock.
 
Beneath these photos is a black and white photo of a woman wearing a white blouse and dark full-length skirt standing in profile on a ridge next to a long, straight crack in the ground stretching into the distance.
 
The text reads:
 
Well-known local naturalist, Alice Eastwood, standing next to crack in the earth at Point Reyes, about thirty miles north of here, shortly after the famous 1906 earthquake.
 
The Moving Land

On a clear day, you'll see Point Reyes to the far north, past the Bolinas peninsula. Both of these pieces of land have been inching their way north from Monterey for twelve to fifteen million years. Bolinas and Point Reyes sit on the Pacific Plate. Here at Muir Beach Overlook, you are standing on the North American Plate. On its slowly grinding path, the Pacific Plate scrapes its edge along the North American plate while it also pushes up from beneath, forming the coastal mountains.
 
The famous San Andreas Fault separates the two plates and lies just offshore from here, coming onto land at Stinson Beach, about ten miles to the north. Driving along Highway 1 for forty miles north from here, you can follow this famous fault along Stinson Beach and Bolinas Lagoon, through the Olema Valley and along Tomales Bay.
 
On the right side of this panel is a map of the California coast from Point Reyes National Seashore to the north down to San Mateo County south of San Francisco. The map also includes the San Pablo and San Francisco Bays to the east. San Pablo Bay is to the north of San Francisco Bay.
 
The land areas on the map are mostly a light tan, with some areas colored two distinct shades of green. The darker green represents NPS-managed Golden Gate National Parks lands, and includes areas north of Bolinas Ridge, the eastern side of Olema Valley as well as areas further south including Muir Woods, the Marin Headlands, Tennessee Valley, Muir Beach, Muir Beach Overlook and a northern section of the San Francisco Peninsula. The lighter green represents land within the authorized boundary of the Golden Gate National Parks, and includes areas around Mount Tamalpais State Park north of Muir Woods, as well as land to the north and east including the Marin Municipal Water District and areas east of Bolinas Ridge. To the south, in the middle of San Mateo County, is a swath of light green with a small strip of darker green in the north western section. Running diagonally north west to south east is a red dotted line representing the San Andreas Fault. The fault line cuts between Point Reyes and Bolinas Ridge, through the center of Olema Valley on down along the ocean, just west of Stinson Beach, Muir Beach Overlook, Muir Beach, Tennessee Valley and the Marin Headlands. The fault continues through the ocean until it comes aground again just south of San Francisco, and continues its path down through San Mateo County.
 
The text reads:
 
The San Andreas Fault lies under the water just offshore. The fault line comes on land just north of here at Stinson Beach, and proceeds north through the Olema Valley and Tomales Bay.
 
End.
sites.name: Muir Beach Overlook AD 2

sites.description: This grab-and-go food service location is downstairs from the more extensive Round House Café, across the plaza from the Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center. It's just the place to grab a drink or a pre-made sandwich.
sites.name: Bridge Café

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Farming and the Cultural Landscape-Panel Description
413 words.

View from the wayside: 
84 words.

This panel is set at the gate across the road from the Pelican Inn, a brick building painted white, with steep sloping brown tile roof with a tall chimney. 

This panel features a photo of several tilled garden rows surrounded by lush, green grass and trees. The most prominent row is full of flowering plants with purple, white red and orange blossoms. On the left of the garden photo is a superimposed image of leafy chard, with green leaves and a veiny, magenta stalk. 

The text reads: 

Within the Redwood Creek Watershed, there are many examples of people living compatibly with the native landscape while cultivating the rich riparian soils. For thousands of years Coast Miwok created shelter and found sustenance in this fertile floodplain. When Europeans took over the land, they leased parcels to Portuguese dairymen who sailed here from the Azores in search of a better life. The immigrants settled and worked in small agricultural communities nearby and established dairy ranches. 

George Wheelwright, a wealthy entrepreneur, purchased the Green Gulch pasture adjacent to Redwood Creek in 1945. He modified the creek, constructed a levee and grazed cattle here until he sold the land to the San Francisco Zen Center in the 1960s. The Zen Center ended the grazing, enabling the native landscape to return. The Center now runs Green Gulch Farm, growing organic produce for local businesses and farmers' markets.

End text.

Below the garden photo is a series of four images, and a corresponding era. Starting on the left, the first image is a black and white illustration of a Coast Miwok woven basket with a triangle pattern running. A row of reeds and a few trees are in the background. The era is 'over 6,000 years ago.' 

The text reads: As food came into season, the Coast Miwok moved about to sustainably harvest the abundant resources of the ocean and creek. 

End text.

The next image is a black and white photo of men, women and children in the 1870s. Some are standing, others on horseback, all are facing the camera which captures several heads of cattle and a white farm building with an angled roof behind them. 

The text reads: 

The Azorean dairy farmers worked on local ranches. Their efforts helped Marin County become California's largest milk and butter producer.

End text.

The third image is a color photo of several brown cows grazing in a green pasture with a stream in the background, Eucalyptus trees in the distance and fog rolling in over a green hillside. The era is listed as 'the 1940s to the 1960s.' 

The text reads: Intensive cattle grazing eroded the land and degraded the creek. 

End text.

The fourth image is a color photo three kids and one adult in a green field, their eyes trained on a beehive behind clear glass at Green Gulch Farm. 

The text reads: The Green Gulch Farm practices strive to balance human uses and natural processes.

End.
sites.name: Muir Beach A D Farming & Culture

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Collaborating for a Healthy Watershed-Panel Description 
414 words.

-Not yet placed, view from wayside pending-

This panel features a photo of green, rolling hills that form a valley. A winding road passes through the middle of the valley floor and climbs up and out the far end. In the blue sky above the valley, a red tail hawk, its dark head tilted upwards, soars with its wings spread wide. Its reddish-brown and white feathers are on full display.

The text reads: 

Redwood Creek Watershed extends unbroken from the ridge tops of Mount Tamalpais, through the old-growth redwood forest of Muir Woods to Big Lagoon at Muir Beach. Within its nine square miles are expansive grasslands, dense tangles of coastal chaparral, shady redwood forests and refreshing riparian woodlands in which water flows and empties into the Pacific Ocean. Caring people are actively working together to protect and support the health of this precious watershed system.

One hundred years of logging, grazing, construction, trail and road building in the past century left the watershed in a severely degraded condition. To restore and manage the watershed as one continuous system, federal, state and local agencies, non-profits and others adopted a Vision for the Future. This innovative and collaborative document includes a set of guiding principles to protect the watershed and offer hope to endangered species such as the coho salmon and California red-legged frog.

End text.

At the bottom of the panel are a series of four images. Beginning on the left, the first image is a three-quarter view colored map of the Redwood Creek Watershed. Muir Beach is marked by a red dot at the bottom center, and Mount Tamalpais, at the top. Between them are Green Gulch, Redwood Creek and Muir Woods. 

The text reads: A healthy watershed provides clean water for people, plants and wildlife--water for drinking, agriculture and recreation. 

End text.

The next image is of a fish out of water: a dead, gray coho salmon sitting upright on a bare rock bed. 

The text reads: the cumulative impact of watershed restoration vastly improves habitat for the coho salmon and other threatened and endangered species. 

End text.

The last two photos are of children in the outdoors. A smiling, young girl wearing a gray hoodie sitting on an incline wearing boots and work gloves. The other shows a young boy wearing a green t-shirt bending over a green plant stem he holds between his fingers. 

The text reads: Youth from all over the Bay Area steward the land by participating in education and habitat restoration programs.

End.
sites.name: Muir Beach A D Healthy Watershed

sites.description:
An Intimate View of Coastal California-Wayside Panel
The wayside is to the right of the previous wayside, and faces south west out over the wide expanse of the Pacific Ocean.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.

The text reads:
 
A collage of habitats
 
This setting of wind, waves and rocks inspires us to appreciate the watery world's relationship to the continent's edge. On clear days, you can view an expanse of forty miles up and down the coast, and look inland toward the crest of 2,640-foot high Mt. Tamalpais. Other times, enshrouded in fog, you can only imagine the coastal edge while you smell the briny air and listen to the rhythmic waves rolling against the cliffs far below.
 
The California coast includes a puzzle-like collage of natural habitats: rocky coastline, sandy beaches, coastal scrub, coastal prairie grasslands, willow-lined streams, rocky outcrops, a scattering of native oak and pine trees, tide pools along the water's edge, and a variety of marine habitats. Each habitat has its own particular, best suited, plants and animals.
 
This panel features three photographs of wildlife in its bottom right hand corner. Furthest left is a photo of a bird with long, brown wings stretched high overhead flying in profile. The wings are longer than its body is long, though it has a long yellow beak. The central photo is of a small bird with brown and white feathers perched on a branch in front of green leaves. He has a brown body and white neck with a dark stripe along the crown of his head. The photo on the right is of a large mammal with a reddish-brown coat, walking on all fours over a white rock.  From left to right they are examples of a brown pelican, a white-crowned sparrow and a coyote.
 
The text reads:
 
This land of various coastal habitats is the home of numerous animals, most of which are small, quiet and reclusive.
 
Hidden Life in the Brush and Rocks
 
Listen to the white-crowned sparrow as it sings from a miniature forest of coyote brush, while the scrub jay sounds an alarm at our intrusion. Brown pelicans glide above the water. Swallows swoop after insects. Coyotes prowl for mice. A bobcat hunts where the shy brush rabbit hides.
 
Nature's Colors

In spring and summer, a tapestry of flowers blanket these rugged bluffs and rolling hills: pink seaside daisies, gum plant in gaudy yellow, pastel tints of Wight's paintbrush, golden sticky monkey flower, and purple bush lupine—names as colorful as the hardy plants themselves.
 
End text.
 
Above the text is an artist's colorful illustration of the northern coastline at Muir Beach Overlook teeming with life. A flock of brown pelicans fly westward over the ocean in the top left corner, while in the foreground a bobcat peers over hillside at a red, white black towhee bird perched above a cluster of whitish pink seaside daisies with yellow center. Coastal scrub plants half-hide an orange and black monarch butterfly in the bottom right corner, and behind it, a coyote steps out among green leaves. In the distance a black turkey vulture hovers over the cliff, while a red-tailed hawk soars upwards with the green hills that extend to the north.
 
End.
sites.name: Muir Beach Overlook AD 3

sites.description: When this tree fell in 1930, this cross-section was put on display. The concentric rings of the tree reveal that it lived 1,021 years. Some redwoods live more than 2,000 years.

information.description:
Hold on to your butts: fossil records indicate that relatives of today's coast redwoods were living large during the Jurassic Period 160 million years ago. The dinosaurs may have bit the dust, but the redwoods continue to thrive in this location, one they have inhabited for some 20 million years thanks to environmental conditions that remain largely unchanged.
A combination of latitude, elevation and microclimates in the California Coast Ranges makes it possible for redwoods to grow. These factors are also what limits the redwoods' range to a few hundred coastal miles. The cool, moist air created by the Pacific Ocean keeps the trees continually damp, even during summer droughts. California's North Coast provides the only such environment in the world. The trees can live to be 2,000 years old, and regularly reach 600 years.

Redwoods are tough customers. They possess built-in resistance to insects and fire. Diseases are virtually unknown. Their unusual ability to regenerate also aids in their survival as a species. Sprouts may come directly from a snag or downed tree's root system. Basal burls, hard, knotty growths that form from dormant seedlings on a living tree, can sprout a new tree when the main trunk is damaged by fire, cutting or toppling.
information.name: The Old Ones

information.description: Since the 1970s, researchers have noted some coast redwood and giant sequoia trunks are growing at a rate faster than others previously documented. Could this be the result of climate change? Experts aren't sure, but think it's possible. One theory suggests that increased sunlight due to less summer fog, but a still-adequate amount of winter precipitation, is spurring the growth. Another theory is that wildfire suppression reduces the amount of fire stress, allowing redwoods to expend more energy on trunk growth. Whatever the reason, the available evidence suggests that, at least for now, redwoods are growing faster in the changing environment.
information.name: Hotter planet, bigger trees?

sites.name: Redwood Cross-section

sites.description:
Mori Point is a great place to see marine mammals passing through along the coast. The winter and spring months are great for whale watching. 94% of the worldwide 21,000 gray whale population travel up and down this coast on their 10,000 mile journey between Alaska and Baja California Sur. Adults move south from December to January. Some start heading back north again to feast as soon as February. Females and their calves hang out longer and tend to huge the protective coast as they head north from March through April. 

Depending on the time of year, it's also not uncommon to see humpback whales, blue whales, several species of dolphins and orcas. 

In early spring, Mori Point comes alive with color under a blanket of wildflowers. Goldfields, lupines, checker-bloom, red maids, poppies and tidy-tips sprout up from the grass in colorful displays. The ocean waves and shore provide a spectacular backdrop to these fields of flowers.

_Acrobatic ravens_

A murder of crows, or ravens as it may be, lives here at the cliff edge. They’re often seen taking advantage of the updrafts to perform frolicking mid-air acrobatics, chasing each other in twisting, turning, topsy-turvy feats. These birds aren’t just playful, they’re highly intelligent, too.
sites.name: The Point

sites.description:
The large white boulder here near the base of Bootlegger's Steps is local limestone. Mori Point is one of the few places in the San Francisco area where limestone occurs in industrial quantities. Mori's limestone interested the people that lived here through the centuries. Native Ohlone people quarried the rock for construction, decoration and trade. When the Spanish arrived in 1776, they used Mori's limestone for buildings at the Presidio and Mission and used it to make whitewash for Presidio structures. The quarries again became active during rebuilding after the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and during World War II. By the 1980s, the quarries were shutting down for good. 

The limestone also interested local scientists, who wanted to know how these isolated limestone blocks formed. The marine fossils in the limestone bodies show that they formed on the shallow tops of submarine volcanoes in the central Pacific. Between about 130 and 80 million years ago, these volcanoes took a ride towards North America on an ocean plate conveyor belt. When they arrived at the continent, the mountain peaks with their white limestone caps became lodged in the side of the continent rather than slipping under it like the rest of the ocean crust.
sites.name: Limestone

sites.description: [Muir Woods Trading](http://www.muirwoodstradingcompany.com/) Company is your one-stop shop for souvenirs and a hot meal in the woods.
sites.name: Muir Woods Trading Company

sites.description:
Crissy Field is the place for you, your friends and anyone else who wants to enjoy a stunning walk or bike ride along a flat, hard-packed promenade with iconic views of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge.

This enviable part of the city wasn't always so accessible. From 1921 to 1936, Crissy Field was the military's cutting edge location for testing flight technology. 

During this time, the Air Service captured the nation's imagination with eye-grabbing headlines about flights at Crissy Field, including aerobatic stunts and air races. Most significant were a series of long-distance flights that contributed to the development of airline travel.

information.description:
Presidio coast artilleryman Dana H. Crissy was ambitious. Being an artilleryman was interesting, but more interesting would be to get in on something new and innovative. Crissy changed the trajectory of his military career by joining the ranks of the Aviation Section of the Signal Corps, going on to become the Commander of the Mather Airfield in Sacramento. His position in Sacramento made him eligible to participate in a daring military test.

On October 8th, 1919, 61 planes took flight from Roosevelt Field, Long Island heading west across the US while 15 planes--including one piloted by Crissy—flew east from a still unnamed airfield at the Presidio in San Francisco. These planes made up the Transcontinental Reliability and Endurance Test, the first US military attempt to fly across the North American continent. After three days, and 24 hours in the cockpit, Captain Lowell H. Smith was the first to complete the trip, touching down on Roosevelt Field, New York.

In the end, only nine planes made it all the way across. Nine pilots died, including Major Dana H. Crissy and his navigator, Sergeant 1st Class V. Thomas. The men perished on their first day out, trying to land their DH-4 airplane near Salt Lake City. 

Colonel Hap Arnold of the Presidio, a personal friend and brother in aviation to Major Crissy, requested the airfield at the Presidio, where Crissy took off on his last flight, be named in his honor.
information.name: The naming of Crissy Field

information.description:
In 1925, after running six miles at full throttle across the Bay, two P-N9 Navy seaplanes under the control of Commander John Rodgers, took flight and headed west at a brisk 115 miles per hour. Their destination? Hawaii. But this was no pleasure flight making its way to a weekend of luaus. Rather, it was a major test of aviation. Coming on the heels of the around-the-world flight, which made use of short hops over the northern continents, the Navy was eager to show it was possible to fly planes over entire oceans at a single go. 

Despite meticulous planning, the expedition encountered adversity just five hours in, when one of the planes sprung an oil leak and was forced out of the air. Commander Rodgers’ plane was flying fine, and so, continued towards the south Pacific. Things continued uneventfully until 400 miles from their destination, the fuel reserves ran dangerously low, forcing Rodgers to veer off their charted path in search of a ship that could help them refuel. Unfortunately, no ship could be found. The airmen were forced down over the Pacific, in an area teeming with sharks. The low fuel took out both the engines and the radio. Stranded with little food, the men were left with few options. They managed to stay calm enough to remember their naval training and fashioned sails out of the canvas covering their plane’s wings. Their ingenuity paid off. Against the odds, the men survived long enough to be rescued by a Navy submarine before sailing past Kauai, one week later than their intended arrival.
information.name: First flight to Hawaii - Almost

sites.name: Crissy Airfield

sites.description:
Looking towards the ocean, the promontory in front of you is made of bedded red chert and graywacke sandstone. These are pieces of a much larger block of ancient sea floor that forms the Marin Headlands across the Golden Gate. To the south of this point until Land’s End, the Marin Headlands block also underlies San Francisco. These large blocks, known as ‘terranes’ to geologists, are large pieces of sea floor that ended up being plastered on to the edge of North America, rather than sliding beneath the continent. 

Chert is a glassy rock made up of ‘Radiolaria,’ a big word for ocean faring single-celled organisms. These little guys are smaller than a grain of sand and come in a variety of symmetrical shapes that survive for hundreds of millions of years embedded in the rocks as fossilized mineral skeletons. They tell us the age of the rocks and the environment in which they lived. Radiolaria in these rocks lived somewhere in the central Pacific between 200 and 100 million years age. 

The graywacke sandstone formed at the edge of North America during submarine landslides that dumped sand into the deep-ocean subduction trench about 100 million years ago.  These rocks sometimes contain fossilized shells of marine mollusks.
sites.name: The Headlands in SF?

sites.description: Muir  Woods has a three-dimensional cast-bronze tactile map of the Redwood Creek Watershed. The model has tactile letters and braille along its surface, as well as raised features representing roads and trails. Additionally, the model contains a compass rose in alignment  with its geographical surroundings. On top of that, it’s a working hydrological model of a watershed.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D - Redwood Creek Watershed Tactile Model

sites.description: Situated on the bluffs between the Pacific Ocean and the San Francisco Bay, the [Point Bonita YMCA ](http://www.ymcasf.org/ptbonita/)offers opportunities for individuals and groups to participate in environmental education, host retreats and engage in physical recreation.
sites.name: Point Bonita YMCA

sites.description:
Bicentennial Campground is the most accessible campground within GGNRA. You may use barbecue grills in the nearby Battery Wallace picnic area during your stay, for a maximum of three nights per year. Remember to bring your own water, as none is provided. There's also no fires and no pets allowed in the campground, but on the plus side, there are no fees, either. 

Contact the Marin Headlands Visitor Center (415) 331-1540 for reservation information.
sites.name: Bicentennial Campground

sites.description: Muir Beach Overlook has a three-dimensional cast-bronze tactile map of the Redwood Creek Watershed. The model has tactile letters and braille along its surface, as well as raised features representing roads and trails. Additionally, the model contains a compass rose in alignment  with its geographical surroundings. On top of that, it’s a working hydrological model of a watershed.
sites.name: Muir Beach Overlook A D - Redwood Creek Watershed tactile model

sites.description: Whether you're an experienced trail hand or a city slicker who doesn't know a pommel from a stirrup, the [Miwok Stables](http://www.miwokstables.com/) offers exciting horseback riding opportunities for all ages and skill levels. Just a ten minute drive over the Golden Gate Bridge, the stables are open daily, with a credentialed staff ready to get you riding in some of the Bay Area's most scenic terrain.
sites.name: Miwok Livery Stables

sites.description: Morton Street Field, in the Tennessee Hollow Watershed at the corner Morton and Rodriguez Street, is licensed to Town School. It's open to public play when not scheduled to be used by Town School. First come, first serve.
sites.name: Morton Street Field

sites.audio_description:
Directly off of Conzelman Road, Battery Spencer is a hotspot destination for Bay Area tourists and locals alike. There's parking at the battery, but it's limited, so be prepared to park either further up Conzelman, or in the lot below on busy days. From the parking lot, you'll first encounter an open plaza area made of loose gravel where there are trash and recycling bins as well as a row of upside down U-shaped posts for locking bikes. 

Following the gravel trail past the plaza takes you past the first battery building on the right, which is now a restroom facility. A little ways past the bathrooms, the path forks in two directions. Going right will take you through the battery itself, a network of rooms bordering a large, open area in the center. Going left will take you on a slightly elevated path away from the batter, overlooking the famous view of the Golden Gate Bridge. From this exposed point, the winds coming off the bay are intense. 

The trail leads you out to the bluff edge, from where you can see the high-vaulted north tower up close, and the thick suspension cables swooping down from the bridge's highest point in a semi-circular arc down close to the cars and pedestrians crossing north and south below. Smaller support cables run in parallel, vertical columns in equidistant increments along the entire length of the bridge, connecting the suspension cables to the roadbed. The detail of the art-deco tower, with its four rectangular window-like cut outs and iconic color, international orange, a sort of earthy-red tone, can be admired with greater clarity from this vantage than anywhere in San Francisco. On clear days, you can see far into the city from Battery Spencer, as well as the shipping lanes in and out of the bay. 

From the bluff, you can access the battery by turning away from the water and going down one of several flights of stairs. You can walk around the battery's first level, mostly a large, open space, or climb up to the second level. The building is mostly army green, though the paint is worn and peeling in places.
sites.description: If you've ever seen a car commercial featuring the Golden Gate Bridge, chances are good that part of it was shot on Conzelman Road leading up to Battery Spencer. At almost 500 feet above the bay, this high cliff-top vantage point makes for great views today and was prime location for big coastal defense guns when the army was here. Construction of Cliff and Ridge batteries started here shortly after the Civil War. The newly developed 12-inch rifled guns of Battery Spencer replaced the 15-inch cannon-ball shooting guns of the former batteries in 1895. Come for the view, but be sure to walk around the remains of the battery, a relic of a bygone era. Parking along Conzelman Road at the battery is limited and often full, so be prepared to walk a little.
sites.name: Battery Spencer Overlook

sites.description:
Built in 1937 by Works Progress Administration (WPA), the historic Log Cabin was originally a non-commissioned officers' club. The cabin's rustic wood and stone exterior is unlike any other building in the Presidio, but reminiscent of other WPA buildings in parks around the country. 

With an open floor plan and wall-to-wall windows, the [Log Cabin](http://www.presidio.gov/venues/Pages/Log-Cabin.aspx) is one of the park's most popular venues for celebratory events. The large lawn area is ideal for wedding ceremonies or receptions, and offers panoramic views of the San Francisco skyline.

Reservations for use are taken up to two years in advance, so start planning that sorority reunion now!
sites.name: Log Cabin

sites.description: Paul Goode Field, in the Tennessee Hollow Watershed just south of Morton Field, is licensed to San Francisco University High School. It's open to public play when not scheduled to be used by SFUHS. First come, first serve.
sites.name: Paul Goode Field

sites.description: Below the suspension bridge to the left is a spectacular stack of pillow basalt rock formations that attracts geologists from around the world. The tunnel and trail you just walked is another example of pillow basalt, an igneous rock that only forms when lava erupts underwater. The rapid cooling of lava by cold water forms the pillow-shaped bodies, which often break open and release more lava from inside. The volcano that erupted these rocks did so far out in the Pacific Ocean over 190 million years ago.  Continental drift brought them to this place millions of years ago.
sites.name: Basalt at Point Bonita

sites.description: Fern Creek is the first section of a loop around the Alice Eastwood campground, and an access point to Mount Tamalpais State Park. This area, like much of Muir Woods, is home to many animal friends. Living from the forest floor to high in the canopy, it is hard to see most inhabitants. So keep your peepers peeled!

information.description:
Muir Woods lies within the southern portion of the northern spotted owl's range, a subspecies of the spotted owl. These owls reside in old-growth coniferous forests from Northern California to British Columbia, and prey on small mammals. In Muir Woods, spotted owls primarily diet on dusky-footed woodrats, with other common prey such as brush rabbits, voles, pocket gophers, and mice. They don't make their own nests, preferring instead to reside within tree cavities, including broken-topped trees and platforms. Because of their specific nesting preferences, the health of northern spotted owl populations are indicative of the health of old-growth forests, making them one of the most-studied owl species. They're classified as federally threatened, with the primary threat due to logging activity resulting in the fragmentation and elimination of their forest habitat. 

If you're visiting in the twilight hour, keep your ears open. You may hear the northern spotted owl's distinctive "barking" call.
information.name: Northern spotted owl at Muir Woods

information.description: A lot of animals in Muir Woods are just little guys who you might see along the ground or lower in the canopy. Some common woodland friends include banana slugs, Steller's jay, Echo blue butterflies, thrushes, rough-skinned newts, hummingbirds and the Sonoma chipmunk. But keep your eyes open for larger animal friends, too--Muir Woods is also home to black-tailed deer, bobcats, otters, skunks and raccoons.
information.name: Woodland animal friends

information.description:
When you're going about your daily fish identifications, it's important to remember that a trout is a salmon, but a salmon does not always a trout make. Consider the coho and the steelhead, both are anadromous, meaning, they migrate to the ocean after birth in freshwater rivers and streams. Yet, steelhead are the same species as rainbow trout, coho are just plain, old salmon. 

Both varieties of fish friends start off spotted along their backs, with red flanks and a dark olive coloring above and below their flanks. Coho develop the most pronounced hooked nose of all male spawning salmon, while steelhead have more of your garden variety fish-nose. Both turn silver when they adjust to life in ocean waters.

Steelhead can live up to 11 years, and weigh up to whopping 55 pounds, though average size is much smaller, more like 10 pounds. Similarly, coho are on average between eight and 11 pounds, though coho as heavy as 31 pounds have been reported. Both fish friends are threatened by a number of human-induced environmental factors such as habitat degradation, water diversions, and improper harvesting. In Muir Woods, we're doing our part to care for our fish friends in trouble by restoring native habitat up and down their spawning grounds--Redwood Creek.

As in all areas of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area, look, but don’t take--fishing is not allowed!
information.name: Fish friends

sites.name: Fern Creek Trailhead

sites.description: [Gray Whale Cove State Beach](http://www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=528) is one place to park to access trails at Rancho Corral de Tierra, although it is a long hike in through McNee Ranch State Park.
sites.name: Gray Whale Cove State Beach

sites.description: The Lyon Street steps connect Cow Hollow to Pacific Heights and the Presidio's Broadway Gate along a series of terraces adorned with finely trimmed hedges, and stunning views of the bay. Take this route to avoid a throng of joggers!
sites.name: Lyon Street Steps

sites.description:
One aspect of serpentinite rocks is an abundance of seeps and springs formed where groundwater moves along fracture surfaces and escapes to the surface. This groundwater is often very alkaline, and can be home to plant species specifically adapted to those conditions, like Franciscan thistle. The willows seen here grow naturally in wet areas and are indicative of water near the ground surface, in this case coming from serpentine seeps. 

This willow grove provides exceptional habitat for song birds. Keep your eyes peeled for warblers and sparrows. You may also hear the chittering and whistling dive-bombing of an Anna's hummingbird. Hawks and ravens are common sights overhead taking advantage of the updrafts over the bluffs, and looking out to sea you may spot cormorants, brown pelicans and surf scoters.
sites.name: Willow grove: Home to song and water birds

sites.description: Situated on the northeastern flank of the Santa Cruz Mountains, Phleger Estate was once heavily logged for its redwood trees. Century-old stumps and steam powered sawmill remnants are still visible. Thankfully for nature lovers, so are the redwoods, which have grown back along the creeks and trails.

information.description:
For access to the trails at Phleger, park in the lot near Huddart County Park, on the southern side of the estate. The trails here are well maintained and frequented by equestrian horse-friend types, but are also great for hikers. No dogs or bicycles are permitted at the Phleger Estate.

The trails at Phleger Estate combine for approximately 4.6 miles of moderate difficulty out and back hiking under the cover of secondary growth redwoods.

Take the trail from the Huddart County Park entrance to the Miramontes Trail, which leads to both the Mount Redondo and Raymundo Trails, which in turn lead to the Lonely Trail.
information.name: Trails at Phleger Estate

information.description: In 1848, when gold was discovered at Sutter's Mill in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, people from all over the states and indeed, the world, went gold-crazy. San Francisco's population ballooned from a few hundred to more than 30,000. The need for homes, hotels, businesses and other buildings helped fuel a lucrative logging industry, including Phleger Estate, then known as Mountain Meadow.
information.name: Gold-digging

information.description: Union Creek winds along Phleger Estate's eastern edge, once powered more than a dozen lumber mills, which operated during the wet winter months. From 1852 to 1855, entrepreneur Willard Whipple logged the area for his lumber concern. Remnants of Whipple's operation remain on site today.
information.name: From water to steam power

information.description: The San Andreas fault line runs through Phleger Estate forming a rift valley of low-lying, marshy terrain along Union Creek.  The area west of the fault is rising due to pressure built up along the fault, forming the Santa Cruz Mountains to the west. The mountains rose about three feet during the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake.
information.name: San Andreas activity

information.description: Herman Phleger, a respected San Francisco lawyer and his wife Mary Elena Phleger, bought the large country house above west Union Creek in 1931. They were early supporters of the Save-the-Redwoods League, and in 1994, Mary Phleger sold the estate to the Peninsula Open Space Trust. The land was then turned over to the National Park Service.
information.name: Private Estate to National Park

sites.name: Phleger Estate

sites.description: Muir Beach has a three-dimensional cast-bronze tactile map of the Redwood Creek Watershed. The model has tactile letters and braille along its surface, as well as raised features representing roads and trails. Additionally, the model contains a compass rose in alignment  with its geographical surroundings. On top of that, it’s a working hydrological model of a watershed.
sites.name: Muir Beach  A D - Redwood Creek Watershed tactile model

sites.description:
For any emergencies on the beach or in the water, or if you're in need of assistance at Stinson Beach, go to the Lifeguard Station, located at the far southern end of the beach.

Been surfing all day? Worn out from playing with the kiddies? Need an adult beverage? Come get your grub on at the [Siren Canteen](http://www.thesirencanteen.com/). It's right by the beach next to the Lifeguard Station, and offers shaded seating and ocean views for maximum relaximum. No kooks!
sites.name: Stinson Beach Lifeguard Station and the Siren Canteen and Café

sites.description:
The Main Post has had many lives over several centuries. It housed three nation’s militaries before taking on its modern incarnation as a place of recreation, serving the public with a variety of programs and events. 1994 was the year the Presidio became a national park, which allowed the Main Post to become the rocking spot it is today. 

Stop by the visitor center in Building 36 on Lincoln Boulevard talk to a ranger and pick up maps and brochures. Open Thursday through Sunday from 10 am to 4 pm.

information.description:
The Spanish first surveyed the land they called "Alta California" in 1769, which included modern San Francisco. A delegation of 193 colonists and soldiers with one priest returned in June of 1776 to the San Francisco Bay to establish a presidio. When completed, it was the northernmost military outpost of the Spanish on the American West Coast. 

Presidio soldiers forced the Ohlone and Miwok people into newly established Spanish-style communities, and posted sentries to protect the frontier from other colonial powers. Women and children often outnumbered the men. Thin soil and strong coastal winds made agriculture and cattle grazing difficult, but colonists bent themselves to the task, though their efforts took a toll on the land and their bodies. 
 
In the late 1700s, northern California was the Spanish wild frontier. Presidio residents received supply shipments at most once a year. In 1792, a British ship sailed to the bay and reported the Spanish fortification was poorly supplied and defended, prompting the Spanish to build more fortifications in the area. 

The Spanish lost control of the region entirely the citizens of Mexico fought and won their independence in 1810, and took over former Spanish interests on the continent, including the Presidio. However, The Mexican Era of the Presidio was characterized by promised intentions from the new government meant to support the outpost that never came to pass. Soldiers were constantly owed back pay, a fact that turned their allegiance away from their commanders.
