For the next few years, the Black Point community became a center for political and social dialogue. With the outbreak of the Civil War, the army reclaimed the land and constructed a proper military fort here.
information.name: The abolitionists of Black Point

information.description:
The community of Black Point staunchly supported California Senator and "Free Soiler" Democrat David Broderick for his anti-slavery beliefs. The outspoken Broderick managed to get elected on his anti-slavery platform in a time when the issue was divisive, but it cost him a friendship with fellow politician and one-time Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court, David Terry.
 
Not only did the friendship sour, but because Terry insisted on some rather strong statements concerning Broderick's character in addition to claims that Broderick's election to the Senate contributed to Terry's own losing re-election campaign, things went from bad to worse to awful. Terry challenged Broderick to a duel at Lake Merced, south of the city and Broderick accepted. The two men chose pistols to settle their affair. Broderick's misfired into the ground before the official count was over, giving Terry the right at a free shot, which found its target in Broderick's lung. Two days later, Broderick succumbed to his wound at his friend Haskell's Black Point home, where he was heard to say he'd been killed for his support of freedom and accountable government.
information.name: Dueling ideologies

information.description: The army re-activated Point San Jose in 1863 to defend gold-laden San Francisco against potential Confederate attack. Following the Civil War, the post became the headquarters of the US Army 9th Infantry Regiment, and served as the military headquarters for the US Army on the West Coast.
information.name: Active army once again

information.description: Right around Halloween in 2010, archaeological monitoring near the hostel at Fort Mason led to an excavation and discovery of a pit filled with human bones. 1,400 human bones to be exact, enough for about 20 bodies, all stacked by type. Research is on-going, though a leading theory about the remains ties them to the Point San Jose hospital in the 1860s, where a Dr. Edwin Bentley is thought to have used the bones to teach medical students about cause of death.
information.name: A spooky discovery

sites.name: Black Point Battery

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Spirit of the forest
The wayside is right of the trail.
Panel Description
333 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 36 inches by 14 inches.

View from the wayside:
52 words.

Beyond it, a giant redwood, with two separate trunks growing from one shared base is visible. In the middle of the base there’s a round hole you can see all the way through, like a porthole. The tree stands on a slight slope, the ground is covered in sorrel, ferns and duff.

The text reads: Old growth forests include trees of all ages, many over 250 years old, along with standing snags, logs on the forest floor, organic material in the streams, and many species of native wildlife. Such a forest is biologically complex and ecologically stable. Today, Muir Woods offers people from near and far a chance to experience a small remnant of the old growth redwood forest that was once widespread along the coast of northern California. 

This panel features a panoramic illustration of forest animals and plant life. At the top of the picture a spotted owl, wings spread wide, swoops towards the forest floor. A snail and bright yellow banana slug inch their way across a decomposing log with a colony of orange-capped mushrooms growing beneath it. On the far left of the illustration, a pileated woodpecker is perched vertically on a gray tree trunk. His bright red crest and black and white striped breast stand out against the green and reddish-brown background of the forest. In the distance, a bright blue Steller’s jay dives towards the ground. 

An orange and black butterfly with white spots covering the tips of its wings hovers over a branch just above the shallow waters of a creek. Green, feathery ferns line its banks. On the far bank of the creek, reddish-brown redwood trunks with deep grooves in their bark can be seen stretching deep into the forest. 

At the bottom of the panel is a quote that reads: “The clearest way into the Universe is through a forest wilderness.” John Muir, 1890

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 21

sites.description:
16. Wayside Panel: Bohemian Grove
The wayside is right of the trail. 

Panel Description
279 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches.

View from the wayside:
24 words.

Behind it, ferns stretch far into the distance of a small clearing. To the left of the clearing, is a massive redwood family circle. 

The text reads: California’s renowned Bohemian Club held its annual midsummer encampment on this spot in September 1892. To prepare for the event, club members built a road into the canyon, set up camping and dining facilities, and created a large amphitheater complete with log seating. A low wall topped by colored lanterns surrounded the amphitheater and formal entranceway. A huge statue of Buddha dominated the scene.

At the center of the panel is a black and white photo of the plaster Buddha statue. The white plaster is a stark contrast to the darker colors of the woods. A row of lanterns on either side of a railed walkway lead up to the 70-foot high statue  modeled after the famous thirteenth-century bronze Buddha in Kamakura, Japan.

In the top right corner of the panel is a black and white photo of the Bohemian Club members sitting under umbrellas, enjoying a musical interlude during one of the club’s annual midsummer encampments.

The text reads: The Bohemian Club was founded in San Francisco in 1872 as a men’s club. Its original membership consisted of newspapermen, artists, actors and musicians. By the 1880s, newer members included bankers, politicians, and railroad tycoons. Each summer they met outdoors to camp, drink, play cards, listen to music, and perform plays. In 1900, the club purchased land near the Russian River in northern California, where they still hold their annual summer outing.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 16

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: A Quiet Appreciation
The wayside is right of the trail.
Panel Description 
317 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches.

View from wayside:
67 words.

To the left of the wayside is  a redwood that’s grown straight and tall, with downed wood and baby redwoods growing in a thick clump at its base. To the right of the tree, there’s a small clearing with ferns and sorrel covering the ground. Beyond the clearing is a wood fence and somewhat visible through the brush, the Visitor Center and Gift Shop.

The wayside features a colorful artist’s illustration of forest animals and plant life. At the top of the picture a spotted owl, wings spread wide, swoops towards the forest floor. A snail and bright yellow banana slug inch their way across a decomposing log with a colony of orange-capped mushrooms growing beneath it. On the far left, a pileated woodpecker is perched vertically on a gray tree trunk. His bright red crest and black and white striped breast stand out against the green and reddish-brown background of the forest. In the distance, a bright blue Steller’s jay dives towards the ground. 

An orange and black butterfly with white spots covering the tips of its wings hovers over a branch just above the shallow waters of a creek. Green, feathery ferns line its banks. On the far bank of the creek, reddish-brown redwood trunks with deep grooves in their bark can be seen stretching deep into the forest. On the right side of the picture, a hummingbird hovers in the air, her thin beak reaching into orange blossoms.

The text reads: A Quiet Appreciation. The primeval forest is more than what we see, it’s also what we hear--and what hears us. By walking quietly, we protect the natural soundscape of Muir Woods that is vital to wildlife and valued by visitors. Please talk softly. Turn off cell phones. Encourage children to walk quietly.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 4

sites.audio_description:
Wayside Panel: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
The wayside faces east in front of the Crissy Field Center.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame
 
View from the wayside:
 
Facing east, the Beach Hut is to your left, and the Crissy Field Center is to the right. Both are part of the same building, which features an all-glass façade and reddish-orange siding reminiscent of the Golden Gate Bridge. The building is segmented, with alternating sections with tall ceilings that draw back at a downward angle towards the back of the building, and linking corridors with lower ceilings. In front of the entrance to the Beach Hut is a patio area with several large, green chairs and tables. Beyond the wayside across the lawn is a water fountain.
 
The text reads:
 
The Crissy Field Center is an environmental education and leadership center for youth and their communities. Programs encourage new generations to become bold leaders for thriving parks, healthier communities and more environmentally just society. Through this partnership of the National Park Service, the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy and the Presidio Trust, the Center also works to provide park opportunities for underserved audiences.
 
This green building is on its way to attaining LEED Platinum status and the Center has been a Certified Green Business since 2010. From building construction to sustainability in its future--for people, and for the planet. “Reduce, reuse, recycle” are demonstrated here in many ways.
 
This panel features a very simple illustration of the Crissy Field Center. The diagram shows the outline of the building's floor plan, as well as its walls, but not the roof. The result is an outline that shows the basic contours of the space. On the right side of the outline in the space where the roof would be is a yellow grid of squares that together, make up a rectangle, and above this, the sun, rendered as a yellow circle with lines radiating from it in a ring.
 
Below the illustration of the Crissy Field Center several photographs along the bottom. The first is of a large solar panel mounted on a trailer. The panel appears to be one rectangular piece, but is broken up into 14 smaller black rectangles.
 
The text reads:
 
Because building components were manufactured off-site, construction waste was greatly reduced. The advanced pre-engineering substantially slashed the demand for raw materials, and made the construction site virtually waste free.
 
During construction, electricity from the grid was used as little as possible. Contractors had a solar generator on site that provided the electricity for their tools.
 
The next photo is of a long tunnel with a rounded roof made of wood panels. To the right of this photo is another photo, a close-up of several light brown wood planks.

The text reads:
 
The Center abounds with creatively reused and repurposed materials. The raised flooring, for example, came from a Hewlett-Packard facility. The redwood siding is re-milled from lumber salvaged from an old railway tunnel in Marin County.
 
The last photo is of the frame of a building under construction. Only two wood frame panels have been installed along one side of a wall. Two workers are in the midst of lowering and placing a window pane next to them.
 
The text reads:
 
Every effort was made to incorporate recycled materials in the Center. More than 35% of the building is made of recycled content. This includes the steel frame (up to 95% recycled), light gauge steel walls, roof panels, ceiling tiles (77% recycled), and carpet tiles.

End.

Walk 72 feet to the west, down the steps behind you and continue walking straight until you nearly reach the edge of the plaza and East Beach parking lot. To your left is a wayside.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 2

sites.description:
Once the site of a Coastal Artillery post, Fort Cronkhite in its modern incarnation is used to educate visitors about its past, and its facilities are used to house a number of park partners including NatureBridge, the Marin Headlands Nursery, and the Marine Mammal Center.

_Fort Cronkhite during WWII_

When the US joined the Allied powers in 1941, a real concern grew in the minds of citizens and the armed forces that the California coast was subject to attack by the Japanese. Soldiers were posted up and down the coast, digging foxholes along ridges where they hid while using spotlights and listening stations to monitor the skies for enemy aircraft.

The buildings at Fort Cronkhite are typical of thousands of wartime barracks, mess halls and supply buildings built around WWII, and retain that aesthetic today, though their facilities have been repurposed for modern use. Fort Cronkhite originally housed hundreds of Coast Artillery soldiers assigned to the army's Harbor Defenses of San Francisco. The soldiers manned gun batteries, radar sites and other fortifications on the high ridges overlooking the fort, waiting for an enemy that never came.
sites.name: Fort Cronkhite

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: San Francisco Port of Embarkation
The wayside faces north west on the norther side of the path.
 
View from the wayside:
 
The wayside overlooks the waters of the San Francisco Bay, below are the buildings and piers that comprise the Fort Mason Center. In the distance to the west, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge and to the north, the Marin Headlands.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
The panel features a map of Fort Mason Center with a purple star and the words “You Are Here” placed along a path on the northern edge of the Great Meadow, above the Fort Mason Center pier.
 
The text reads:
 
Soldiers shipped out from here
 
First the Spanish and then the American military used this bluff to guard the harbor against hostile invasion. As the 19th century came to a close, Fort Mason's mission shifted from keeping enemy ships out of the bay to sending the U.S. military ships overseas. By 1915, Fort Mason was the army's primary depot for shipping troops and supplies to conflicts and colonial territories in the Pacific.
 
In 1932, the transport operation, which occupied all of lower Fort Mason and several other bay area port facilities, acquired the name San Francisco Port of Embarkation (SFPE). In 1939, the SFPE employed more than 30,000 people. They had shipped more than 23 million tons of cargo and 1.65 million soldiers on 4,000 freighters and 800 troopships.
 
 
The panel features a black and white photograph of the side of a ship packed with men in white sailor's uniforms lining the decks, with life preserving ships hanging above them, off the side of the ship. A striped smoke stack is visible rising up behind the men in the background.
 
The text reads:
 
Soldiers on ship at Fort Mason.
 
Below the photo of the men on the ship is another black and white photo, of several buildings, and a truck with its long bed covered in a canvas tarp.
 
The text reads:
 
The story of Fort Mason's port is the story of America's emergence as a world power. By 1890, the United States had fulfilled its perceived destiny to span the continent, and the nation's military and economic interests were extending abroad. The piers and buildings of lower Fort Mason were built between 1909 and 1914 to support operations and ambitions in Hawaii, Guam, the Philippines, Panama Canal Zone, and other Pacific locations. Shipping continued from Fort Mason until 1962.
 
In its top right corner, the panel features a black and white photograph of a white, three-story building with a pointed roof and flag hanging above its entrance between the windows of the second and third floors.
 
The text reads:
 
The Port of Embarkation's headquarters occupied the building at the east end of the sweeping lawn to your left. The headquarters staff handled the immense amount of coordination work involved in moving troops and supplies to and from the Pacific.
In the bottom right corner of the panel is a black and white photograph of several rows of uniformed women at attention in front of a flagpole flying the American flag, and a row of palm trees.
 
The text reads:
 
The first west coast deployment of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps (known as WAACs) was to the San Francisco Port of Embarkation in 1943. In addition to clerical work, which was both abundant and critical at the depot, WAAC personnel worked as drivers and mechanics in Fort Mason's motor pool.
 
End.
 
Walk 390 feet further west to reach the next wayside located on the northern side of the path just to the left of a steep, narrow staircase that descends to Fort Mason Center.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 9

sites.description:
Muir Woods National Monument
649 words.

The entrance to Muir Woods National Monument is located along a sharp bend on Muir Woods 

Road. Limited parking is available in a small lot to the east of the Visitor Center.

Facing west from the parking lot, the plaza is directly ahead of you. The plaza is an open space 

leading to the Visitor Center, ticket kiosk and entrance to the woods, all to the north. The Visitor 

Center is to the right of the ticket kiosk, and the entrance to the woods is a few feet further north 

behind both buildings. Bathrooms are located at the south west corner of the plaza, near the 

passenger drop off along Muir Woods Road.

In the middle of the plaza is a bronze, three-dimensional tactile model of Muir Woods and the 

Redwood Creek Watershed. The plaza is lined with wooden benches around its perimeter. To 

the north, a large wooden sign marks the entrance to Muir Woods, and a lone redwood towers 

over the shorter canopy of Douglas firs that crowd out the sky. As you pass under the wooden 

sign the asphalt of the plaza becomes a boardwalk path.

As you pass under the wooden entrance sign, you are immediately surrounded by a dense 

forest. The main section of Muir Woods is a 1.3 mile loop consisting of the Redwood Creek and 

Bohemian Grove Trails. The trails are a combination of wooden boardwalks and asphalt that 

circle around redwood groves and lead back to the Visitor Center and plaza. While you can take 

either trail to start, the loop is designed to begin with Redwood Creek Trail. From the entrance 

to the woods, Redwood Creek Trail is the path that forks slightly east, to the right.

Along the Redwood Creek Trail, you will encounter the Muir Woods Cafe and gift shop, 

Redwood Creek, Founders Grove and Cathedral Grove. Four bridges cross over Redwood 

Creek from the Redwood Creek Trail. The first three link Redwood Creek Trail to Bohemian 

Grove Trail to the west. The fourth bridge leads up to the Hillside Trail. Take any of the first 

three bridges to the Bohemian Grove Trail in order to loop back to the Visitor Center and 

entrance.

Beginning at the entrance sign to the woods, it is about a one tenth of a mile walk along 

Redwood Creek Trail to the Muir Woods Trading Company gift shop and cafe. A short series of 

stairs leads to the cafe and gift shop to the right of the trail. 75 feet further north, an accessible 

ramp to the right of the trail also provides access to the gift shop, cafe and bathrooms. The 

stairs and ramp lead to an outdoor patio. The cafe and gift shop are straight ahead, the 

bathrooms are to the left of the gift shop, which is left of the cafe. Left of the trail, directly 

opposite the junction that leads to the Muir Woods Trading Company is Bridge 1, which cuts 

west, or, to the left of Redwood Creek Trail.

Continuing north about two tenths of a mile from the gift shop is Founders Grove, a wider 

section of the woods that features some of its largest redwoods. These coniferous giants have 

soft, pulpy bark with a reddish hue, which gives them their name. Park staff lead periodic talks 

on the history and ecology of Muir Woods in Founders Grove. 

Bridge 1 and Bridge 2 are two tenths of a mile apart. Bridge 2 and Bridge 3 are one tenth of a 

mile apart. Bridge 3 and Bridge 4 are half a mile apart. Bridge 3 is the final turnaround and 

connection between the Redwood Creek and Bohemian Grove Trails. Bridge 4 crosses over the 

creek and leads up to the Hillside Trail. A series of 21 wayside interpretive panels are arranged 

beginning in the plaza, along the loop trail, Cathedral Grove and the Bohemian Grove Trail.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: A Tree for the Ages
The wayside is right of the trail. 
Panel Description
416 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 28 inches by 12 inches.

View from the wayside:
63 words.

To the left of the wayside, is a cross-section of a redwood five feet in diameter housed within a wooden pavilion. It sits like a gong, with its smooth, circular surface oriented vertically. The round is dark brown and smooth along its surface, while its edges retain its rough bark. White, concentric circles are painted along its smooth surface roughly eight inches apart.

The lines are labeled with bronze arrow-shaped signs pointing to white painted lines, each representing an historical event concurrent with the tree’s life. The arrows feature both tactile and Braille lettering.

An arrow with 909 A.D. written on it, points at a divot in the center of the tree, the year the tree was born. Moving out from center, is the first line representing the year 1100, the time period when the Mesa Verde cliff dwellings were built. Next, the year 1325, the year the Aztecs began construction on Tenochitlán. Followed by 1492, the year Columbus sailed to the Americas. 1607, the year the Jamestown colony was established. 1776, the signing of the Declaration of Independence. 1849, the California gold rush begins. 1908, Muir Woods is established. And finally, 1930, the year the tree fell.      

At the center of the wayside panel is an illustration of the redwood cross-section. 

The text reads: The slice of a redwood tree before you was put on display here in 1930. Careful study of its rings revealed that it had lived 1,021 years. The painted lines on the cross section highlight some of the historical events that occurred in other parts of North America while the tree was alive.

The illustration has an annotation that reads: Evidence of Years Past: A new tree ring is created each year as thick, light-colored wood cells are added by the tree early in the growing season, followed by a layer of thin, dark cells late in the growing season. Unusually wet years tend to result in wide rings; dry years tend to result in narrow rings. Dark areas of ash and charcoal reveal that the tree lived through fire and healed afterward.

At the bottom of the panel is a quote that reads:

“God has cared for these trees, saved them from drought, disease, avalanches, and a thousand straining, leveling tempests and floods; but he cannot save them from fools—only Uncle Sam 
can do that.” John Muir, 1897

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 6

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Fall in Muir Woods
The wayside is against the south side of the Visitor Center.
Panel Description
489 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame. 36 inches by 14 inches.

View from the wayside:
56 words.

The wayside stands against the side of the Visitor Center, facing north. To the west and left of the wayside is the junction between the plaza and the entrance to Muir Woods to the north.

The text reads: Warm days, gold and crimson foliage, and migratory animals mark the season.

Sonoma chipmunks busily prepare for hibernation. They forage through the woods in search of seeds, nuts, and berries. When their cheek pouches are full, they dig a small hole, empty the food into it, and then cover it with dirt and leaves.

Throughout the season, convergent ladybugs cluster on understory plants. They have flown here in early summer to escape inland heat. They now gather in dense clusters near the creek, conserving body heat and emitting a foul smelling odor to ward off predators while they rest. In early spring they will wake up, mate, and return inland to lay their eggs.

Fall foliage floats to the canyon floor like rain drops. Poison oak’s “leaves of three” are flaming red, the maple leaves change from green to mustard, and the California bay-laurel leaves turn lemon yellow. These colorful leaves are not only a beautiful sight, they also provide nutrients for the forest and its animals. Big-leaf maples nourish black-tailed deer with calcium and potassium. Water striders feast on decomposing leaves in Redwood Creek. Migratory and resident birds fuel up on ripened poison oak, huckleberry fruits, tan oak acorns, and cow parsnip seeds.

October is the end of the dry season, when fires are a natural occurrence in the forest. Fires release nutrients tied up in the soil, burn weak trees that compete for light in the forest canopy, clear piled up debris in the understory, and kill insects or disease that can potentially harm a forest. Bare mineral soil is necessary for redwood seeds to grow and allows the forest to regenerate.

Along the bottom of this panel is a timeline representing September, October and November, and the corresponding fall events that occur in each month. Under September, the following events are listed: ladybug cluster, height of fall color and warmest time of year. Under October: fire season. Stretching across both October and November: berries, buckeyes, and acorns ripen. Under November: migrating birds arrive and rainy season begins.

This panel features three illustrations. The largest shows leaves floating on the surface of clear water. The leaves are brightly colored, a shade between green and yellow. Below them in the water, small rocks line the waterway.

The caption reads: Decomposing leaves in Redwood Creek nourish insects, salamanders, birds, fish and creekside plants.

The other two illustrations are of wildlife. One shows a Sonoma chipmunk nibbling a blossom on a branch. The other shows ladybugs sitting close together on thin branches.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 2

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Redwoods and their Relatives
The wayside is oriented to the south in the middle of the trail, in front of a circular section of the boardwalk.
Panel Description
482 words. Graphic panel set into a carved wood frame, 36 inches by 20 inches.

View from the wayside: 
58 words.

In between sections of the boardwalk is an exposed section of the forest floor, covered in branches, brown conifer needles, redwood sorrel and ferns. Arranged along the circular perimeter are several potted treelings, examples of different redwood varieties and relatives. Among them, are the Japanese cedar, taiwania, Chinese fir, umbrella pine, pond cypress, bald cypress and giant sequoia. 

This panel features three artist’s illustrations of redwoods and their relatives. On the left is an illustration of a bushy, triangular tree that resembles a classic Christmas tree shape, the dawn redwood. It’s the shortest and squattest of the three. Next is an illustration of a coast redwood, taller and narrower than the others. The final illustration is of a giant sequoia. It’s nearly as tall as the coast redwood, but not quite. The sequoia is substantially thicker than either the dawn or coast redwoods, and its needles are the darkest. They grow in bunchy clumps along its stubby branches.  

Also included on the panel is a map of Asia, Australia and the Americas. A numbered list of redwoods and their relatives, all members of the family Taxodiaceae, corresponds with areas on the map marked with the corresponding numbers to each tree species, indicating their modern regional distributions. Giant sequoias and coast redwoods are found in California. China is home to the dawn redwood, Chinese fir and Chinese swamp cypress. Taiwan has both the Taiwan fir and taiwania. Japan has both the Japanese cedar and umbrella pine. In Tasmania, you can see the King William pine, Tasmanian pencil pine and summit cedar. Florida has both pond and bald cypresses, and Mexico, the Montezuma cypress.

The text reads: The coast redwood belongs to the plant family Taxodiaceae, which also includes fourteen other species. Members of the Taxodiaceae family are conifers that generally have soft wood, long, straight trunks, round cones, and narrow, needle-like leaves. The giant sequoia and the dawn redwood are the most closely related to the coast redwood.

Over forty species of the Taxodiaceae family once thrived in a warmer, wetter climate than the one that prevails today. Now there are fifteen “relict” species remaining, mostly around the Pacific Rim. Many have been given misleading common names-fir, cedar, pine—because of their similarity to these other conifer families.

Some of these trees are now quite rare, and may become even more so. Climate change, which was a significant factor in the reduction of the area where redwoods can grow, is a continual process. It is probable that today human activity plays a role in the current rapid progress of global warming. Scientists estimate that a three to four degree increase in global temperature could eliminate the cool, moist coastal zone in California. What, then, might the future hold for the coast redwoods?

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 5

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Preserving the Forest Primeval
The wayside is right of the trail.
Panel Description
271 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches. 

View from wayside: 
97 words.

Directly behind it is a large ring of redwoods, known as a ‘family circle.’ More than 10 trees make up the circle, some with base diameters up to six feet, and others that are smaller. The ground around the trees is covered in redwood saplings,which have a lighter, brighter green than the needles of the more mature trees they surround. They’re arranged in bunches sprouting off the main trunks as high as 10 feet. On the forest floor below is a mixture of downed branches and browned-out conifer needles.

The text reads: You are entering one of the world’s last remaining ancient coast redwood forests. This magnificent forest—with its redwoods, the tallest of living things—is protected and made accessible to the public by the National Park Service for the pleasure, education, and inspiration of present and future generations. We hope you enjoy the cool, quiet serenity of this living, ever-changing forest world.

This panel features a vertical black and white photo of a man with a white beard wearing a brimmed hat, waistcoat and jacket; John Muir. He’s standing to the left of a trail in front of a redwood tree. The redwood trunk is wide, with thick grooves in its bark. Its height dwarfs Mr. Muir. More redwoods can be seen in the background, lining the trail on either side.

Below the photo is a quote from John Muir that reads: “This is the best tree-lover’s monument that could possibly be found in all the forests of the world.”

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 3

sites.description: In 1966, the [Presidio Riding Club](http://www.presidioridingclub.org/) stables were created at the site of the former vehicle sheds and the Balloon Hangar building. The 1940s vehicle sheds were enclosed and turned into horse stalls and the hangar's interior was converted into an indoor riding arena.  No public trail rides or lessons are available, but you are invited to bring your horse to enjoy the spectacular location and trails.
sites.name: Presidio Riding Club

sites.description: Redwood Creek Trail is the main drag through Muir Woods, and connects to a host of other trails leading up the flanks of Mount Tamalpais, across national park, State Park, Marin County Park and Marin Municipal Water District open spaces. From here, you can link up with the Canopy View Trail, Hillside Trail, Fern Creek Trail, the Plevin Cut or the Ben Johnson Trail.
sites.name: Redwood Creek Trail

sites.description:
7. Wayside Panel: Survivors from an ancient time
The wayside is left of the trail. 
Panel Description
372 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 28 inches by 12 inches.

View from wayside:
39 words.

Beyond the wayside, you can see willowy, lime-green horsetail stalks lining the ground. 20 feet away, fallen logs lie in a clearing where young redwoods are growing. Behind this grove of younger redwoods, older, larger ones can be seen. 

At the center of the panel is a world map showing the fossil record’s indication of ancient distribution of coast redwoods, dawn redwoods and giant sequoias. Previously, coast redwoods were found in Asia, Greenland, Europe and North America, as were dawn redwoods. Giant sequoias were in all of these areas except for Asia. 

Alongside this information are markings indicating modern day distribution of these three species. Now, the coast redwood is only present along a small strip of the California coast. Dawn redwoods are present only in a small section of southwest Asia and giant sequoias, an equally small section of California, slightly inland from where the coast redwoods are found. 

The text reads: Various species of redwoods have been alive on Earth for millions of years. They have proven to be experts at survival. More than 100 million years ago, during the Mesozoic era, members of the redwood family lived throughout the Northern Hemisphere along with dinosaurs and other now-extinct plants and animals. Then, some 65 million years ago, a great meteorite crashed into our planet, causing geologic, climatic, and other environmental changes that destroyed the dinosaurs and many other living things. Redwoods managed to survive the catastrophe and have gone on to survive fire, flood, windstorms, drought, and earthquakes. They have even survived the slow, grinding hardships associated with continental drift, climate change, and the emergence of new forms of life, including people, flowering plants, and broad-leafed trees. As the very tallest and among the largest and oldest of living things in the world, redwoods are indeed giant survivors from a time of giants.

End of text. 

Also included on the panel is an illustration of Deinonychuses; dinosaurs with long, pointed tails that stick straight back, with small forearms and powerful legs roaming a vast, ancient redwood forest. A massive downed tree looms over their heads as they walk amongst decomposing logs on the ground.  

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 7

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: The Last Word in Airfields
The wayside faces south, on the south side of the trail at the edge of Crissy Field.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
From where you're standing along the inland side of the San Francisco Bay Trail, is the edge of Crissy Field. There's a brief but steep slope leading up from the trail to the flat, unspoiled grassy field. To your right is a path that cuts diagonally west across Crissy Field.
 
The text reads:
 
U.S. Army Coast Defense Air Station
 
From 1921 to 1936, Crissy Field was at the forefront of military air operations. Home of the U.S. Army Air Corps' Coast Defense Air Station, the site included a grassy landing strip and the barracks, offices and hangars that typified the era of barnstormers and biplanes. Limited space for expansion and frequent fog eventually prompted the Air Corps to move north to Hamilton Field in Marin County.
 
This panel features two black and white photographs. The first photo is of a biplane in mid-flight, close to the ground. Its propeller is a whirring blur, but the double-decker wings, with sections above and below the cockpit are clear, as are the support poles holding them together.
 
The text reads:
 
Above: This is the earliest known photograph of Army flight operations at Crissy Field.
 
The second photograph is of several men in flat-topped Army hats and uniforms, standing under the shadow of a biplane's wing, that, at its full height, is about three feet over the men's heads. The wheel of the plane is in the lower right hand corner, and the supports connecting the two sections of the plane's wings are visible behind the men.
 
In 1921, Marshal Ferdinand Foch, commander of the victorious allied armies in World War I, inspected this new installation and pronounced it, “The last word in airfields.” Left: The Chief of the U.S. Army Air Service, Major general Mason Patrick, inspects the airfield.
 
End text.
 
End.
 
Walk west one third of a mile from and you'll arrive at the next wayside on the southern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 12

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: “The Natural” Off-Set

The wayside faces south west, overlooking the lawn in front of the Crissy Field Center and beyond that, the East Beach parking lot.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
Facing south west, this wayside looks out over the lawn in front of the Crissy Field Center. The tall, metallic vertical-axis wind turbine poles line the edge of the lawn in front of the sidewalk that borders the East Beach parking lot. Immediately to your left is an asphalt path that leads to stairs up to the Beach Hut Cafe. Go up the stairs and continue straight to go to the Beach Hut, or turn right, then left, for the entrance to the Crissy Field Center. Before the stairs that lead to the Beach Hut and Crissy Field Center is another path to the right, which takes you to several wooden benches on the left-hand side of the path. Directly behind the wayside about 30 feet away, are trash and recycling bins.
 
The text reads:
 
Using Nature's Gifts to Achieve Sustainability
 
What if each building was able to supply its own energy and water? What will our world be like? And what will our future look like? There are many ways to reduce a building's impact on the environment. One way is to maximize the use of natural elements: sun, wind and rain. Crissy Field Center harnesses nature to “off-set” the resources the building would otherwise need from the grid (the network of electricity, gas and water lines). For more information about all of the Center's green features and to see how its systems are performing, check out the interactive building dashboard for real-time data:
 
http://frogdashboard.com/crissy/home.htm
 
This panel features a photograph of a row of three black, rectangular solar panels on the roof of a building set at a 45 degree angle with the roof.
 
The text reads:
 
Off-Setting Electricity
 
Five vertical-axis wind turbines (of three designs) capture the wind that rushes through the Golden Gate. Wind speeds average 10.5 miles per hour in this area. This experimental 5.4 kilowatt (5,400 watts) system is wildlife safe, quiet and operates at relatively low wind speeds. The turbines along with the 28kW solar panel array help to off-set the electricity needed from the PG&E grid.
 
Off-Setting Natural Gas

The cafe utilizes a solar thermal hot water heater. The energy from the sun preheats water, which then moves to a standard gas heated water tank. Pre-heated water reduces the amount of gas needed to keep water hot in the tank.
 
Below the photo of the solar panels is one of a large, dark green tank with a domed cover and a metal pipe connected to it on its right side surrounded by creosote bushes. In the background, part of a building is visible on the right.

The text reads:
 
Off-Setting Water
 
A 5,000 gallon catchment tank collects rainwater for use in the facility's restrooms. More than 50% of the water used to flush toilets is reused greywater.
 
In the top right corner of this panel is a photograph of a long building with many windows that alternates between two-story and single story sections, the Crissy Field Center. In front of the center, the photo captures the image of three metal poles with different shapes at the tops.
 
End.
 
The next wayside is a little under two tenths of a mile west. Facing the Natural Off-Set wayside, walk to your right, or west, along the grassy edge of the lawn bordering the parking lot 70 feet. To your right is a crosswalk across the parking lot to the San Francisco Bay Trail waterfront path. The crosswalk takes a diagonal jog north west across the parking lot to the edge of the San Francisco Bay Trail. From where you stand, walk 18 feet to your right to cross the parking lot in the crosswalk, then, change your trajectory slightly left for 30 feet to stay in the crosswalk, then slightly right for 18 feet until the parking lot ends. Then, walk straight, or north, 30 more feet. Now you are on the San Francisco Bay Trail, a wide area for bikers, joggers and pedestrians to walk along the edge of the Bay from East Beach to Crissy Field and further west to Fort Point. The trail periodically has benches on its southern edge.

To reach the next wayside, walk 670 feet, or, a little over one tenth of a mile west on the San Francisco Bay Trail then turn left and walk 25 feet to cut across the trail to the parking lot. From the edge of the parking lot walk 20 feet straight to the crosswalk, then walk diagonally left 37 feet to reach the kiosk waysides.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 3

sites.description:
Hawk Hill offers stunning panoramic vistas overlooking the San Francisco Bay and Golden Gate Bridge. During the fall, as many as 19 different species of raptors fly over Hawk Hill in numbers greater than 20,000. Every year, [Golden Gate Raptor Observatory](http://www.parksconservancy.org/programs/ggro/) volunteers monitor the migration of these birds of prey. 

In 2011, six acres of land on Hawk Hill became the site of a major restoration effort to increase habitat for the endangered Mission blue butterflies and many bird species with declining populations. This meant removing Monterey pines and cypresses, which aren't native and likely began growing here unintentionally because their seeds were in the soil the army used for construction during WWII. After the trees were removed, thousands of native coastal scrub and prairie plants were introduced, providing more habitat to native species.
sites.name: Hawk Hill Overlook

sites.description:
8. Wayside Panel: Family Circles
The wayside is right of the trail. 
Panel Description
257 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches.

View from the wayside:
91 words.

Just beyond the wayside is a family circle of about 15 redwoods surrounding a dead, burnt snag. The snag is 30 feet tall, hollow, jagged and broken. Its outside is black from fire scarring, but inside the wood is a light brown. The redwoods in the family circle are of varying diameters, some are only one foot across, others are 5 or 6 feet across. The redwoods are growing on top of a thick pile of duff, decaying leaves and branches, with little green burl sprouts cropping up along the perimeter.

This panel features an illustration of a ring of redwoods that has sustained fire damage. Black burn marks are visible part way up each trees’ trunk. In the center of the ring is a snag. 

Text reads: Hundreds of years ago a single large redwood grew here. Then, disaster struck. The trunk of the large redwood was killed, perhaps by repeated and severe wildfire. From here you can see the original tree trunk still standing upright, now a dead and blackened snag. Despite such terrible damage, the tree did not die. Below the ground, its massive root system was full of vitality. Before long, hundreds of young, brightgreen burl sprouts began to come up around the circle formed by the root crown of the original tree. Some of those sprouts have grown into the full-sized trees that today stand in a circle around the original trunk.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 8

sites.description:
Halfway down Funston Avenue, the Alameda (Spanish for "avenue") served as the official entrance to the Presidio from the 1860s until 1895. During this period, cannonballs lined the streets as a form of decorative curbing and soldiers stood guard at the US Army’s preeminent western post.

Today, little evidence of the Alameda remains other than the four large Victorian houses that border the old post entrance where Presidio Boulevard meets Funston Avenue.
sites.name: The Alameda

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Aviation's Adventuring Years
The wayside faces south, on the southern side of the trail.

Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.

View from the wayside:
The wayside faces the green grass of Crissy Field. On the far side of the field, you can see three-story Stilwell Hall, with its rows of windows and tall columns.

The text reads:

Crissy Field 1919—1936
Like information technology today, aviation grew by leaps and bounds during Crissy Field's heyday. In the 1920s, the Air Service promoted military aviation with many news-making flights that involved Crissy Field, including aerobatic stunts and air races. Most significant were a series of long-distance flights. By 1936, airliners were crossing the nation regularly, and aviation was no longer only for daredevils.

This panel features a black and white photograph at its center of two biplanes flying in profile with Crissy Field in the background. Buildings and natural features on the ground are small and indistinct from this vantage.

The text reads:
De Havillands from Crissy Field pass over the Main Parade Ground of the Presidio in the 1920s. Note the dangling radio antenna, which is being used to pass a message from one airplace to another.

At the bottom of the panel is another black and white photograph of a biplane on the ground, being pushed backwards by five men, who stand at intervals along its wings.

Air Service men of the 91st Observation Squadron push a De Havilland DH-4B biplane into a hangar alongside Crissy Field in 1923.

This panel features a black and white photograph in its top right corner of three biplanes flying in profile with a snow-capped mountain peak behind them.

Planes from Crissy Field participated in dedication ceremonies at Lassen Volcanic National Park in 1931.

Pushing the Envelope of Flight

In October 1919, the Army launched 61 fabric-covered, open-cockpit biplanes on a transcontinental flight to test the limits and potential of air power. Fifteen “ships” lifted off this field to fly east, and 46 departed Long Island westbound for San Francisco. Only nine planes finished and nine men died trying, one was Major Dana H. Crissy. These pilots' courage and the risks they took helped pave the way for future commercial air travel.

End text.

End.

Walk west 280 feet to arrive at the next wayside on the northern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 13

sites.description: [Slide Ranch](http://slideranch.org/) connects children and adults to nature by cultivating healthy bodies and minds to foster future generations of environmental stewards. By teaching people of all ages to recognize the interconnectedness between their own health, a healthy food system and a healthy environment through farming, cooking, caring for animals and exploring wilderness, Slide Ranch is focused on positive impact into the future.

information.description:
Yes, a yurt. No, this isn't Burning Man. The yurt is available for meetings, workshops, dancing, performances and other celebrations. It's fully electrified and has a wood burning stove, portable toilet and clean water source. 

Feel free to bring as many as 40 of your closest friends to your shindig.
information.name: The yurt at Slide Ranch

sites.name: Slide Ranch

sites.description:
[The Presidio Trust](http://www.presidio.gov/) is a unique federal agency created to save and transform an historic American site, and give it new, lasting purpose into the future. The Presidio’s transformation into a national park site is the result of a collaboration between government, private organizations, non-profits and the philanthropic community. 

The Trust headquarters, located in 103 Montgomery Street, houses rotating exhibits related to the Presidio.
sites.name: The Presidio Trust

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Saving Muir Woods
The wayside is left of the trail. 
Panel Description
569 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 40 inches by 40 inches.

View from the wayside:
66 words.

To the left of the wayside, is a redwood with thick, grooved bark and a ten foot diameter, the Pinchot Tree. It is surrounded on all sides by more ancient redwoods, that together, make up Founders Grove. In order to see the branches and verdant green needles of these trees requires craning your neck all the way back, and even then, the tops aren’t always visible.

The text reads: Muir Woods National Monument was established in 1908 through the inspired leadership of William and Elizabeth Kent, Gifford Pinchot, and President Theodore Roosevelt. William Kent was a prominent businessman, outdoorsman, and community leader who later served in Congress, where he sponsored legislation that created the National Park Service in 1916. Kent and his wife, Elizabeth, acquired this redwood-filled canyon in 1905, in order to protect it as a natural area. Two years later, the North Coast Water Company tried to obtain title to the grove by eminent domain, hoping to build a dam and reservoir. To stop this maneuver, the Kents offered to give the area to the federal government if the President would use the Antiquities Act to protect it as a national monument. Kent proposed that the site be named in honor of their mutual friend, naturalist and writer John Muir. Gifford Pinchot, the first director of the U. S. Forest Service, recommended Kent’s proposal to President Roosevelt, who enthusiastically signed an executive order creating the national monument on January 9, 1908.

End of text.

This panel features four black and white photographs arranged in rows of two. Each photo is of a different pair of men. The photo in the top left, taken in 1923, shows two men wearing brimmed hats and jackets standing in front of a redwood. To their right is a large boulder. The men are William Kent and Stephen T. Mather, first Director of the National Park Service. In the adjacent photo, two men are wearing brimmed hats and jackets, standing on top of a rocky peak with a wide valley and peaks stretching into the distance behind them. They are President “Teddy” Theodore Roosevelt and John Muir in Yosemite in 1903. 

Below is photo taken in 1907, of two men dressed in formal black attire. They’re facing away from the camera, their bodies angled towards one another as though in conversation. One of the men wears a top hat, he is Teddy Roosevelt. To his right is Gifford Pinchot. The final photo shows two men wearing brimmed hats, waistcoats, ties and jackets posing for the camera. The man on the left is the taller of the two, clean-shaven and thin. To his right is a man with a long, white beard and pocket watch chain hanging from his breast pocket. They are William Kent and John Muir, respectively, standing outside the Muir Woods Inn in 1910.

Along the bottom edge of the wayside is a green and white timeline titled, “The Path to Preservation.” It represents the 101 year period from 1872, the year Yellowstone was declared a National Park, to 1973, the year Congress passed the Endangered Species Act, protecting such Muir Woods species as the Northern spotted owl and Coho salmon. 

40 feet north of the wayside, the boardwalk changes to ground level asphalt with a low, rustic wooden fence to its right.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 10

sites.description: [Cavallo Point Lodge](http://www.cavallopoint.com/) offers a variety of fine experiences for guests, from dining, luxury stays, spa treatment and more.
sites.name: Cavallo Point Lodge

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Who lives here?
The wayside is left of the trail.

Panel Description
309 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 28 inches by 18 inches.

View from the wayside:
61 words.

This wayside overlooks Redwood Creek, with its rocky creekbed partially exposed. Ferns line both sides of the bank, and a downed log stretches across the rocks from the far bank 40 feet away. To the right is Bridge 2, a cedar boardwalk with low railing wide enough for three persons to walk side by side, spanning the width of the creek to the left and west of the Redwood Creek Trail.

The text reads: Redwood forests are dark and quiet places in which wildlife may seem rare or absent entirely. It’s easy to remain unseen in this dense forest. Many forest creatures are nocturnal. 
Others live high in the forest canopy or in the soil or deep duff on the forest floor. In fact, redwood forests are surprisingly lively places.

End of text.

The panel features an artist’s depiction of animals and plant life from the perspective of the forest floor. Redwoods dominate the image, taking up the top two thirds. Below them, on the far left is a black and brown hoary bat swooping in over a gray shrew mole on the sorrel-covered ground. To its right, a Sonoma chipmunk with black and white stripes running the length of its face and back crouches on the duff. To the right of the chipmunk, inching its way through the sorrel is a bright yellow banana slug, and Echo blue butterflies resting on a leaf. An orange throated Varied thrush with blue and black feathers and an orange belly can be seen perched in the middle of the image, as a blue Steller’s jay glides in towards the ground. An Anna’s hummingbird flaps its purple wings next to a bright red blossom above a brownish-red rough-skinned newt, his big eyes on the red and polka-dotted colony of ladybugs swarming over a nearby log. 

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 11

sites.description:
Bridge 1
23 words.

From the Redwood Creek Trail heading north, Bridge 1 goes west, to the left of the trail, connecting to the Bohemian Grove Trail. 

From the Bohemian Grove Trail heading south, Bridge 1 goes east, to the left of the trail, linking to the Redwood Creek Trail.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Bridge 1

sites.description: [The Marine Mammal Center's](http://www.marinemammalcenter.org/) mission is to expand knowledge about marine mammals health and ocean environment, to inspire the global conservation. Their core mission is the rescue and rehabilitation of sick and injured marine mammals, supported by state-of-the-art animal care and research facilities, a corps of dedicated volunteers and an engaged community.
sites.name: Marine Mammal Center

sites.description:
This building is the first site of the Top Secret Military Intelligence Service Language School, a US military program that trained a group of Japanese Americans to become linguist soldiers for a variety of specialized operations in the Pacific Theater just prior to the US entering WWII. The cover story was that this place was an industrial laundry. Instead, this building was the training facility of the first MIS class, which had 30 graduates who had an accelerated six month training after the attack on Pearl Harbor. The school was then moved to Fort Snelling in Minnesota, where over 6,000 men were trained over time. 

The graduates of the MIS became interpreters, interrogators, instructors, propaganda specialists and signal technicians whose work provided vital intelligence during the war. They saved countless Allied lives and hastened the end of the war. Collectively, the graduates of the MIS earned the Presidential Unit Citation.  
 
The army moved the school to Fort Snelling after its short time in the Presidio, when, in a dark historical twist, Japanese Americans living on the West Coast were placed in concentration camps following president Franklin Delano Roosevelt's Executive Order 9066. This decision, a knee-jerk reaction to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, was implemented across the road from MIS in Building 35 at the Presidio Main Post.
sites.name: Military Intelligence Service Learning Center

sites.description: Healthy food, healthy people. [Café RX](http://caferx.net/the-food1/) is your prescription for delicious and nutritious cuisine made from the freshest ingredients.
sites.name: Café RX

sites.description:
[House of Air](https://www.houseofair.com/) is an indoor trampoline park located in a converted Presidio airplane hangar along Crissy Field. The facility features over 8,000 square feet of trampoline space.

House of Air also has a cafe and a display detailing the history of Crissy Field.
sites.name: House of Air

sites.description:
Mountain Lake is a peaceful oasis and popular location for nature lovers, runners, and cyclists. 
One of San Francisco’s few remaining natural lakes, the fresh waters here make life possible for plants, birds and other wildlife. Though the lake suffered serious degradation for many years, long term efforts to improve the environmental health of the area are proving effective.

information.description: For years, native animal friends experienced a population decline due to the lake’s proximity to Highway 1. Traffic pollution led to an accumulation of heavy metals in the water. Further challenges came from residents releasing aquatic pets—even an alligator—that competed with native wildlife in the lake. Only through diligent efforts from volunteers and the Presidio Trust has the health of the lake been restored. Thanks to an improvement in water quality, the Presidio Trust recently reintroduced the western pond turtle, three-spined stickleback, and native submerged aquatic vegetation to Mountain Lake, a sign that things are looking up for native species.
information.name: Restoring Mountain Lake

sites.name: Mountain Lake

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Braving Wind and Waves
The wayside faces north, on the northern side of the trail.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
Facing north, you're looking out towards the bay, though from this vantage, the water is barely visible. A two-story building, and a tall palm tree with a thick, dark trunk obscure the view of the water. From here, you can see the side of the building, which is shaped a bit like a barn, with a multi-angled roof that comes together at a single point at its highest section. The main entrance is to the right, preceded by a small landing accessible by four small stairs. A balcony, supported by columns extending down to the landing, frames the entrance. The building is the office for the Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary, Ocean Climate Center.
 
The text reads:
 
Fort Point Life-Saving Station
 
Activated in 1890, this U.S. Life-Saving Station was built to aid endangered seafarers in the days when San Francisco was one of the world's busiest ports. "Surfmen" braved wind and waves to rescue victims from distressed sailing ships and steamships off the central California coast and in the bay's treacherous waters. Nearly a dozen shipwrecks still lie buried along the Presidio shore.
 
This panel features two black and white photographs arranged side-by-side. One is from the perspective of being out over the water looking back to shore from a long, wooden pier. On land are several two-level buildings and a flagless flagpole. The second photograph is of a small ship with a smoke stack, half submerged in water. The Golden Gate Bridge is visible in the background.

The text reads:
 
Surfboats were launched from a "maritime railway" to ensure quick response to a call from a vessel in distress, such as the oil tanker S.S. Frank Buck.
 
In the far right corner of the panel is a third photograph of five men standing in a row in front of a large building with a second floor balcony. The men are dressed in sweaters and dark coats and hats.

The text reads:
 
Finding a Safer Haven
 
In 1990, the U.S. Coast Guard, the successor of the U.S. Life-Saving Service, moved its operations across the Golden Gate to the Horseshoe Bay at Fort Baker, where its tradition of lifesaving continues. Nonprofit organizations now use the former boathouse (to your right) and the farther commandant's quarters (to your left).
 
End.
 
Walk west just over one tenth of a mile to arrive at the next wayside on the northern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 14

sites.description:
Cathedral Grove & Bridge 3
86 words.

As you head north along Redwood Creek Trail, Bridge 3 is to the west, left of the trail. Bridge 3 is the last turn around to complete the loop path with the Bohemian Grove Trail. Continuing north along the Redwood Creek Trail will take you to Cathedral Grove and Bridge 4, which leads up the Hillside Trail. Cathedral Grove is the woods’ silent preserve, and features two waysides. The Bohemian Grove Trail also features several waysides as you make your way south back to the entrance.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Cathedral Grove and Bridge 3

sites.description: The Marine Cemetery vista overlooks a once-forgotten merchant marine cemetery where hundreds of sailors from 30 states and 43 countries were buried between 1881 and 1912. A memorial stone plaque at the vista pays tribute to these seamen from around the world who died at the nearby Public Health Service Hospital. A remnant of oak woodlands persists in this area, making it a good spot for birders.
sites.name: Merchant Marine Cemetery Vista & Memorial

sites.description:
4th of July, 1897. It’s a scorcher in old San Fran. A group of friends decides to cool off by taking a trip out to Sutro Baths, but after paying the entrance fee, one of the friends, San Francisco native John Harris, is denied entry to the pools because he’s black.
 
Mr. Harris decided to sue the Adolph Sutro. In a landmark case, just one year after the reprehensible Supreme Court decision Plessy vs. Ferguson that upheld separate but equal segregation policy for public spaces, Mr. Harris brought his case before the San Francisco Superior Court under California’s Dibble Civil Rights Act, which declared: all citizens “of every color or race whatsoever” shall “be entitled to the full and equal” facilities of “all places of public accommodation or amount.”

The suit was successful, but personally for Mr. Harris, the victory was a bittersweet, as the amount he won in damages was insufficient even to cover his legal expenses. The case, however, spurred a wave of suits across the state in the wake of Harris’ eventual success.
sites.name: John Harris Civil Rights Battle

sites.audio_description:
Baker Beach, a scenic destination at the southwest corner of the Presidio. 

Baker Beach is accessible by two parking lots. The first is located along Gibson Road, the other, which has a view of the Golden Gate Bridge and is next to Battery Chamberlin, can be reached by turning right onto Battery Chamberlin Road at the intersection with Gibson Road.

As you head towards the second parking lot at the end of Battery Chamberlin Road, the way is lined with picnic tables and barbecues along the road's right hand side. The barbecues and benches are set far back from the roadside under cover of cypress and pine trees in sandy soil. Each area has bins for trash and recycling. 

As you enter the parking lot at Battery Chamberlin, you'll see the Golden Gate Bridge in the distance. The parking lot is large, with spaces along the entire perimeter, and a section in the middle for additional parking. The bathrooms, trash and recycling are on your right as you enter. A trash bin as well as the housing for a beach access wheelchair are both to the right of the entrance to Battery Chamberlin at the far end of the parking lot. 

Past the bathrooms on the right hand side of the parking lot, is another picnic area. Tables and trash bins are located along a loop in the dark sand amidst coastal scrub. 

The beach is a sandy shore a good ways lower down from the parking lot, with views of the Golden Gate Bridge, rocky cliffs and across the Golden Gate, the brown and green peaks of the Marin Headlands. The beach is accessible from both parking lots by a short series of sand-covered wood stairs. 

The entrance to Battery Chamberlin at the far end of the parking lot starts off sandy, but quickly turns to concrete. The entrance is surrounded by an eight foot tall chain link fence. The battery houses a 6-inch rifled gun mounted on the only still functional “disappearing carriage.” The rifle is housed inside a concrete wall, shielding the gun from view where it sits on top of a raised concrete platform five feet off the ground. A short concrete staircase along the inside edge of the wall provides access to the gun, which sits in the center of the circular platform. A second staircase gives access to the top of the wall, or parapet. 

The gun barrel is steel and painted a gun-metal gray. The barrel is a long, thin cylinder sitting on top of a circular mount with disappearing carriage that is painted olive drab. The carriage rotates and pivots the gun's position. A short ladder attached to the carriage gives access to the steering wheel controls used to aim the gun.
sites.description:
Baker Beach, a mile-long sandy stretch, is located in the southwest corner of the Presidio near the 25th Avenue Gate. For stunning views of the Pacific Ocean and Marin Headlands, this is one primo spot.

The picnic area is cozy and sheltered from the wind. The tables are popular when the sun comes out, so get there early to claim a spot, especially on the weekends. The site is equipped with barbeque pits and nearby restrooms. So throw something tasty on the grill and stay awhile!

The picnic site is managed by the National Park Service Special Park Uses Group (SPUG). Visit the [SPUG website for information about group permits](http://www.nps.gov/goga/planyourvisit/permits.htm), or contact them by phone at (415) 561-4374.

information.description: Baker Beach is a great place for fun, but the ocean waters here can be dangerous. Powerful riptides can overpower even experienced swimmers. Cold temperatures and shorebreaks—waves that break directly on shore—are other potential hazards, so be careful on your day at the beach.
information.name: Ocean Safety

information.description: Beware bathing beauties in birthday suits! The north end of the beach is a place where people are traditionally under-dressed and nude!
information.name: Bare all at Baker Beach

sites.name: Baker Beach

sites.description:
An easy three-quarters of a mile from the trailhead, Haypress has five campsites that can accommodate up to four people each. Groups can reserve the entire campground from November 1st to March 31st. The rest of the year, a maximum of three sites may be reserved per group. Maximum stay is three nights per year. Some important things to consider are: there's no water available on-site, no wood or charcoal fires allowed, no pets and no fees. 

Contact the Marin Headlands Visitor Center (415) 331-1540 for reservation information.
sites.name: Haypress Campground

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: A refuge of peace and quiet
There is a fork in the trail. The wayside is located between the forking paths that lead into Cathedral Grove
Panel Description
161 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches.

View from the wayside:
38 words.

Several deep-grooved, reddish-brown redwoods tower overhead, between the forking paths behind the wayside. Two of them lean slightly to the right. In front of the trees, the ground is covered in a sweeping bed of sorrel and ferns. 

This panel features illustrations of a northern spotted owl, pileated woodpecker and winter wren, surrounding the text, which reads: Cathedral Grove was set aside as a quiet refuge to protect its natural soundscape in an increasingly noisy world. The soundscape is vital to animals for hunting and foraging, courtship and mating, nurturing young, and avoiding predators. By walking quietly, we experience the natural sounds of a living, ancient forest. We hope you enjoy the beauty of Muir Woods through both sight and sound. 

There is a quote that reads: “In every walk with nature, one receives far more than one seeks.” --John Muir

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 12

sites.description:
Born on April 29th, 1820 in Germany, Adolph Heinrich Joseph Sutro grew up to embody the American immigrant dream. He arrived in California in 1850, during the Gold Rush, and was well educated in the field of mining engineering and business. Yet, somewhat surprisingly, Sutro made his fortune not in gold but in silver, during the late 1860s and 1870s at the Comstock Lode in Nevada.

His fortune came from devising and implementing a ventilation system that rid the Comstock Lode mine shafts of water and gas by driving a tunnel through Mount Davidson. Sutro included the miners in his plans for the tunnel and worked alongside them in dangerous conditions to see the work finished. Once operational, the tunnel drained two million gallons of water a year from the mines. The tunnel was a great success. Despite the decreasing value of the lode over the 1870s, Sutro was able to sell his tunnel for a great fortune, which later became a fortune for the people of San Francisco.
sites.name: Citizen Sutro

sites.description: The trail head at Merrie Way features a large parking lot (with priority spaces for hybrid vehicles), bathrooms, cafe and Visitor Center where you'll find map displays of area trails. It's free to park here and the easiest access point to the 2.9 mile out and back Coastal Trail segment. The first part of the trail is wheelchair accessible and the entire trail is fairly easy, flat terrain with great views of the Golden Gate among cypresses and coastal scrub. Despite the relative simplicity of the trail, please be careful! There are some rugged spots, especially near Eagle's Point where the rocky cliffs can be treacherous and windy.

information.description:
The Coastal Trail, a section of the California Coastal Trail that follows the railbed of the old Cliff House Railway, gets the most love out of all the trails at Lands End. This trail is wheelchair accessible until the Mile Rock Overlook, and bike accessible until the Eagle's Point steps. A spur trail takes users to Mile Rock Point and Mile Rock Beach, which offer views of the Golden Gate.
 
This revitalized trail features diverse, native plant habitat. Along with the requisite views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Pacific Ocean and San Francisco Bay, hikers and wildlife enthusiasts are in for a world class treat. Keep your eyes peeled for marine mammals and birds—cormorants and oystercatchers are staple species—as well as landscape features like the famous Cliff House, Sutro Bath ruins and the Palace of the Legion of Honor.
information.name: California Coastal Trail

sites.name: Lands End Trailhead

sites.description:
1. Wayside Panel: Fort Mason Historic District
The wayside faces north at the sidewalk on the corner of MacArthur Avenue and Bay Street to the right of the gated entrance to Fort Mason.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set into metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
In front of the wayside are two signs on a post, one indicating that the Hostel International is one quarter mile north, and the other telling pet owners they're required to pick up after their animals.
 
About a foot past the sign, on the edge of the sidewalk, is a trashcan. The sidewalk continues north a ways before curving slightly west. The sidewalk is bordered on the right by a row of trees planted in a grassy lawn. To the left of the sidewalk is MacArthur Avenue.
 
The text reads:
 
U.S. Army post (1864-1966)
 
First fortified by the Spanish in 1797, this bluff above the bay was re-armed by the U.S. Army in 1864. The post remained active through the Civil War, western Indian Wars, and conflicts abroad, beginning with the Spanish-American War in 1898. During World War II, Fort Mason was the Army's logistics center for sending troops and supplies to the Pacific.
 
Fort Mason was designated a National Historic Landmark on February 4, 1985.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a coastal bluff with a series of buildings comprising a compound. The bluff is undeveloped except for the buildings, so that there is a lot of flat open space leading up to the buildings. A single roadway leads to the buildings. In the distance, across a body of water, mountainous terrain.
 
The text reads:
 
Though San Francisco had grown enormously by 1900, Fort Mason was isolated from the city's bustle by undeveloped open space.
 
In the right corner of this panel is a black and white photo of two men in army uniform and brimmed hats talking to one another as they walk down the steps away from a building's entrance.
 
The text reads:
 
General Dwight D. Eisenhower inspected Fort Mason in 1946.
 
End.
 
Follow the sidewalk 603 feet north to the next wayside.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 1- Fort Mason Historic District

sites.description: Named for former Presidio commander and first governor of Alta California, Luis Antonio Arguello, [Arguello](http://www.arguellosf.com/menu/) features Mexican cuisine and a contemporary bar with craft cocktails.
sites.name: Arguello Restaurant

sites.description:
Turnaround for loop trail
61 words.

This is the furthest end of the loop trail. To complete the loop, head south the way you came. At the entrance to Cathedral Grove, take Bridge 3 to the right, west of the Redwood Creek Trail. Bridge 3 will connect to the Bohemian Grove Trail which will take you south, to the left, back to the entrance of the woods.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D turnaround for loop trail

sites.description: The Landmark Buildings are home to a wide range of organizations from dining, entertainment and the arts.

information.description: Get your art on with the help of [Flax Art & Design](http://fortmason.org/resident/flax-art-design/), a full-on art emporium for all your aesthetic project needs!
information.name: Flax Art & Design

information.description: [Blue Bear School of Music](http://fortmason.org/resident/blue-bear-school-of-music/) is San Francisco’s own school of rock! Open to aspiring musicians of all ages.
information.name: Blue Bear School of Music

information.description: [Magic Theatre](http://fortmason.org/resident/magic-theatre/) gives time and space to innovative writers for their work to be cultivated and performed.
information.name: Magic Theatre

information.description: [The Mexican Museum](http://fortmason.org/resident/the-mexican-museum/) showcases the vibrant work of Latino artists and highlights the connection between their work and culture.
information.name: The Mexican Museum

information.description: [Southside Theater](http://fortmason.org/venue/southside-theater/) is a venerated performance space available for use. Follow the link for info and booking!
information.name: Southside Theater

information.description: [World Arts West](http://fortmason.org/resident/world-arts-west/) promotes and educates audiences about world cultures through dance performance and classes.
information.name: World Arts West

sites.name: Fort Mason - Landmark Building D

sites.description:
The prison building, built between 1910 and 1912 when Alcatraz was still a military prison, is a three-story cellhouse with four cellblocks. When it transferred from military control to the Bureau of Prisons, the cell bars were strengthened to better prevent escapes. The cells remained primitive and lacked privacy. African-American prisoners were segregated from the rest of the prison population due to the prevalence of racial prejudice and physical abuse amongst prisoners. D-Block housed the worst inmates in solitary confinement.

In 1972, Alcatraz became part of the newly created Golden Gate National Recreation Area and was opened to the public in 1973.

information.description: In the 1930s, the federal government developed a new type of prison for the nation’s most incorrigible bad boys. The facilities at Alcatraz were modernized to become a  maximum-security, minimum-privilege penitentiary specially designed for inmates that other prisons couldn't contain. During its 29 years of operation from 1934-1963, more than 1,500 convicts were incarcerated here.
information.name: Bureau of Prisons

information.description: The hospital began operations when the cell house was completed in 1912 and continued to provide services after Alcatraz became a federal prison. Naturally, the hospital was used to provide medical care to inmates, prison personnel and civilians on the island. In all, the hospital was made up of the recovery wards, doctor’s offices and a surgery facility. The hospital was also used to house the infamous Robert "Birdman" Strauss to isolate him from inciting and rousing the other inmates.
information.name: The Hospital Wing

sites.name: Alcatraz Cellhouse

sites.description:
The Headlands Visitor Center is a great jumping off point for all your GGNRA adventures in and around Marin County. Visit our mini-museum with exhibits detailing the many histories of the Headlands, from the Coast Miwok, 1800s American settlers and growth of the US Army. 

Learn about the local ecology with hands-on science exhibits that include feathers, bones and other natural objects connected to the exceptional landscape north of the bay. 

Our bookstore offers an excellent selection of natural history guides for the San Francisco Area. Drop by anytime from 9:30 AM to 4:30 PM or call (415) 331-1540 during the same hours if you have questions. 

Walk to the western edge of the Visitor Center parking lot next to the bathrooms and continue west along the Coastal Trail to continue to the next tour point.
sites.name: Visitor Center

sites.audio_description:
A quarter mile loop trail tucked away in a quaint neighborhood of the Presidio provides access to El Polín Spring. A limited amount of parking is available at the trailhead in a cul-de-sac on MacArthur Avenue. Standing on the cement curb facing the trail to your south, there’s a composting toilet a few feet to your right, past a row of four wooden benches. Trash and recycling bins are directly to the left of the trailhead, and a few feet further left, several bike racks. 

As you walk along the hard-packed trail, almost immediately you’ll come across a wooden staircase on your right, the first of two in succession. The first flight of stairs is brief. The second set of stairs, separated from the first by a brief, flat path, is quite long and steep. Following the steep staircase will take you to the Ecology Trail and Inspiration Point Overlook. Walking up the short flight of stairs and turning left will take you to the Mountain Lake Trail. Simply continuing along the initial path will take you around El Polín Loop, where you’ll encounter native plants and an archaeological site where a Spanish adobe structure once stood.

The floorplan of the adobe structure has been recreated using modern adobe bricks that are a bright, powdery white, and are stacked one and a half feet high on three sides of a rectangular foundation, so the shape before you is like that of a block letter “C”. The bricks are flat, wide and meticulously even. The spine of the “C”, is about fifteen feet long. It’s flanked by two incomplete sides, about half its length. The incomplete sides don’t make it all the way to their corners, but descend in a manner similar to steps or the sides of a Mayan pyramid. In the middle of the “C” is a tile floor. The tiles are large squares, the same white color as the bricks. The tile floor, like the two foundation sides, is incomplete. A section at one corner is missing. 

Continuing along the loop you will come to an open section of the trail that forms a sort of circular space, with wooden benches along the perimeter. At the far side of the circular space are two options for proceeding, and completing, the loop.
