Both routes take you up the same slight slope around the middle section of the loop. Green, native riparian plants grow around the interior of the loop. If you take the right hand fork, the trail becomes a wooden boardwalk along the curve of the loop. El Polín Spring is to your right just before the boardwalk begins. The spring water trickles over two low brick dams and then flows under the trail to emerge on the left side in a small channel made of rounded river stones. Hummingbirds frequent the spring and the buzzing of their wings may be heard. Additional wooden benches can be found along the boardwalk, which is only about one quarter of the loop. A few feet from where the boardwalk ends, the trail is bisected by a thin gully. The gully is also made of small rounded stones, and runs down the slope through the middle of the trail to the center of the loop. 

A few feet after the gully is a connecting trail off to the right that leads to the Mountain Lake Trail, Julius Kahn Playground and the Bay Area Ridge Trail. Continuing along the loop, you’ll find more wooden benches, and a small path to the left towards the interior of the loop. This path leads to a raised, circular stone structure that looks like a well built into the ground. Three stone gullies are visible from here, converging at the stone structure, where the spring and groundwater from the surrounding area is channeled and collected. The stone structure has semi-circular openings at its base that line up with the gullies and let water in from two upstream gullies and water flow out in the downstream channel. The soil in this area is damp, allowing several leafy, green plants to grow.
sites.description: Located at the heart of the Tennessee Hollow Watershed, El Polín offers visitors a chance to connect with the Presidio's earliest history, experience some of the park's best birdwatching, and to enjoy the blooms and wildlife made possible by the year-round flow of the spring.

information.description:
Before European colonists arrived, the Yelamu Ohlone lived here, and their ancestors inhabited this space for thousands of years before them. The signs of Yelamu seasonal camps are known from nearby.
 
El Polín spring provided an essential water source for the Spanish Presidio built nearby in 1776. By 1812, Spanish colonial families were firmly established at El Polín, over twenty years before the town of Yerba Buena, later named San Francisco, was founded. 

According to legend, the waters of the spring increase fertility in women. The Miramontes family, who resided near the spring in the early 1800s are often used to support this claim, as they produced 20 offspring. 

The watershed was home to tent encampments during the 1898 Spanish American War, and later served as temporary housing for San Franciscans left homeless by the 1906 earthquake. The area also saw several generations of more permanent housing. By the 1930s, several neighborhoods of brick houses had sprung up and in 1959 a new set of apartment buildings arrived when the Army expanded during the Cold War. As a result, only small pockets of riparian habitat remained.
information.name: History of El Polín

information.description:
An enduring figure of the 1800s is Juana Briones, a woman of European, Native American and African descent, who grew up at El Polin. Briones was the descendant of members of both the Anza and Portola expeditions from Mexico to Alta California. She made a name for herself as a healer, midwife and self-taught doctor, skills she is said to have learned from Native Americans. She was also a cunning businesswoman, selling milk, produce and raising cattle.

Briones was such a respected member of her community that she was able to keep her several Mexican rancho land holdings, even after California's admission to the Union in 1850, when changing laws meant many Californiano families lost their land rights. 

Though there are no authenticated surviving photos, journals, or other primary documents from Juana herself, she is well remembered.
information.name: Juana Briones

information.description:
For the past decade, revitalization has been underway within the Tennessee Hollow Watershed surrounding El Polin spring. 

The watershed covers 270 acres in the eastern Presidio. It's made up of three streams that flow north through a valley before merging into one watercourse that flows into the San Francisco Bay. Creeks provide most of the freshwater for the restored Crissy Field Marsh. 

After the US Army took over the Presidio in 1846, they changed the watershed by planting cypress and eucalyptus trees. They also redirected the flow of water by constructing dams, which were used as a water supply at the Main Post.
information.name: Restoration of the southlands

sites.name: El Polín Spring

sites.description:
European colonists realized early on that the unique geography of the Golden Gate held great significance for securing control of the region. Below the Golden Gate Bridge is Fort Point, a Civil War-era US Army post, but this was not the first fortification to be built here. 

Prior to Fort Point, the Spanish built a fort of their own, Castillo de San Joaquín, which sat on a cliff nearly in the same place as Fort Point, only higher up. Castillo de San Joaquín was destroyed when the US Army blew up the bluff where it stood, in order to build Fort Point, because they wanted their fort to be able to fire at ships from water level. 

On this walk you will mostly see concrete coastal defense structures installed from the late 1890s in a time known as the Endicott Period of coastal defenses, although a 1970s Nike ground to air missile base on the Presidio marked the final period of defenses here.
sites.name: Securing the Golden Gate

sites.description:
Built in 1895 as housing for soldiers, the iconic barracks buildings on Montgomery Street are now home to several organizations including the (Presidio Trust)[http://www.presidio.gov/], (Futures Without Violence)[https://www.futureswithoutviolence.org/] and the (Walt Disney Family Museum)[http://waltdisney.org/].

The 30th Infantry Regiment called these barracks home from 1922-1941. This unit was known as "San Francisco’s Own." The men in this outfit were highly decorated by the French government for their WWI July 1918 offensive on the Marne River, where they pushed back the German line.
sites.name: Montgomery Street Barracks

sites.description: [Fort Funston Nursery](http://www.parksconservancy.org/get-involved/volunteer/drop-in-programs/fort-funston-nursery.html) raises 25,000 native plants a year thanks to the hard work of its volunteer staff. The natives are planted all over Golden Gate National parklands, contributing to the health and beauty of our parks.
sites.name: Fort Funston Nursery

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Sunlight and Shade
The wayside is left of the trail.
Panel Description
209 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches.

View from the wayside:
34 words.

Beyond it, many ferns grow in front of a tanoak. 60 feet away, a tightly-formed family circle is visible. The trunks of the trees are dark brown and black from fire damage.

The text reads: Full sunlight rarely reaches the floor of a redwood forest. Shade-loving plants such as moss, ferns, and lichen thrive in this cool, dim, moist environment, where they may get as little as 5 percent of full sunlight. Special adaptations that make it possible for plants to live here include deciduous foliage, large leaves, or branches and leaves that bend toward the light. Redwood sorrel is so well adapted to low light levels on the forest floor that its tender, heart-shaped leaves fold down and hide when too much direct sunlight hits them. They straighten up, unfold, and turn toward the light once again as soon as shade or diffused light returns.

End of text.

This panel features an illustration of a downed redwood log stretching horizontally across the scene. Ferns and sorrel are featured in the foreground, and small, slender redwood sprouts are shooting up along the log’s exposed roots. In the background are many living redwoods.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 18

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Marsh Dynamics
The wayside faces south, on the southern side of the trail.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
This panel overlooks the Crissy Field tidal marsh. There's a fenced-off section of dune plants and coastal scrub before a sandy shore that encircles the blue waters of the marsh. On the far shore is a large white two-story building. Cypress trees and thick bushes surround the building, obscuring it somewhat from this vantage. Further in the distance, you can see the domed top of the Palace of Fine Arts. To the left, east, the trail takes you to East Beach. Right, takes you to  Crissy Field, Fort Point and the Golden Gate Bridge. 
 
The text reads:
 
How a Coastal Wetland Works
 
This tidal marsh was designed and engineered to mimic a natural system. Like the dunes that front the wetland, the system thrives on natural disturbance. Freshwater and storm runoff drain from the land into the marsh, bringing sediment that settles or is flushed out to the bay. Tides continually ebb and flow, importing mineral and organic materials. Constant movement and mixing foster a biological storehouse of organisms that can tolerate fluctuations in salinity, dissolved oxygen levels, water temperature and moisture.
 
This panel features a photograph of three small, puffy birds on a sand dune. The birds have white underbellies and brown backs, heads and wings. Their heads are turned so that they're looking over their backs.

The text reads:
 
Sandpipers in winter plumage.
 
The text reads:
 
The Original Mud Pie
 
Twice a day receding tides unveil nutrient-rich mudflats that serve up a feast to multitudes of shorebirds. Algae, fungi and decaying organic debris nurture countless invertebrates--insects, worms, crabs, clams and myriad others--that float, swim, settle to the bottom or bury themselves in the mud. This tidal menu refuels many shorebirds that stop over here during their long migration between the Arctic and South America. Though many species of shorebirds appear to eat together, their different feeding habits assure they seldom compete directly with one another for food.
 
This panel features an illustration of a brown and white bird with a very long, thin needle-like beak. The bird is walking in shallow water with its head down, its beak near the water's surface. It's labeled, "marbled godwit."
 
The text reads:
 
Long-legged wading birds ply the shallows for swimming creatures or sweep or probe the muddy bottom with their slender bills for burrowed worms, mollusks and crustaceans. Similar species such as sanderlings pick up tiny prey from the exposed mud surface or just below it.
 
This panel features a map of the Presidio. Included is a section of the Pacific Ocean to the west, and the San Francisco Bay to the north. Also labeled is a section of the Presidio beginning at a small body of water just inland from the shore of the bay and continuing down to the southeast corner of the Presidio is Tennessee Hollow watershed.
 
The text reads:
 
Freshwater laden with organic nutrients and minerals drains from the Tennessee Hollow watershed to merge with tidal inflows in the Crissy Field marsh. The mixing of freshwater with saltwater creates an estuary, a rich habitat for a diversity of plants and wildlife.
 
Below the map of the Presidio is a photograph of two yellow bulldozers in front of the reddish-brown dome of the Palace of Fine Arts. In the background, is the San Francisco skyline.
 
The text reads:
 
Construction of the Crissy Field tidal marsh in 1999 was supported by mitigation funds from the San Francisco International Airport. About 230,000 cubic yards of soil and rubble were excavated to create the marsh.
 
End.
 
Walk west  one fifth of a mile to reach the next wayside located on the northern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 10

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Setting a Deadly Obstacle Course
The wayside is left of the Crissy Field kiosk, and faces west.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
From where you stand in the middle of a large, open plaza, you're facing the bathrooms and maintenance buildings, two symmetrically identical, cream colored buildings, with red tile roofs. To the right, the Golden Gate Bridge stretches off to the right across the bay, with the rolling hills of the Marin Headlands behind it.
 
The text reads:
 
Fort Point Mine Depot
 
The Fort Point Mine Depot was created to defend the West Coast's greatest harbor from enemy attack. Here, U.S. Army personnel assembled mines, loaded them on ships and planted them in minefields outside the Golden Gate. An enemy ship attempting to enter San Francisco Bay would have had to maneuver through a deadly obstacle course. Completed in 1910, the depot remained in the service through World War II.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a building with an angled roof, a double door entrance and two identical windows on either side of the doors, highlighting the symmetry of the building. A curved path leads up to the entrance.
 
The text reads:
 
Soldiers inserted explosives into the mines in their loading rooms. Extreme care was taken to ensure that no accidents occurred.
 
This panel features two illustrations, one is a map showing the coast you're standing on now, with a brown L-shape extending out over the water representing Torpedo Wharf, and white, rectangular blocks on the green area representing land. These blocks represent buildings, including the explosive storage facilities and the mine loading rooms.The other illustration is of two devices side-by-side. Each has several sections, arranged in a vertical line, and tethered together by a rope at the bottom connecting them horizontally. The device on the left has a tan rectangular prism labeled “Planting Buoy” that looks like a brick with a ring through its center tied to a rope that descends and attaches to a gray sphere, labeled “mine case.” Below the mine case is a metal clasp that attaches to the rope tether, labeled “mine shackle.” Below the shackle, are two rope tethers running parallel to one another. One rope is short, and goes straight down, connecting to a gray circular prism, the shape of a hockey puck and labeled, “anchor.” The other rope, which is knotted to the anchor, runs horizontally to the right, and is tied to a dark gray device shaped like a pie plate, with multiple cables sticking out from its sides like spokes on a wheel. This device is labeled “distribution box.” On top of the distribution box, at its center, is an upside-down “U” shaped ring, like the top portion of a combination lock to which a rope is tied, extending upwards to a device, labeled “distribution box buoy” which resembles a barrel turned sideways, to which it is tied.

The text reads:
 
This schematic shows an underwater mine and distribution box, with temporary buoys that were placed during planting operations. Throughout the modern era of American harbor defenses (1890-1950), mines were considered to be one of the primary harbor defense weapons.
 
End.
 
The next kiosk is one fifth of a mile away. To reach it, first walk 50 feet to the south to get around the Warming Hut, then turn left to start back east. In 100 feet you'll encounter a path to your left. Follow it 90 feet then turn right to head east along a cement path for 750 feet, or, just over one tenth of a mile to a kiosk on your right.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 18

sites.description: Housed in a Works Progress Administration building originally designed as a bathhouse, the [Maritime Museum](https://www.nps.gov/safr/learn/historyculture/bathhousebuilding.htm) features exhibits on navigation, naval history, ships and more. The museum is free, and open seven days a week from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

information.description: Founded in 1947, the [San Francisco Senior Center](http://www.sfsenior.com/) is located in the Maritime Museum building near the Aquatic Park and is the oldest non-profit senior center in the entire US! With an array of programs including low-cost nutritious lunches served daily, the Senior Center is dedicated to improving the lives of San Francisco's elders.
information.name: San Francisco Senior Center

sites.name: San Francisco Maritime Museum

sites.audio_description:
Facing west from the kiosk, Rodeo Beach is 150 feet away, just on the other side of the parking lot. The bathrooms are five feet to the north of the kiosk and the parking lot, the same distance to the south. There's a grassy area to the right of the the bathrooms with five picnic tables and waste bins accessible by a cement walkway. To the south of the kiosk is a large parking lot and beyond that, a series of long, rectangular buildings with cream-colored walls, orange-tiled roofs. These were the barracks buildings at Fort Cronkhite. 

Rodeo beach is a popular destination for surfers, who can often be seen in floating on their boards amongst the breakers in the northern end of the cove. They're not the only ones who flock to these waters, though. It's a hotspot for families and people who just want to relax in the sun. Rodeo beach has a wide, sandy shore that stretches for half a mile from end to end. From the northern end of the beach, large rock outcroppings can be seen in the water to the south. Their edges smoothed and rounded by years of wear. The inland terrain around the beach is hilly, and sparsely developed. Both ends of the beach are marked by rocky cliffs that gain elevation as they jut out over the water. 

About 300 feet back from the shoreline and 400 feet from the northern tip of the beach is the mouth of Rodeo Lagoon. Another 400 feet to the south is a bridge from the beach over the lagoon back to Mitchell Road. 

From the kiosk at Rodeo Beach, it is one fifth of a mile walk east to the wayside at the northern edge of the bridge over Rodeo Lagoon.
sites.description: Rodeo Beach is a beautiful pebbly beach popular with surfers. Down the hill from Battery Townsley, and nestled between Fort Cronkhite, and the Marin Headlands Visitor Center, Rodeo Beach is a great place to start a day's visit in the Headlands. On-site barbecues and picnic tables make it possible to grill out with a group.

information.description: For access to trails, park along Bunker Road near the Marine Mammal Center. Take Old Bunker to the Coastal Trail and Battery Townsley. The trail continues both further inland as well as down to the coast where it meets the Tennessee Point Trail, which features beautiful bluffs. You can tailor your hike to your interests and time, but a full circuit of the Coastal, Wolf Ridge and Miwok Trails will take you a good half day to complete.
information.name: Trails at Rodeo Beach

information.description:
Rodeo Beach formed about 5,000 years ago when sea level rise slowed after melting of the last glacial period.  At that time, this sandy barrier beach dammed an ancient stream valley to form Rodeo Lagoon. Strong waves and currents produce the unusually coarse pebbly beach sand here today. 

Watchful beachcombers can find a rainbow of pebbles dotting the shore. The vibrant colors are the result of the most common rock found in the Marin Headlands: radiolarian chert. Trace amounts of iron in the chert pebbles are oxidized in different amounts to produce a wide spectrum of colors, including green, yellow, red and black. Admire these natural beauties all you like, but please don't take them from the beach.
information.name: Rodeo Beach Geology

information.description: Big changes could be ahead for Rodeo Beach and the lagoon. When we burn fossil fuels for energy, we add carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. This buildup acts like a blanket that traps heat, warming and expanding ocean waters, and melting glaciers. As a result, sea level is rising and storms are becoming more powerful. Barrier beaches like this become submerged during rapid sea level rise. Winter storm waves already wash across the barrier. Without its protective beach, Rodeo Lagoon would become much saltier and pose environmental challenges to rare species who make their home here, such as the tidewater goby and California red-legged frog.
information.name: Where'd the Beach Go?

sites.name: Rodeo Beach

sites.description: The Coast Guard have been in the San Francisco Bay for over a century. Their modern incarnation, the [Coast Guard Station Golden Gate](http://www.uscg.mil/d11/staGoldenGate/), is located at Fort Baker next to the Presidio Yacht Club.
sites.name: Coast Guard Golden Gate

sites.audio_description:
Kiosk Description
 
The kiosk is a four-sided object with three interpretive panels.
 
View from the kiosk:
 
Facing east at the kiosk, you are looking out over the parking lot and buildings that comprise Fort Mason Center. To the right is the parking lot, and close on your left, are the Landmark Buildings, beginning with Building B. Directly behind you is Building A, and the Fort Mason Center Office, which has maps and information about the center. East, just beyond the kiosk, is a trashcan.   
 
Kiosk Panel: Fort Mason Center
The panel faces west.
 
This panel features a map of Fort Mason Center. North is on the left hand side of the map, to reflect north's actual orientation from where you stand.
 
Marked on the map are the three piers that hold the Festival Pavilion furthest east, then the pier with Cowell Theater and Herbst Pavilion.
 
South of the piers are Landmark buildings E and D to the east, and further west, separated by a parking lot, buildings C, B and A.
 
East of the Festival Pavilion is the Fire House. In the south east corner of the map, the steep stair case to the General's Residence, Chapel and Upper Fort Mason is marked. To the South west, the gate house.
 
Below the map is a listing of the tenants inside each of the Landmark Buildings.
 
Landmark Building A
 
Gallery 308
 
Greens Restaurant
 
Main Office—Fort Mason Center
 
SFMOMA Artists Gallery
 
The Interval Bar & Café at Long Now
 
Landmark Building B
 
BATS Improv
City College of San Francisco

Cooks & Company
 
Embark Arts
 
On the Commons
 
Seedling Projects
 
Landmark Building C
 
Readers Bookstore
 
Goody Café
 
Museo Italo Americano
 
Meeting Rooms C205-C260
 
San Francisco Children's Art Center
 
Young Performers Theatre
 
Lily CAI Chinese Dance Company
 
Environmental Traveling Companions
 
California Lawyers for the Arts
 
Landmark Building D
 
Flax Art & Design
 
Blue Bear School of Music
 
Magic Theatre
 
The Mexican Museum

Southside Theater
 
World Arts West
 
Landmark Building E
 
SF Maritime National Historic Park (Headquarters Offices)
 
Maritime Research Center
 
Bathrooms located in Buildings B, C, D
 
ATM in Building B Lobby
 
Food in Buildings A, B, C
 
Kiosk Panel—Fort Mason Center
The panel faces west.
 
The text reads:
 
From Army Port to Vibrant Cultural Center
 
After the last army ships embarked from Fort Mason in 1962, the port's piers and warehouses were left empty. Fog and pigeons found their way inside while the once important Port of Embarkation grew dilapidated. The facility's fate changed when Fort Mason became part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area in 1972.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of two three-story buildings with large, covered flatbed trucks parked outside them.
 
Over the next few years, the National Park Service considered more than 400 proposals for converting the site to civilian use. Ultimately, in 1977, Fort Mason became a national model for re-use of surplus military property when the deserted port was brought back to vibrant life as a community-based cultural center. More than a million people come to Fort Mason Center each year.
 
This panel features two photos juxtaposed diagonally to one another. The first is a black and white photo of a long, hangar-like building with a high ceiling, with stacks of crates on the right, a train car and large industrial equipment.
 
Below, a photo of the same building, converted and housing several tables and ornate sculpted vessels framing two women at dinner, and many more people dining behind them.
 
Fort Mason Foundation, established to manage Fort Mason Center, has raised millions of dollars to preserve and renovate the fort's historic Mission Revival-style buildings. A partnership between the foundation and the National Park Service allows Fort Mason Center to offer affordable space—more than 300,000 square feet—to nonprofit groups and visiting events, and to ensure affordable programs for visitors.
 
Park Partners and Events
 
Special events and programs of all sorts and sizes take place in Fort Mason Center's pier pavilions, theaters, and other spaces. Groups at home here year-round include Blue Bear School of American Music, Chinese Cultural Productions, Endangered Species Project, Environmental Travel Companions, Mexican Museum, Oceanic Society, Sailing Education Ventures, and San Francisco's Children's Art Center.
 
This panel features a photo of a woman with short hair wearing chef's whites smiling as she holds up a basket of brightly colored produce, with more peppers, potatoes and gourds on a table in front of her.
 
The text reads:
 
Renowned Greens Restaurant, open since 1979, has turned notions about vegetarian fare upside down with gourmet food so satisfying you might feel indulgent, but never deprived. Much of Greens' produce is grown on its own organic farm in Marin County, and other farms that employ planet-friendly growing methods.
 
To the right of the photo of the chef, are three more photos arranged vertically.
 
The top-most photo shows several kayakers, some in individual kayaks and some in two-person vessels, passing under the Golden Gate Bridge on a clear day with a blue sky and hazy cloud overhead.
 
The next photo is of two men wearing short sleeve shirts and jeans standing at opposite ends of a platform outdoors.  In the background is the Herbst Pavilion. They're each standing over white objects sitting on work tables, meticulously chiseling away at them.
 
The last photo is of a woman with short, spikey blonde hair and stage makeup holding a skull, and looking out past it at some unseen horizon.
 
The text reads:
 
New plays by the likes of Pulitzer Prize-winning Sam Shepard, as well as works by emerging writers, premier at the internationally acclaimed Magic Theatre.
 
End text.

 
Kiosk Panel: San Francisco Port of Embarkation
The panel faces north.
 
The text reads:
 
Army's primary depot for Pacific operations
 
First Garrisoned by U.S. Army troops during the Civil War, Fort Mason later played a key role in the emergence of the United States as an international power. Throughout the 1800s, the young country's military resources were focused on subduing Native Americans and supporting the nation's expansion across the continent. Beginning with the Spanish-American War in 1898, the focus shifted overseas. Between 1909 and 1914, the army developed Fort Mason to support U.S. interests in the Pacific.
 
Fully operational by 1915, and known as the San Francisco Port of Embarkation since 1932, the Fort Mason depot operated until 1962. In the 1970s, the long-vacant buildings were rehabilitated and today look much as they did when they were first constructed.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a pier with a long building built on top of it and several ships docked along each side.
The text reads:
 
After the 1906 earthquake and fires destroyed their shipping facilities elsewhere, the army decided to develop Fort Mason's port and consolidate depot activities here.
This panel features a black and white photograph of men in a line on a suspended metal bridge walking through a large, square doorway.
 
The text reads:
 
Pacific locations to which troops and supplies were shipped from the Port of Embarkation:
 
Hawaii
Guam
Philippines
Alaska
Aleutian Islands
Siberia
China
Panama Canal
Guadalcanal
Japan
Korea
 
This panel features a black and white aerial photograph of several buildings on a waterfront. A closely packed network of buildings and a pier with ships docked and black smoke pouring from their stacks.
 
The text reads:
 
During World War II, the San Francisco Port of Embarkation experienced explosive growth. The numbers only begin to tell the story:
 
In 1939
Employed 831 people
Shipped 48,000 tons of cargo
By the end of the war in 1945
Employed more than 30,000 people
Shipped 23.6 million tons of cargo and 1.65 million soldiers
 
Look about today and you'll see remnants of the historic train tracks seen in this photo.
 
Military Architecture
This panel features a black and white photograph of an insignia of an eagle with its wings spread perched on a wheel crossed with a sword and key affixed to the exterior of a building.
 
The text reads:
 
On U.S. Army posts around the world, the Quartermaster Corps once managed living quarters, supplies, and transportation, among other duties. The quartermaster insignia symbolizes these responsibilities:
Eagle represents the nation
 
Sword represents the military forces
Key signifies the Corps' storekeeping function
Wheel (styled after a six-mule-wagon wheel) represents transportation
Wheel's thirteen spokes and stars represent the original colonies and the Corps' origin during the Revolutionary War.
 
Look for the Quartermaster insignia on Fort Mason's historic pier buildings.
 
This panel features a photo in its lower right hand corner of the Landmark Buildings at the Fort Mason Center, with their three-stories and red roofs. In the background is the southern tower of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands.
 
The text reads:
 
As the army's role extended abroad, military planners turned to local influences for the new depot facility. They looked to the southwest's Spanish Colonial missions for inspiration and chose Mission Revival-style architecture for Fort Mason's warehouses. Eventually the Mission Revival style would be so closely associated with West Coast military architecture that red-tiled roofs and unadorned white walls would indicate military presence.
 
End.
 
Facing east at the kiosk, walk left, or north 225 feet and you'll reach a crosswalk. Continue north through the crosswalk another 60 feet and turn right. Walk 170 feet and turn left. Walk 20 feet to arrive at the wayside which is mounted on a metal guardrail in front of the large, orange concrete chair.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 15

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: "The Pacific for its Stage"
The wayside faces north east, northern side of the trail.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
You're standing on the edge of a wide waterfront trail. A small, sandy beach with medium-sized rocks scattered about leads up to the bay. In the distance you can see the L-shaped pier, Torpedo Wharf, the Golden Gate Bridge and Marin Headlands.
 
Behind you are several picnic table and barbecues. Trash cans are 30 feet behind you and to the left, on both sides of a sidewalk that cuts between the picnic tables.
 
The text reads:
 
Landmark Flights Help Shrink the World
 
Crissy Field was the site of several record-breaking flights that helped make the world a smaller place. Given its strategic location on the West Coast and its capacity to accommodate both land and sea planes, Crissy Field influenced the expansion of military air power and the rise of commercial aviation. As the San Francisco Chronicle noted in 1925, “It is here in the Pacific that the future drama of our expanding commerce will be enacted. The play of rival forces now finds the Pacific for its stage…”
 
An Air Corps Aloha
 
In 1929, two PN9 seaplanes made the first attempt to fly from the mainland to Hawaii. Both aircraft were forced down short of their goal. One of the crews was adrift for 12 days before the men were rescued. Two years later an Army modified Fokker C-2 flew from the shoreline here at Crissy Field to the new Oakland Airport, then on to Hawaii. Charles Lindbergh called it “the most perfectly organized and carefully planned flight ever attempted.”
 
This panel features three black and white photographs. The first shows a propeller plane from the front at a three-quarter angle. Its wings are straight and flat across the top of the cockpit, and the wheels below its undercarriage are small, resembling the black and white wagon wheels of a Radio Flyer. The propeller is barely visible because of a dark shadow. In the background is half of a building with an angled roof, and a large bay door left open. The plane is on display on a gravel lot next to a field of grass.
 
The text reads:
 
Specially modified to carry extra fuel and the latest navigational equipment, this Fokker C-2 transport, the Bird of Paradise, completed the first California-to-Hawaii flight in 1927 in less than 26 hours.
 
The next photo shows another plane, this one from a three-quarter rear angle. This plane has two-tiered wings, supported by thin vertical bars. It's resting on a short ramp that leads into the water, and is surrounded by water on all sides. Several individuals are standing on the dock beside it.
 
The text reads:
 
A PN9 amphibious aircraft sits on the seaplane ramp. At low tide you can see the ramp at the water's edge.
 
The last photograph is of two men, one dressed in a bomber jacket with large breast pockets and wings pinned above the pocket on his left. His head is covered in a dark cowl, and goggles rest on his forehead above his eyes. He is smiling, and writing in an open ledger laid out on a wooden table before him. To his left is a man in a dress Army uniform, complete with a flat-topped, brimmed hat. He's also smiling, as he looks over the shoulder of the man writing in the ledger.
 
The text reads:
 
Major Hap Arnold watches Lieutenant Lowell H. Smith sign in upon his return from a transcontinental flight in 1919. Five years later, Army aircraft were the first to circumnavigate the globe.

End.
 
Walk west 340 feet to arrive at the next wayside on the northern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 15

sites.audio_description:
Wayside Panel: San Francisco Port of Embarkation
Soldiers went to war from these piers
 
Millions of tons of cargo and vast numbers of army personnel passed through the Port of Embarkation headed for Pacific destinations. Built between 1909 and 1914, these warehouses and piers played a key part in U.S. Army operations for decades. They were just half-finished when the port was pressed into service for shipment of troops, weapons, and other supplies to Hawaii because of a war scare with Japan in 1913.
 
But it was during World War II that cargo and troop traffic here reached staggering levels—23 million tons of supplies and 1.6 million soldiers were processed through the Port of Embarkation by the war's end. The numbers were dramatic, but the human stories were even more so. Soldiers boarded ships and went to war, families went to live overseas, other families watched loved ones leave—uncertain whether they'd ever see one another again.
 
In the bottom left hand corner is a black and white photograph of two men facing each other. One is dressed in a double-breasted trench coat and brimmed hat, with a paper pad and pen in his hands. The man to his right is dressed in full army uniform, including a round combat helmet and the insignia of a master sergeant, three pointed chevrons up and three rounded bars below, on the arm of his coat. His back is covered in a heavy rucksack and bedding, with more belongings in his arms and at his feet.
 
The text reads:
 
A veteran African-American master sergeant being interviewed by U.S. Army news reporter. Photo taken here at the Port of Embarkation during WWII.
 
In the center of the panel are four black and white photographs. The top two overlap diagonally. The top-most photo is of the piers here, with ships docked on either side of a long building, and men moving about on land. The second photo is a group shot of soldiers in uniform, wearing helmets and with rifles slung over their shoulders. The next photo is of several women wearing long coats. Their backs are to the cameras, but prominently in view are three strollers with babies in them.
 
The text reads:
 
War brides, married to American soldiers overseas, arrived at Fort Mason with new babies to begin their lives in the United States.
 
The final photo is of men in more casual uniform, with jackets and ties walking between two American flags. One man is on crutches and is missing a leg from the knee up.
 
The text reads:

Troops were welcomed home here, too, and received their military discharge at the port.
 
With the closure of the American frontier in the late 1890s, the United States turned its focus outward. Soon, activities and interests overseas required continual movement of troops and supplies. The Spanish-American War in the Philippines in 1898, Philippine-American War from 1899-1902, Boxer Rebellion in China in 1900, and other events prompted the military to consider construction of a shipping center on the West Coast. When the 1906 earthquake and subsequent fires destroyed the army's leased piers, the Army decided to develop a depot at Fort Mason.
In the bottom right hand corner of the panel is a black and white photograph of a massive pile of boxes stretching far into the distance, beneath the cover of a wide roof inside a warehouse looking building.

The text reads:
 
The port processed so much cargo the warehouses were filled to overflowing and shipments piled up on the docks.
End.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 16

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Daring Pilots, Youthful Heroes
The panel faces north, on the northern side of the trail.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
The wayside faces north across the inland side of Crissy Field. You can see the long, manicured expanse of green grass that extends from here all the way to the coast of the San Francisco Bay. You're standing at the edge of Mason Street, between two paths that cut different trajectories across Crissy Field. To your right, a trail cuts north east across the field, and to your left, another trail cuts straight north across the field. To the left of this trail are trash and recycling bins. Off to the left in the distance behind a row of palm trees and white colored buildings with red roofs is the Golden Gate Bridge. An asphalt trail borders the field, you can take it east towards East Beach or west towards Fort Point.
 
The text reads:
 
The 91st Observation Squadron
 
Crissy Field was home to many daring pilots who made their mark on aviation history. Among these famous flyers were Major Dana H. Crissy, who died in a crash attempting to fly to the East Coast from here, and Major Hap Arnold, who later led U.S. Army Air Forces during World War II. In 1924, Lieutenant Russell L. Maughan flew from the East Coast to Crissy Field in one day from “dawn to dusk,” and Lieutenant Lowell H. Smith landed here after flying around the world.

This panel features a black and white photograph of young man with a receding hairline and subdued smile wearing an elaborate uniform with gold, braided epaulets, a stiff, high collar and twin rows of brass buttons running from his chest to his belt. The sleeves of his uniform are decorated with three loops like a clover, and two small lines that cross each other in an “X” with a circular button at their center, just above a broad stripe marking the cuff.
 
The text reads:
 
The airfield's namesake, Major Dana Crissy, commander of Mather Field in Sacramento, crashed while attempting a transcontinental flight that left here in 1919. The airfield was named in his honor in 1921.
 
Next to the photo of Major Crissy is one of two men dressed in heavy coats down to their thighs with thick fur collars, knee high boots and cowls with goggles resting on their foreheads standing at opposite ends, holding a white, tubular sheet in front of the tail end of a biplane. The sheet has several prominent circular tears, as though something has punched through it.
 
The text reads:
 
Air Corps members show off a target sleeve after a practice mission with antiaircraft gunners.
 
End text.

[End tone]
 
To the right of the photo of the Air Corps members, is one of many women dressed in long coats, cowls, goggles and boots. Several of them are holding small children, all of whom are wearing winter hats and coats. Behind the women, clearly visible above their heads, is the propeller of a plane, upon which sit three toddlers in pullovers and shorts.
 
The text reads:
 
Behind the Flight Line
 
Officers and their families were housed on the bluff by the Golden Gate. Enlisted men lived in the three-story barracks behind you. The mothers, wives and children of the aviators were authorized to go aloft on special occasions to “eliminate worry” about the risks their daring men were taking. Their happy expressions suggest the strategy worked.
 
End.
 
Walk east just under one half mile to reach the next wayside located on the northern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 20

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: From These Small Seeds
The wayside is right of the trail.
Panel Description
344 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches. 

The bottom left corner of the panel has a cut out that sometimes contains seed pods for you to hold. Please return the seed pods to the panel when you’re finished handling them.

View from the wayside:
52 words.

To the left of the wayside, is a large, solitary redwood. The ground surrounding it is covered in green sorrel and ferns. Behind the redwood, the ground begins to slope upwards. About 100 feet away up the hill is a circle of young redwoods growing past a row of Bay laurel trees. 

The text reads: In 1976, park researchers determined that this tree was about 200 years old. Since it stands alone, not in a “family circle,” it seems likely that the tree grew from seed. Redwood seeds are small—100,000 to the pound. To germinate and grow into full-fledged trees, they must fall on fresh mineral soil that has somehow been exposed, perhaps by fire, flood, or the downfall of an established tree. The cones of a coast redwood are usually less than an inch long. They mature within a year, turn brown, and gradually shed their seeds—30 to 100 of them per cone. Mature redwoods produce thousands of cones each year, thus creating hundreds of thousands or even millions of seeds during their long lifetimes.

End of text.

This panel features an illustration of three redwood cones hanging from a branch. The cones are small and craggy. They hang from the very tips of the needle-covered branches. At the bottom edge of the illustration is a sequence drawing of the way in which redwood saplings grow from a seed. There are four drawings in the sequence. The first depicts a redwood seed lying on top of exposed soil. The second shows a small seedling growing into the soil with the seed still attached. The third shows the seedling, slightly larger and more vertical, with a deeper root. The fourth shows the seedling with multiple appendages, and the seed, discarded on the ground.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 9

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: A Creek of Life
The wayside is left of the trail.
Panel Description
234 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 28 inches by 18 inches.

View from the wayside: 
35 words.

Beyond it, wispy horsetail plants grow all along the ground, along with thorny blackberry vines and slender bay laurel trees. To the right on the far bank of Redwood Creek is a redwood family circle.

The text reads: In the past, Redwood Creek was manipulated to reduce flooding. Today, the natural channel is being restored along with the vegetation that is critical to the diversity of life in this riparian corridor.

End of text.

This panel features a colorful illustration of animal and plant life on the banks of Redwood Creek. A kingfisher is perched on a branch in the top right corner, a thin-beaked bird with a blue crest atop his head and orange and blue ‘V-shaped’ stripes on his white breast stares into the water below him, perhaps contemplating making a morsel of the coho fingerlings swimming in the water. Perched on another branch above and to the left of the kingfisher is a violet green swallow, with a white breast, violet wings and iridescent-green neck, eyeing a yellow and black butterfly, the tiger swallowtail hovering over a branch below.Just above the water’s surface, a bright yellow banana slug crawls along a rock below the scarlet blooms and tall stalks of a monkey flower plant. Ferns, and white flowers grow all along the bank.

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D  Wayside 20

sites.description: Along the shoreline of Lands End are the ruins of the once mighty Sutro Baths, the public ocean water bathhouse envisioned and financed by Adolph Sutro in the late 1800s. Right on the beach, the ruins are an interesting place to wander about as the tide rolls in and out.

information.description:
Adolph Sutro, self-made millionaire, San Francisco mayor and all around cool cat, developed the lavish Sutro Baths in 1894. With his special interest in natural history and marine studies, he constructed an ocean pool aquarium among the rocks north of the Cliff House. Sutro then expanded his ocean front complex by constructing a massive public bathhouse that covered three acres and boasted impressive engineering and artistic details. Sutro's dream was to provide a healthy, recreational and inexpensive swimming facility for thousands of San Franciscans.
 
The baths weren't just any swimming hole. Inside a massive glass enclosure were seven swimming pools kept at various temperatures. Not to mention slides, trapezes, springboards and a high dive. During high tide, the Pacific Ocean could fill the 1.7 million gallons of water required for all the pools in one hour. The baths were capable of accommodating 10,000 people at once, offered 20,000 bathing suits and 40,000 towels for rent. But no flip flops.

Also included at the baths was a cultural educational component that focused on natural history exhibits, sculptures, paintings, tapestries and artifacts from Mexico, China, Asia, and the Middle East, including Egyptian mummies. Sutro Baths was a venue for concerts, talent shows and restaurants. A railroad provided transportation to Lands End by the late 1890s, so a visit to Sutro Baths became a feasible family day trip.
information.name: History of the baths

information.description:
4th of July, 1897. It's a scorcher in old San Fran. A group of friends decides to cool off by taking a trip out to Sutro Baths, but after paying the entrance fee one of the friends, San Francisco native John Harris, is denied entry to the pools because he's black.
 
Mr. Harris decided to sue Adolph Sutro. Mr. Harris brought his landmark case before the San Francisco Superior Court under California's Dibble Civil Rights Act of 1896, which declared: all citizens "of every color or race whatsoever" shall "be entitled to the full and equal" facilities of "all places of public accommodation or amount."  As usual, California was ahead of its time, seeing as how the Supreme Court made the reprehensible decision to uphold separate but equal segregation policy for public spaces in Plessy vs. Ferguson the year prior.
 
The suit was successful, but personally for Mr. Harris, the victory was bittersweet, as the amount he won in damages was insufficient even to cover his legal expenses. Furthermore, due to his vast wealth and the small amount of the fine, Mr. Sutro was able to continue his exclusionary practices at the baths. The case, however, did have an impact on the state at large, contributing to a wave of suits in the wake of Harris' success.
information.name: John Harris and the Dibble Civil Rights Act

sites.name: Sutro Baths

sites.description: The [Camera Obscura](http://www.giantcamera.com/) behind the Cliff House is a device based on a design by Leonardo da Vinci that produces 360 degrees of spectacular live images of the waters around Seal Rock.
sites.name: Camera Obscura

sites.description:
Mori Point was once considered for a major development deal that included a seven-story conference center, golf course and housing. During this time, Mori was a popular destination for motorcyclists. This well-kept grassland was once severely rutted from unregulated off-road vehicle use, and covered in non-native plant species.The local community's stalwart resistance to the development proposals over two decades led to Mori Point's permanent protection. When the land was transferred to the National Park Service in 2002, major efforts to restore the land to a healthy open space began. In collaboration with the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, hundreds of community volunteers turned the vision into a reality. Mori now has improved trails, interpretive signage, a restored wetland and breeding ponds for the California red-legged frog.       

_Frog ponds: Creating habitat for frogs & snakes_

Mori's freshwater frog ponds are home to our threatened amphibious friends, the California red-legged frog. The ponds are ideal habitat for these cute lil' leapers, and a scenic location for humans to enjoy as well. The ponds are the result of extensive habitat restoration in the 32-acre wetlands. 

The red-legged frog is threatened by habitat loss and predation from invasive species such as bullfrogs. Habitat like these ponds gives their numbers a chance to recover. Funnily enough, the San Francisco garter snake, which is critically endangered, finds red-legged frogs delicious and in fact prefers them over just about everything else. Which means, the colorful snakes hang out near the ponds, too. Keep your eyes peeled!
sites.name: Restoring the wetlands

sites.description: Colorful blossoms probably aren't the first association you make with Alcatraz, but believe it or not, the military and prison personnel transformed portions of the island from barren sandstone to lush gardens. It was after all, their home. Once the prison closed in 1963, the gardens were neglected and overgrown. Today, through the efforts of dedicated volunteers, the Garden Conservancy is partnering with the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy to bring a host of unique plant varieties back to life on the island.
sites.name: Alcatraz Garden

sites.description:
Just east of Fort Point is the Fort Point fishing pier, a.k.a. Torpedo Wharf. This pier sits at the mouth of the Golden Gate. Because of its location, fishermen and fisherladies may encounter any species that enters the bay. It's a great spot for fishing and crabbing. No license required.

The pier is the original site where ships loaded underwater mines, then called 'torpedoes,' before transporting them to plant outside the Golden Gate in the 1890s.
sites.name: Fort Point fishing pier

sites.description:
From the edge of the cliff, look south. You can see blue-green serpentinite rock formations moving into a dark gray rocky m[é]lange, or mixture of rock types that is part of a geologic unit known as the Franciscan Complex. These rock types are telling signs of a tectonic plate boundary, in this case, one that marked the edge of the North American and Farallon plates 100 million years ago. This plate boundary is known as a subduction zone, a place where the Farallon plate sank beneath the North American Plate.

Also, keep your eyes peeled out to sea. These waters are home to many marine mammals. Dolphins are most common in summer and whales migrate through the region from November to February.
sites.name: Godfrey Overlook

sites.description: [The Presidio Nursery](http://www.parksconservancy.org/get-involved/volunteer/drop-in-programs/presidio-nursery.html) is a feel-good kind of place. Not only does it nurture thousands of native plants and trees before they're ready to go in the ground, it also empowers hundreds of volunteers and youth from all over the Bay Area who the nursery relies on to do this important work. All of this is possible thanks to the collaborative effort of the Presidio Trust, Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy and the National Park Service. Together, these agencies support the nursery's goal of restoration within the Presidio.
sites.name: Presidio Nursery

sites.description:
Wayside Panel:  Heart of the Post
The wayside faces west along the sidewalk of Fort Mason Road.
 
View from the wayside:
 
The wayside looks out over Fort Mason Road, which parallels the sidewalk, and Funston Road which cuts west. Lining both roads are similar looking one-story buildings, painted in uniform colors: white walls and green roofs. 275 feet to the west is the entrance to the Hostel, which houses Café Franco. From the wayside, there is a small island with trees in the middle of Fort Mason Road. To the right, the sidewalk continues around a tall chain link fence.
 
Panel Description:
Graphic panel set into metal frame.
 
This panel features an illustration of several soldiers, hats off, as a bugler plays in front of a flagpole flying the American flag. On the right of the panel is a building with a small child and dog staring up at the flag.
 
The text reads:
 
Flagpole, headquarters, and hospital
 
Trees now crowd the spot once occupied by Fort Mason's flagpole—the circle in the center of the street. However, the post's historic headquarters and first hospital still stand on the street's west side. This was the heart of the post. Soldiers and civilians came and went on official business. Wives and children who lived on the post were drawn to the sweeping bay views this high ground afforded, before trees and shrubs grew tall along the edge of the bluff.
 
The daily raising and lowering of the flag has always been a solemn ceremony on army posts. Had you been within sight of Fort Mason's flagpole when the moment came, you would have stopped and turned your attention to the stars and stripes. At the very least, a lone bugle sounded as soldiers sent the flag up each morning and brought it down each evening. On more formal occasions, the entire post band performed.
 
This panel features four black and white photographs along the bottom. Furthest left, is a photo of a long, one-story house.
The text reads:

When the post headquarters was completed in 1864, a continuous porch ran along the east side. At some point after the building was turned into living quarters in 1922, the porch was segmented by two enclosed additions.
Next over to the right is a photo of a tall and narrow house with a pointed roof.
 
The text reads:
 
This Queen-Anne-style cottage was built between the hospital and headquarters buildings in 1831 to replace the original hospital steward's quarters.
 
The next photo is of a building with a wrap-around porch on two sides of its exterior, with a grassy lawn and sidewalk in front.
 
The text reads:
 
Fort Mason's first hospital, pictured here in 1893, was constructed in 1862 as two separate buildings. The half that faces this way was the actual hospital; the half that faces north was the hospital steward's home. The structures were combined in 1884 to create a larger medical facility.
 
The final photo along the bottom of the panel shows a U-shaped line of men and women standing on a roadway between two buildings.
 
The text reads:
 
In 1906, earthquake refugees formed lines around Fort Mason's flagpole as they waited for food rations distributed from the guardhouse that once stood at this end of the street.
 
End.
 
Walk 210 feet north, then turn left and walk 63 feet to the next wayside.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 5

sites.description:
Native plant communities are necessary to maintain a healthy ecosystem. Invasive species, plants that are introduced by humans either intentionally or unintentionally, pose a major threat to native species and the communities of which they are part. Invasives have a tendency to form monocultures, large colonies of a single species, that allow limit resources and space for native species. Unchecked, this means fewer native species, disrupted plant communities and the native animals that depend on them.

Many of the invasive plants along coastal California come from either South Africa or Australia, where there is a similar Mediterranean climate are here. These plants have not co-evolved with local species that might control their abundance and spread and can thus out compete many of the local species.
sites.name: Plants from near and far

sites.description:
Wayside Panel:  “Manifest Destiny”
 
The wayside faces north just north of the sidewalk, immediately to the right as you descend the stairs.
 
Facing north, a trash can is about 17 feet away, to the left of the sidewalk. To the right,  the sidewalk curves around to the east, two metal railways are visible. Each accompany a set of stairs, the first staircase ascends, and is to the right of the sidewalk. The second descends and is to the left.  Just to the left of the wayside a few feet in front of it, is a bench. The wayside looks out over a steep ivy-covered drop-off. Tall cypresses and other trees grow along the slope closest to the water.
 
To the north west, stretching out into the bay is a long, high-ceilinged building with cream colored walls and red doors on a pier.
 
The text reads:
 
Pathfinder's path brought him to this bluff
 
In 1842, U.S. Army captain John Charles Fremont led his first western expedition to explore and map the Oregon Trail. Soon he would be known as “the Pathfinder,” the man who mapped the west. Published accounts of his adventures stirred the nation's fervor about expansion to the Pacific from the United States' western border at Missouri and inspired countless settlers to emigrate. Many Americans came to believe that a coast-to-coast empire was the United States' "Manifest Destiny."
 
Between 1860 and 1861, as the Civil War loomed, John and Jessie Fremont lived in a cottage that stood on this spot. Though John was away much of the time, Jessie enjoyed the company of like-minded neighbors—including some of the West's leading anti-slavery activists. However, the small neighborhood on the bluff had been built on military property by civilians who had no legal claim to the land. The army confiscated the houses during the Civil War, and the Fremonts' cottage was demolished to make way for a gun battery.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a woman in a dark dress and hat standing on a long, wraparound porch looking out over water.
 
The text reads:
 
Jessie Benton Fremont on her porch here at Black Point, looking towards Alcatraz Island.
 
“The waters of the great bay washed the rocks of our headland and we looked down over roses and geraniums to the decks of passing ships…” –Jessie Benton Fremont, Far-West Sketches, 1890.
 
In the lower portion of the panel is an illustrated portrait of a man with long, wavy hair and a full beard dressed in a black suit and bowtie.
 
The text reads:
 
John Charles Fremont (1813-1890)
 
He gave the Golden Gate its name in 1846. That same year, he assisted the American settlers who revolted against Mexican rule and declared California an independent republic after raising their Bear Flag. He was the United States' first Republican candidate for president, in 1856, and served the Union as a general during the Civil War. However, despite these and many more chapters in his colorful career, John Fremont remains most famous for exploring and mapping the west.
 
Alongside the portrait of Fremont is a black and white photo of a woman with dark hair parted in the middle, looking intently at something she's holding in her lap.
 
The text reads:
 
Jessie Benton Fremont (1824-1902)
 
If not for Jessie Fremont, John Fremont's impact on the United States' westward expansion would likely have been less significant. From her husband's journals and stories of his treks to the west, she wrote the chronicle that moved Americans to emigrate. She made her own journey west to join Fremont, traveling with their young daughter across the Isthmus of Panama in 1849. Years later she earned independent acclaim for her writing about a variety of topics.
 
Jessie reading on her front porch, near this location.
 
End.
 
Walk 84 feet east to a staircase with metal guardrails. Walk down the 23 stairs and walk straight another 14 feet to the next wayside.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 6

sites.audio_description:
Madonna AD

The sculpture is made from smooth granite. The figure is tall and straight, with no defined arms or legs. The face is not very detailed, but is characterized by large oval eyes, a thin nose with a sharp bridge and upturned lips forming a subtle smile. Her head is covered by a shape that may represent hair or a hood that comes down from the crown of the head to her shoulders, and melds into her back. At the base of the sculpture is a second figure made of mosaic tiles laid into the base of the Madonna. The mosaic figure is a child, much smaller than the Madonna, and only shown from the chest up. The child has dark brown hair that goes past the shoulders, and four eyes arranged in two vertical rows. The top  half of the figure’s face is divided by color in two quarter sections, colored purple and gold. Two hands, one darker than the other, rest on the child’s shoulders. The child is wearing a white tunic with a blue broach.
End.

Facing south, there’s a fork in the path. Stay to the right and walk 200 feet. Here, the path makes a slight turn, stay left to keep walking south another 220 feet. Turn left again and walk 30 feet to reach the next wayside.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 11

sites.description: In its modern incarnation, Fort Mason is a lovely spot to spend an afternoon walking, cycling or just relaxing, with great views of the San Francisco Bay, Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands. There are plenty of places to explore right here, including food and shops at Fort Mason Center on the waterfront. If you have a whole day, Fort Mason is a great location to start a journey to the marina, East Beach and Crissy Field.

information.description: The Great Meadow features a network of paved paths that lead through the meadow and down to Marina Boulevard. The San Francisco Bay Trail is part of these paths, hugging the coast, beginning at the Municipal Pier near the Maritime Museum and Fisherman's Wharf, and continuing to Crissy Field. The trail is on a gentle slope.
information.name: Trails at Fort Mason

information.description: Geography is the key to understanding Fort Mason. Its elevated position overlooking the bay made it a natural choice for a fortification for 200 years. This site served as a point of defense for the Spanish and Mexican militaries prior to its takeover by US forces in 1846.
information.name: A military history

information.description: In 1797, the Spanish built the first military fortification here, Bateria de San Jose, armed with five eight-pounder cannons. After a successful revolution securing its sovereignty from Spain, Mexico continued to hold influence in the region from 1822 to the 1840s. However, northern California was the wild frontier for the newly formed Mexican government's sphere of influence, and it proved difficult for them to maintain a real presence in the region. This left the area vulnerable to takeover, and gave the US an opening to establish itself where Mexico had abandoned territory.
information.name: Bateria de San Jose

information.description:
After the Bear Flag revolt in 1846, American forces sought to shore up their dominance by leading a series of attacks on Mexican fortifications in the region that would later become San Francisco. They were successful, but their achievement wasn't all that impressive. Back then, San Francisco remained fairly unoccupied, with a population of about 1,000, mostly fur trappers, whalers, fishermen and sailors. It wasn't until gold was discovered in the Sierra Nevadas in 1848 that San Francisco began to boom.
 
During the Gold Rush, San Francisco quickly became a launching pad for opportunists looking to make a buck. The huge influx of settlers prompted a city-wide housing crisis. Developers took advantage of the army's underutilized military land at Fort Mason (then Point San Jose) and constructed private homes overlooking the water at Black Point, unintentionally allowing a vibrant, civic-minded community to develop by the water.
information.name: Boom town beginnings

information.description: Upper Fort Mason offers a unique opportunity to live in historic homes on national park grounds in an urban setting. Rent revenues to the park are used to further rehabilitate historic buildings and fund various improvement projects in the park.
information.name: Looking to move?

sites.name: Fort Mason

sites.description: Imagination is the name of the game at the [Bay Area Discovery Museum](https://www.baykidsmuseum.org/). Come let your children learn, explore, take risks and see the world through new perspectives by engaging in different exhibits, including tide pools and wind tunnels.
sites.name: Bay Area Discovery Museum

sites.description:
Just beyond the northernmost rocky section of Baker Beach is Marshall’s Beach, an isolated shoreline at the base of rising bluffs, that’s great for birdwatching and views of the Golden Gate Bridge. The beach is accessed from the Batteries to Bluffs trail.

Marshall’s is a clothing optional beach, and a great place to expose yourself to serpentinite and a mixture of other metamorphic geologic formations known as a melange.

information.description:
The blue-green serpentinite rock seen here is part of a mélange, a mish-mash of serpentinite, sandstone and soft mudstone deposits. The mélange likely formed when a variety of marine rocks slipped down into a deepsea trench during giant earthquakes many tens of millions of years ago.

Today, large landslides are active all along the bluffs here, easily slipping in the highly fractured mélange. The Batteries to Bluffs Trail crosses the toes of many of these landslide deposits.
information.name: Bluff geology

sites.name: Marshall's Beach

sites.description: The elegant Fort Scott Commanding Officer's Quarter, built in 1915, has been converted to a private residence available to rent at a tidy five figures per month. The sidewalk from the house crosses the street and leads directly to the Officer's Club. Back in the day, the Commandant appreciated the convenient jaunt from home to club for his after hours drink.
sites.name: Fort Scott Commandant's House

sites.description:
Break out the clubs and your best shoulder-draping cardigan and head down to the [Presidio Golf Course](http://www.presidiogolf.com/) for challenging play on a beautiful course. Opened in 1895, the golf course on the Presidio is the oldest west of the Mississippi. There was a long standing agreement that Presidio army officers could knock a few balls around whenever they wanted, and in war time, the grounds were available for military trainings. 

You can also enjoy a relaxing meal at the Presidio Café after a day on the links.
sites.name: Presidio Golf Course

sites.description:
On November 4th, 1769, a group of weary, dehydrated, half-starved hikers came upon what's now known as Sweeney Ridge. They were Spanish explorer Captain Juan Portolá and his intrepid expedition, sent from New Spain to settle Monterey Bay and build a mission.
 
It seems the captain's navigation skills were better at sea than they were overland, as he'd managed to pass through but failed to recognize Monterey Bay, then kept going north.
 
Lost and suffering, Portolá's expedition scaled this ridge and saw "...a large arm of the sea…some sort of harbor there within the mountains." The site was later confirmed to be the San Francisco Bay, which is quite a remarkable view from Sweeney Ridge.
sites.name: Portolá Discovery Site

sites.audio_description:
Wayside Panel: Fort Mason Historic District
The wayside faces north east.

View from the wayside:
 
The wayside looks out over the five buildings that comprise the Fort Mason Center. The buildings are painted in uniform colors, cream-colored walls with red tile roofs, fire escapes and window trim. The buildings are several hundred feet away, with a large public parking lot between you and them.
 
The text reads:
 
Critical army port (1909-1962)
Model cultural center (1977-present)
 
Between 1909 and 1962, vast numbers of soldiers were sent to war from the piers at lower Fort Mason. After army operations ceased at the San Francisco Port of Embarkation in 1962, the facility sat idle until it was given new life as a cultural center. Since 1977, Fort Mason Center has been home to arts, educational, recreational, environmental, and charitable organizations and events.
 
Designated as a National Historic Landmark: February 4, 1985.
 
This panel features a detailed map of Fort Mason, Fort Mason Center and the Great Meadow. Fort Mason Center is the furthest northern area, and a “You Are Here” label to the north western edge, right on the line with the entrance to Fort Mason Center.
 
To the right of the map are three black and white photographs, two arranged vertically and one to the right. The photo in the top left of the set shows several men in army uniform with large backpacks walking up a metal ramp and into a large, square door into a large ship.
 
Below, is an aerial photograph of Fort Mason Center, though at the time, it was the Port of Embarkation. Large ships are docked at each of the five piers.
 
The text reads:
 
United States Army, San Francisco Port of Embarkation, prior to World War II.
 
The photo in the top right corner a row of signs suspended above different doorways along one of the buildings at Fort Mason Center.

The text reads:
 
Fort Mason Center is home to many nonprofit organizations, performing arts spaces, galleries, shops and restaurants.
 
End.
 
To reach the next kiosk, walk north through the crosswalk about 50 feet, then continue north. In 70 feet there will be a trash can to your immediate left. Further left, beyond the trashcan, are several picnic tables. Stay slightly right to continue north along the sidewalk another 230 feet. You'll arrive at the entrance to the Fort Mason Center Main Office to your left. To your right is a crosswalk, walk through it and you'll arrive at a kiosk in 40 feet. Six feet east of the kiosk is a trashcan, and 60 feet east of the kiosk, there's a picnic table.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 14

sites.description: Building 64 is located above the dock as soon as you arrive off the ferry. Originally, it was part of the fortress protecting the bay.  Later it served as housing for the military officers and their families living on the island. Over the years it was expanded, and by the early 1900s it was converted into the Military Guard Barracks. Perhaps out of boredom or an early example of frat culture, the men endeared themselves to their austere surroundings by nicknaming certain areas of the island around their barracks. A large corner apartment became the “Cow Palace” and a nearby alley was known as “China Alley.”

information.description: For nearly 80 years, Alcatraz island was the site of the first US fortress and military prison on the West Coast. Most prisoners were US military personnel, but some notable exceptions included southern sympathizers during the Civil War, WWI conscientious objectors and Native Americans, beginning in 1873.
information.name: Fortress Alcatraz

information.description: "Bachelor Quarters" is a funny name for a place that was originally a military chapel, and subsequently used to house officers and their families when Alcatraz was a military prison. The first floor was the living quarters, the second floor housed the school and chapel. But when Alcatraz became a penitentiary in 1934, the building became a full-on bachelor pad, used exclusively to house unmarried guards.
information.name: Bachelor Quarters

sites.name: Alcatraz Building 64

sites.audio_description:
The entrance to Fort Point is along the fort's south wall. As you approach the cement ramp that leads to the entryway, the size of the fort's brick wall becomes formidable, the closer you get the more it blocks out the sky. The entryway is denoted by a squared off pair of columns and an overhang set into the fort's facade. A cement keystone sits above the entrance, with an arc of bricks along both sides. Two large, studded wooden black doors open inwards into the sally port, a brief but wide hallway that leads into the central parade ground. The sally port is flanked by brick walls with small thin windows that acted as gun slits on either side. A second set of studded wooden doors with small openings for guns separates the sally port from the parade ground. 

The parade ground is a large open space at the center of the fort. It is surrounded on all sides by the three-levels of the wall, each with identical sets of domed arch ways, giving the place something of a beehive or honeycomb look. There is no roof on the fort, it's entirely exposed at the top. The lighthouse tower can be seen rising up from its perch on the barbette tier--the "roof" level of the fort. Above the lighthouse is the skeletal orange arch of the Golden Gate Bridge, which passes over the fort. 

A metal staircase is located at the corner to the right of the fort's entrance. A spiral granite staircase is in the corner of the fort to the left of the entrance. Each stairway has a map of things to see in the fort that are also in Braille. Stairs take you to each level of the fort, including the barbette tier, from where you have a unique view from beneath the Golden Gate Bridge and of the San Francisco Bay.
sites.description:
Nestled below the arch of the Golden Gate Bridge is Fort Point. Built in a style similar to Fort Sumter, this is the only brick fort of its type in the western US The fort is an iconic symbol of San Francisco's early history. Long neglected by the military after it became obsolescent during the US Civil War, Fort Point was slated for destruction to make way for the Golden Gate Bridge in 1933, but was spared thanks to the efforts of the bridge's Chief Engineer, Joseph Strauss, who championed the fort's preservation because of its fine masonry and historical significance. 

If you come for a visit, bring a jacket and something to keep your ears toasty, it gets mighty cold and windy this close to the water! If you get too cold (or even if you don't), you can always check out the 20 minute videos that run continuously in the theater to the right as you enter from the Sally Port, or the many shorter videos in the powder magazine you can choose for yourself.

information.description: Having fun at Fort Point isn't hard to do. First of all, it's beautiful. Second of all, you can hop a bike or hoof it along the San Francisco Bay Trail or venture to parts of the Presidio further inland. A network of trails come together down by the fort. The fort itself is an incredible space for all sorts of unusual photographic angles, as well as a stage for stepping back in time. Walking through the windy corridors or looking out over the edge of the barbette tier at the wilds of Marin, one can't help but imagine the men who once lived here, and wonder what their lives were like.
information.name: Having fun at the fort

information.description:
Prior to Fort Point, the Spanish built a fort of their own, el Castillo de San Joaquin, which sat on a cliff top very nearly on this spot. The US Army blew up the bluff edge and that fort so that the new fort's guns could fire at ships from water level. 

Built by the US Army Engineers between 1853-1861, Fort Point was originally armed with cannons designed to repel naval attacks from foreign powers. The fort was rushed to completion with the onset of the Civil War, when it was fully manned and armed with over 100 cannons to counter any Confederate threat to San Francisco. After the cannons were removed, the fort was used as a barracks in the early 20th century and recommissioned briefly during WWII. In 1970, it was declared a national historical site.

In 1861, Albert Sidney Johnston commanded the Department of California for the Union Army. The Confederates hoped they might be able to take hold of the region, and a secret plan was hatched to commandeer Fort Point for the Confederacy with the hopes that Johnston, a southerner by birth, would sympathize with the plot. The plan never came to fruition, though, and California remained a Union-controlled territory. Johnston, however, did in fact align with the Confederacy, but not until Fort Point was completed and the Union arsenal was relocated from Benicia, California to Alcatraz. After fulfilling his duties for the Union, Johnston gave up his post and became a Confederate General. In this capacity, he died at the battle of Shiloh in 1862.
information.name: Fort history

information.description: If you're walking around inside Fort Point, don’t be surprised if you see a Union soldier walking around, too, rifle slung over their shoulder. These soldiers are usually in good spirits, probably because they don’t have to sleep in shifts in the same bed as several other recruits or endure the bitter winds of the fort every day without a break like in the olden days.
information.name: Historical reenactors

information.description: This Civil War-era fort never faced enemy fire but is now under attack by the rising seas and bigger storm waves. When we burn fossil fuels like coal and gas for energy, we add more and more carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. This buildup acts like a blanket that traps heat around the world. Warmer temperatures expand ocean water and melt glaciers, causing sea level rise, coastal flooding and erosion. The National Park Service takes seriously its responsibility to address problems facing our coastal parks, and is taking practical steps to make progress before environmental problems get worse. How can we continue the army’s legacy of defending our coasts in the face of sea level rise?
information.name: Climate change at Fort Point

sites.name: Fort Point National Historic Site

sites.description: The Guard Tower was the last line for guards to secure the island. If the men on duty saw or heard anything unusual, they would sound the alarm that went out over the whole island. Long hours in the tower, meant that it had to be equipped with all the facilities.
sites.name: Alcatraz Guard Tower

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Muir Woods National Monument [Main Entrance]-
The wayside stands just south of the Visitor Center.

Panel Description
358 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 25 inches by 19 inches. 

View from the wayside:
102 words.

Behind it is a split-rail fence that borders a small section of grass and scrub plants. Following the fence line to the left leads you to a metal trash can along the fence’s path. From the trash can, the fence curves left in a wide arc, creating a circular space to the right of the trash can, where visitors can rest on wooden benches located along the fence’s perimeter.A drinking fountain is located between the second and third benches. Directly across from the bench area is the Visitor Center and ticket office.  

The text reads:

Hillside to Visitor Center Distance: 1.1 mile/ 1.8 km one way.  Allow 45 minutes. Mostly flat, uneven surfaces.

This alternative to the Redwood Creek Trail gets you up above
the canyon floor and parallels the creek between Bridge 4 and
Bridge 2. Well worth a little extra effort for a view of the forest
