The final illustration is of a crab with a dark gray shell and pincers, and light purple legs. A brown rock crab, Cancer antennarius.
 
The text reads:
 
Please observe these crabbing rules:
 
Crabs must be at least 4 inches across the widest part of the shell.
 
The limit on crabs is 35 crabs per person per day.
 
No Dungeness crabs may be taken. Born in the ocean, Dungeness crab larvae drift into the bay. The larvae transform into young crabs in food-rich shoreline areas. Since these crabs don't reach maturity until long after they return to the ocean, it is illegal to trap them in the bay.
 
End.
 
The next wayside is directly to the left of the kiosk if you're facing west, about 8 feet.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 17

sites.description:
Kiosk Description
Situated at the western edge of Crissy Field is a four-sided metal kiosk with three wayside panels.

View from the kiosk
To the east of the kiosk, is a two lane road and north of the road, Crissy Field. Along the southern edge of the road are several long, two-story buildings with matching red roofs and cream-colored exteriors. There is a crosswalk to reach the southern side of the street 40 feet to the east, anticipated by a textured surface. On the northern side of the road is a paved path for cyclists and pedestrians that runs the length of Crissy Field. North of the kiosk, is a small, grassy field separating the sidewalk from the San Francisco Bay Trail further north. The trail has a bench about 60 feet due north of the kiosk. The bench overlooks a sandy beach and the San Francisco bay, with a view of Alcatraz Island and the Marin Headlands.

To the west is a row of picnic tables and barbecues set along a grassy field. The first table is 50 feet from the kiosk, and the barbecue is right of the table.  

Kiosk Panel-Protecting Wildlife

Panel Description:
The panel faces east.

The text reads:

The western end of Crissy Field embraces rich and varied wildlife habitats—rocky shoreline, sandy beach, open water and piers. Designated a wildlife protection area, this site hosts many resident and migratory birds, which rest and feed here. Offshore, pelicans and terns plunge headlong into the water for fish. Grebes and cormorants gracefully dive for small fish and invertebrates. In the tidal zone, willets, plovers and sandpipers glean and prove the sand for worms, insects, mollusks and crustaceans.

Watercraft and pets are not permitted in the wildlife protection area, but you may enjoy jogging, fishing, picknicking—and watching birds without disturbing them. Protecting wildlife, and providing you the experience of seeing them wild, is part of the mission of the National Park Service.

To the right of the text is an illustration of three birds in flight. They have light gray feathers with a bluish hue along their backs, with black-tipped wings and heads. Their beaks are thin and pointed.
The text reads: Least terns, Sterna antillarum

This panel features a map of Crissy Field and marsh. On the western portion of the map is a line indicating your position on the map, just south of the waterfront. Along the sandy shore just to the east of where the “You Are Here” marker is on the map, and for a small distance further east past where the beach ends, is an area colored in with tan lines that stretch past the shore line into the shallow waters of the bay. This area is labeled “Wildlife Protection Area.”

The text reads:

The National Park Service has designated the shoreline and coastal waters indicated above as a wildlife protection area. This part of Crissy Field offers a safe haven for birds and other wildlife.

How Crissy Field Got Its Name
In 1919, the U.S. Army sent 61 airplanes racing in short hops across the continental United States to test aircraft reliability and endurance. Major Dana H. Crissy led the west-to-east contingent which left from the still-unnamed airfield at the Presidio. He died in a crash on the first day out. In 1921, Major Hap Arnold, pioneer military aviator and later a five-star general, saw to it that the air base was named in Crissy's honor.
End text.
[End tone]

Kiosk Panel-A Place of Renewal
The panel faces south.

Panel Description:
Graphic panel set in metal frame.

The text reads:
 
The land known today as Crissy Field has undergone many changes. once a rich salt marsh and homeland of Ohlone people, it was later a landing site for Spanish and Russian explorers, a venue for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition and a pioneering United States military airfield.
 
Along with the entire Presidio, Crissy Field was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1962. With generous community support, Crissy Field has been transformed into a spectacular 100-acre shoreline park at the center of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area.
 
Revitalizing Crissy Field
 
Sponsored by the National Park Service and its nonprofit support partner, the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, the revitalization of Crissy Field owes its success to community support and stewardship. The Evelyn and Walter Haas, Jr. Fund provided the lead gift for site restoration, and many other individuals and organizations from throughout the Bay Area generously contributed time and funding.
 
As part of the site restoration effort in 1998-2000, individuals and groups from schools, corporations and civic organizations planted more than 100,000 native plants to help restore natural habitat at Crissy Field. Community volunteers continue to play an important role in sustaining long-term stewardship of this national parkland.

In the lower portion of this panel are three illustrations of plants. The first illustration is of pink sand verbena, a plant that also grows on a vine, with a vertical structure to its blossom. The blossom is pink and round like a sphere, the petals growing in more of a three dimensional pattern. The green triangle-shaped leaves with rounded edges grow above and below the flower.
 
The second illustration is of Indian paintbrush, a plant with hairy, teardrop-shaped leaves alternating their way up its stalk to a red blossom.
 
The third illustration shows a vertical plant with five small, round blue blossoms at the top of its stalk: silver bush lupine. Lower down on the stalk are five crinkly looking leaves, and at the very bottom, a dense section of smaller leaves growing close together.
 
The text reads:
 
Silky hairs on the silver bush lupine's leaves reflect heat and protect them from drying out. Capable of fixing nitrogen from the air, an advantage in nutrient-poor sand, these plants can live many decades.
 
End text.
 
[End tone]
 
Kiosk Panel-Enjoying Crissy Field
The panel faces north.

Panel Description:
Graphic panel set in metal frame.

The text reads:
 
The National Park Service invites you to enjoy all that Crissy Field, the Presidio and the Golden Gate National Recreation Area have to offer. Crissy Field has been designed to accommodate a variety of uses. For the safety and enjoyment of all visitors and the protection of national park resources, please obey park rules.
 
This panel features a map of the San Francisco Bay coastline, from the San Francisco side, that includes Marina Gate and Entry Grove to the east, and stretches all the way to the Golden Gate Bridge to the west. Several areas within the parkland are labeled, including the Warming Hut to the west near Fort Point, then moving east: Golden Gate Promenade, the Tidal Marsh and East Beach.
 
The text reads:
 
Please:
 
Obey all posted regulations.
 
Adhere to special regulations for the wildlife protection area.
 
Note that bicycles are subject to all motor vehicle laws.
 
The following are prohibited:
 
Glass bottles and containers.
 
Fires on beach.
 
Organized sports
 
Camping
 
Collecting plants and other natural objects
 
Removing historic artifacts
 
Feeding or disturbing wildlife
 
Parking in unpaved areas except as designated
 
End.
 
The next wayside is just over a quarter mile to the east. To reach it, take the sidewalk next to the road all the way. The road will be on your right and Crissy Field to your left. The wayside will be on the left, or, northern side of the path.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 19

sites.audio_description:
Kiosk Panel: Fort Mason Historic District
The panel faces west on the sidewalk facing Laguna Street.
 
View from the wayside:
 
The kiosk looks out over Laguna Street as it intersects Marina Boulevard. 12 feet to the right, or, north of the kiosk is the crosswalk to cross Laguna Street. The sidewalk to the north curves west and parallel Marina Boulevard. About 100 feet to the north is the entrance to Lower Fort Mason on the right.
 
The text reads:
 
U.S. Army post (1864-1966)
 
First fortified by the Spanish in 1797, this bluff above the bay was re-armed by the U.S. Army in 1864. The post remained active through the Civil War, western Indian Wars, and conflicts abroad, beginning with the Spanish-American War in 1898. During World War II, Fort Mason was the Army's logistics center for sending troops and supplies to the Pacific.
 
Fort Mason was designated a National Historic Landmark on February 4, 1985.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a coastal bluff with a series of buildings comprising a compound. The bluff is undeveloped except for the buildings, so that there is a lot of flat open space leading up to the buildings. A single roadway leads to the buildings. In the distance, across a body of water, mountainous terrain.
 
The text reads:
 
Though San Francisco had grown enormously by 1900, Fort Mason was isolated from the city's bustle by undeveloped open space.
 
In the right corner of this panel is a black and white photo of two men in army uniform and brimmed hats talking to one another as they walk down the steps away from a building's entrance.
 
The text reads:
 
General Dwight D. Eisenhower inspected Fort Mason in 1946.
 
This panel features a detailed map of Fort Mason. On the western edge of the area labeled “Upper Fort Mason” are the words “You Are Here.” Just to the north, is an area labeled “Lower Fort Mason” to the north.
 
The text reads:
 
Dog Regulations
 
Federal Law requires dogs to be on leash at all times in all national parks. (36 CFR Part 2) Dog walkers must obey regulations and pick up after their pets.
 
Bicycling
 
Fort Mason is the doorway to San Francisco. Ride from here across the Great Meadow to the Marina Green and on to Crissy Field promenade, Fort Point and the Golden Gate Bridge.
 
Bicycle etiquette
 
Share paths safely. Bicycles may not exceed 15 m.p.h. and must slow to 5 m.p.h. around corners and when passing other path users. Yield right of way to pedestrians, strollers and wheelchairs.
 
Accessibility
 
Nearly all of the paths at Fort Mason are wheelchair accessible. Enjoy the Great Meadow or visit the Black Point Batter picnic area and historic site by following a route behind the hostel.
 
History walk
 
A free self-guiding history booklet may be obtained at building 201 (park headquarters), inside the front entrance, during business hours; open Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. (except holidays).
 
Emergency Information
 
In an emergency call the Park Communications Center at (415) 561-5510, or dial 911. Cell phone users call (415) 472-0911.
 
End.
 
To reach the next wayside in Fort Mason Center, walk right, or north, 100 feet, then turn right and walk another 30 feet. A crosswalk is to your left, walk through it, about 45 feet and you'll arrive at the wayside on your right.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 13

sites.audio_description:
Phillip Burton Statue 
 
The bronze statue of Burton is larger than life, suggesting something of his famous will and persona. Viewed from the side, Burton stands tall, with one leg slightly bent. His left arm is bent at the elbow, the fingers on his hand spread wide, his open palm facing towards him. His right arm is fully extended to his side, with his hand gesturing as if allowing someone to enter a room or pass by him. His hair is wavy and parted to the side. His mouth is open and his brow furrowed, lending the impression that he is mid-speech.
 
To continue to the next kiosk from the wayside, head west along the path 900 feet, almost one fifth of a mile. The path curves in a wide arc towards the south before coming back around towards the north. From the Burton statue, walk back the way you came. At 120 feet, turn right and stay west.

At 900 feet, turn left to stay west, and walk down the hill 275 feet until the hill evens out and you arrive at the sidewalk. The kiosk is at the bottom of the hill and slightly left, on the sidewalk.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D Burton Statue

sites.description: Ocean Beach is a great hang. The sunniest months are September and October, but O.B. always draws a crowd. San Francisco tends to be cool and gray, even at the beach. During the late spring and summer months, the coast can get pretty fogged in, but it's still beautiful. Just remember to bring a hoodie and you'll be a lot happier under the fog dome. Running the length of the Sunset and Richmond neighborhoods, there's plenty of space at Ocean Beach for the whole family.

information.description: Keep a watchful eye out for a tiny animal friend, the western snowy plover, a threatened species that rests here in the winter. In California, there's been a significant decline in plover breeding locations due to human disturbance. In an attempt to protect the plovers, the National Park Service is carefully monitoring the species, and creating buffers between them and humans so they have a chance to bounce back.
information.name: Protected Plover nesting area

information.description: It's never safe to swim at Ocean Beach and even wading is dangerous. Unpredictable tides and rip currents (strong, swift-moving channels of water) can pull swimmers offshore. If you're caught in a rip current, swim parallel to the beach until you're free of it, then swim toward shore with incoming waves. If you need assistance, wave your arms and yell for help.
information.name: Ocean safety

information.description:
The low relief coastline at Ocean Beach is susceptible to sea level rise. Burning fossil fuels like coal and gas, releases carbon dioxide, which acts like a blanket around the planet, disrupting the climate. As global temperatures rise, so will ocean tides, encroaching on shorelines like this one. 

The National Park Service is taking steps to curb the effects of climate change so that places like Lands End don't disappear as a result of severe erosion. One action we are taking is to demonstrate sustainable practices like the wind turbine that produces power for the Cliff House, and the environmentally friendly Lands End Lookout.
information.name: A greener beach

information.description:
You can have a fire on Ocean Beach if you follow these simple rules:

-Build a fire in 1 of the 16 provided fire rings. Fires are only permitted in the provided fire rings which are first come, first serve

-Extinguish fires by 9:30pm

-One adult (18+) must accompany every 10 minors

-No permit required except for groups larger than 25 people. Groups larger than 25 must obtain a [Special Use Permit](http://go.nps.gov/gogaspug) 

-To see all the regulations regarding beach fires at Ocean Beach, visit [http://go.nps.gov/beachfires](http://go.nps.gov/beachfires).
information.name: Fires on Ocean Beach

sites.name: Ocean Beach

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: A Tidal-Marsh Extravaganza
The wayside faces north on the northern side of the trail.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set into metal frame.
 
View from the wayside:
 
The wayside is on the inland side of the San Francisco Bay Trail, on the south west corner of the tidal-marsh. A rope fence runs through wooden posts along the edge of the trail, separating it from thick coastal scrub growing long along the ground. Further back, you can see the a row of willows with slender oval leaves, a light shade of green, all of which surround the bright blue waters of the Crissy Field marsh.
 
The text reads:
 
A Model of Diversity and Richness.
Wetlands swarm with life and produce more food per square inch than the richest California farmland. Their complex food webs are based on detritus, the decaying remains of dead plants, rather than on living green plants as in terrestrial ecosystems. Flooded by bay tides twice daily, salt marshes serve as nurseries for countless marine fish and invertebrates, many of them food sources for people. Wetlands offer shelter, breeding habitat and abundant food for an array of animals, from microscopic plankton to large animals. Tidal estuaries also filter out pollutants and prevent flooding by capturing storm runoff.
 
This panel features an illustration of different marsh plants growing in a sand dune near water. The first plant is the tallest, with long, thin green leaves and wispy, wheat-like tops. It's labeled "cordgrass."
 
Next on the dune are three green stalks growing vertically, with smaller stalks stemming from the main one. The tops droop slightly. The plant is labeled, "pickleweed."
 
Following the pickleweed is a rendering of arrow grass, which has several green, vertical tendrils that grow halfway up the plant, around a taller center stalk.
 
To the right of the arrow grass is a plant that creeps along the surface of the dune, Jaumea. With little yellow flowers and alternating little leaves, Jaumea grows more horizontally than the other examples of dune plants.
 
To the right of the Jaumea is a rendering of salt grass. These two plants share a certain resemblance. Both have yellow flowers and thin leaves that alternate up the stalk. Salt grass, however, has more of a vertical structure.
 
The last image is of a plant with many oval-shaped green leaves at its base, and and many forking stalks with blue blossoms at their tips. It resembles a miniature tree, with many branches. It's labeled "sea lavender."
 
The text reads:
 
Salt-marsh plants tend to grow in distinct bands parallel to the shoreline. Tide levels determine soil salinity and how long plants are submerged, thus defining where each species can grow. A mere inch or two of elevation can make a significant difference in the vegetation mosaic. Marsh plants grown in park nurseries from seeds collected in six neighboring wetlands were planted in and around the Crissy Field marsh.
 
This panel features a photograph of tall, thin stalks growing thickly in a marsh. The stalks are a healthy, dark green.
 
The text reads:
 
California cordgrass, common in salt marshes, excretes excess salt that crystallizes on its leaves. Because cordgrass grows in waterlogged, oxygen-deprived mud, its stems, containing specialized tissue, transport oxygen to the roots.
 
A second photo appears to the right of the picture of cordgrass. Another close up of a marsh plant, only this one has a brown and white patch of dead and dying stalks, which are shorter and resemble elk antlers, with small, branching sections coming off a main stem.

The text reads:
 
The succulent tissues of pickleweed maintain an internal salt level equal to that of the surrounding soil or water. The plant absorbs freshwater and concentrates excess salt in the tips of its fleshy leaves.
 
The text reads:
 
Build it and They Will Come
 
The Crissy Field tidal marsh and lagoon restore vital natural habitat and ecological diversity within an urban setting. Birds began frequenting the site even before the marsh was fully excavated. Opening the marsh channel in 1999 brought together bay saltwater with freshwater runoff, attracting yet more birds in dramatic numbers and variety, some for the first time in almost a century. The calm waters and dense foliage of the fully evolved wetland will offer a feeding and roosting refuge for both resident bird species and migrants on the Pacific flyway.
 
On the far right of the panel is an illustration of the American continents, with an icon of a flying bird running the length of the West Coast, the southern tip of Argentina up to Alaska.
 
The text reads:
 
Every spring and fall about 11 million birds of more than 100 species migrate along the Pacific coast to or through the Bay Area. Nearly three-fourths of them rest and feed in the region's tidal marshes, many for the entire winter. Sanderlings, for example, nest on the Arctic tundra and winter as far south as Tierra del Fuego. They linger at Crissy Field to feed and rest during their migratory flights of up to 15,000 miles.
 
End.
Walk east just over one tenth of a mile to reach the next wayside, located on the northern side of the trail.
sites.name: Crissy Field A D 21

sites.description:
The serpentinite here is part of a mélange, a mish-mash of serpentinite, hard ancient sea floor lava and sedimentary rocks and soft mud deposits. The mélange likely formed when a variety of marine rocks slipped down into a deepsea trench during giant earthquakes many tens of millions of years ago.

At this location, the mélange includes gray shale and sandstone, blue-green serpentinite, and the hard dark metamorphic blocks that form the sea stacks just offshore at the point to the north. At the point to your south the mélange includes bedded red chert (a silica-rich sea floor sedimentary rock) and sandstone blocks. 

Large landslides form all along the bluff here in the highly fractured mélange. The Batteries to Bluffs Trail crosses the toes of many of these old landslide deposits.
sites.name: Marshall’s Beach: Slip n' slide

sites.description: Coming in December 2016 to the old Presidio Guardhouse and Stockade, the future permanent Presidio Visitor Center will offer interactive exhibits and information to get you out to the parts of the park that are of most interest to you. Check back late this year.
sites.name: Future Presidio Visitor Center

sites.description: Cool down with a smoothie, or warm up with some tea. Light snacks and treats available.
sites.name: Beach Hut Café

sites.description: Check out the Agave Trail on the island's southern side, and get a sense of Alcatraz's lesser known natural beauty by experiencing the flora and fauna of the Rock, home to many a feathered friend.  Bird life and enviable views of the city make the Agave Trail a great alternative or addition to the main tour. The trail is open when the birds are not nesting: from about mid October to mid January.

information.description: The origin of the name "Alcatraz" is debated, but is often attributed as a derivative of a name given by 18th century explorer Juan Manuel de Ayala, "Alcatraces," meaning 'pelicans' or 'seabird'. The name is fitting, given the number of birds that call the island home.
information.name: Naming Alcatraz

information.description:
Alcatraz Island is a primo destination for seabirds including Brandt's cormorants and pigeon guillemots. 

The bluffs on the island provide habitat where these species can safely nest. These bird friends mostly feed in the open ocean and San Francisco Bay, and have a taste for small fish. 

But the good life these birds enjoy could be in danger. Changes in ocean temperatures, and wind and upwelling patterns are affecting productivity and the distribution of the fish these birds eat. In some recent years, the distribution of anchovies, a favorite snack of cormorants, shifted south, leading to a near complete failure of cormorant nesting at Alcatraz and other nearby nesting areas. 

Continued climate change is likely to lead to further productivity and food chain disturbances for seabirds.
information.name: Bird friends

sites.name: Alcatraz Agave Trail

sites.description: Rodeo Beach formed about 5,000 years ago when sea level rise slowed after melting at the end of the last glacial period.  At that time, this sandy barrier beach dammed an ancient stream valley to form Rodeo Lagoon. Strong waves and currents produce the unusually coarse pebbly beach sand here today. Watchful beachcombers can find a rainbow of pebbles dotting the shore. The vibrant colors are the result of the most common rock found in the Marin Headlands: bedded ribbon chert, which you can see exposed nearby at the south end of the beach. Traces of iron in the chert are oxidized in different amounts to produce a wide spectrum of colors, including red, green, yellow and black pebbles. Admire these natural beauties all you like, but please don't take them from the beach.
sites.name: Rodeo Beach Geology

sites.description: Today, the Presidio Landmark is a swank apartment at the edge of a national park, but this is just the latest in a series of incarnations through the years. The Public Health Service District is also an increasingly popular entry point to trails in the Presidio's Southern Wilds. Parking is limited, so arrive early.

information.description:
You can access four in and out trails from here into the Southern Wilds area. 

Juan Bautista Trail 2.7 miles 

Mountain Lake Trail 2.6 miles

Park Trail 1.7 miles 

Lobos Creek Valley Trail 0.8 miles. No dog friends allowed. 

Each trail is moderate to easy in its terrain, and  offers incredible opportunities to explore the wild Presidio. Be warned! Parking at the trailheads is limited and tricky.
information.name: Southern Wilds trails

information.description:
Back in the 1800s, San Francisco was still a wild-eyed beast of a port town full of ship-bound fortune hunters. There wasn't a lot in the way of social services then, but one place you could go if you were a merchant seaman in need of aid was the US Marine Hospital, which provided free treatment to sailors of all nations. 

Built in 1875, the Marine Hospital operated until 1932, when it was replaced by the building that stands here now, the Public Health Service Hospital. Two wings were added to the front of the building in the 1950s. The work of caring for ailing sailors continued when the Public Health Service took over. Eventually, the hospital extended its programs to caring for members of the US Coast Guard and other governmental agencies, as well as Native Americans and Vietnamese refugees. The Public Health Service also conducted important research on plague and other communicable diseases. 

After the hospital's closure in 1981, the Military Language Institute used part of the facility from 1982 to 1988. In the early 2000s, the building became a major destination for graffiti artists. In 2009, the Presidio Trust demolished the wings that were added in the 1950s, and the following year the main building reopened as the Presidio Landmark apartments.
information.name: Changing facades: Public Health Service Hospital

sites.name: Public Health Service Hospital District

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: Black Point Fortifications
The panel faces north east from the northern edge of the roadway.
 
View from wayside:
 
The wayside is located at the edge of a green grass section of ground bordered by a low parapet. The wall, which is made of brick further to the north west, where a cannon sits pointing out over the wall, its barrel aimed to the north west. Closer in, to the left of the wayside, the wall is concrete. Two round conical domes can be seen below parts of the wall that have thin indentations in the concrete, resembling half-steps. The view of the bay is somewhat obscured by many tall cypress trees.
 
Panel Description
Graphic panel set in metal frame.
 
The panel features a black and white photograph in its top right corner of a row of cannon mounted and pointed over a low parapet framed on either side by low hills. A path leads up to them from behind.
The text reads:
Guarding the Golden Gate (1797-1909)
The well-to-do squatters who once occupied an elegant neighborhood on this bluff came for the beautiful bay view. The Spanish and American militaries came for the view, too—for the defensive advantage it offered. As early as 1797, a Spanish gun battery occupied a rise near here, positioned to intercept ships entering the bay. Though American troops didn't re-arm the site until 1864, it had been reserved for the U.S. military use since 1850, soon after the United States gained control of California.
Fortifications built here during the Civil War were part of a system of gun emplacements that ringed the Golden Gate. A dozen guns in Black Point's 1864 battery supported artillery at Fort Point, Angel Island and Alcatraz Island.
The panel features a map of the San Francisco Bay in its bottom left hand corner. Labeled are Fort Point to the west, Angel Island to the north, Alcatraz Island to the east and Fort Mason to the south with arrows from each pointing to the center of the bay.
The text reads:
If an enemy vessel had entered San Francisco's harbor during the Civil War, it would have faced fire from four directions.
The panel features a black and white photograph of two large cannon with their long barrels pointed over a short brick wall and to uniformed soldiers standing behind them.
The text reads:
When the Spanish-American War broke out in 1898, Black Point's Civil War batteries were in poor shape. Rather than repair their rotting wooden platforms, two concrete gun emplacements were built beside the west battery. Two Rodman cannon were mounted on the new platforms, in case Spanish ships came from the Philippines to attack San Francisco's harbor.
The panel features a map of Fort Mason, the Great Meadow, the southern waters of the bay and a few blocks south of the meadow. Fort Mason and the Great Meadow are boxed off by a dotted line. A label on the north eastern corner of the Great Meadow reads, “You Are Here.”
 
The text reads:
 
Visit each of the stops along the Fort Mason Historic District walk to learn more about the post's place in American history.
 
End.
 
Walk west about 200 feet, you'll feel the roadway's downward slope begin to even out. From here, you have three options of how to continue. Turning right, to the east, will take you down to the waterfront by the Aquatic Park pier, where there is a wayside a little over one tenth of a mile away along the northern edge of the path on a sidewalk.
Proceeding to the left from McDowell Road, or west, near the Black Point Fortifications wayside, takes you to both the Great Meadow, and down to Fort Mason Center.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 7

sites.description:
Kiosk Panel: Fort Mason Historic District
 
The kiosk faces north, along the edge of a concrete wall next to the waters of the bay.
 
View from the wayside:
 
About 40 feet to the right of the wayside is the entrance to Aquatic Park pier. Be careful as you approach the entrance, as there is a tall curb in the way. The entrance is flanked on either side by a tall, metal fence and preceded by a row of wooden posts. The pier is wide, and curls to the east, offering views of the city and Alcatraz Island. Facing south, there's a trash can 70 feet to the right of the kiosk, on the sidewalk on the far side of the roadway next to a 'No Parking' sign. 
 
The text reads:
 
U.S. Army post (1864-1966)
 
First fortified by the Spanish in 1797, this bluff above the bay was re-armed by the U.S. Army in 1864. The post remained active through the Civil War, western Indian Wars, and conflicts abroad, beginning with the Spanish-American War in 1898. During World War II, Fort Mason was the Army's logistics center for sending troops and supplies to the Pacific.
 
Fort Mason was designated a National Historic Landmark on February 4, 1985.
 
This panel features a black and white photograph of a coastal bluff with a series of buildings comprising a compound. The bluff is undeveloped except for the buildings, so that there is a lot of flat open space leading up to the buildings. A single roadway leads to the buildings. In the distance, across a body of water, mountainous terrain.
 
The text reads:
 
Though San Francisco had grown enormously by 1900, Fort Mason was isolated from the city's bustle by undeveloped open space.
 
In the right corner of this panel is a black and white photo of two men in army uniform and brimmed hats talking to one another as they walk down the steps away from a building's entrance.
 
The text reads:
 
General Dwight D. Eisenhower inspected Fort Mason in 1946.
 
This panel features a black and white photo of several ships with masts docked next to a long building on a pier.
 
Below the picture of the ships is one of a row of cannon in profile, pointed out over the edge of a low-lying parapet.
 
The text reads:
 
Guns were mounted at Fort Mason during the Civil War to guard the harbor and city.
 
In the bottom portion of this panel is a map of Fort Mason, including the Great Meadow, Lower Fort Mason and the Municipal Pier, the entrance to which is labeled “You Are Here.”
 
The text reads:
 
Dog Regulations
Federal Law requires dogs to be on leash at all times in national parks. (36 CFR Part 2) Dog walkers must obey regulations and pick up after their pets.
 
Bicycling
Fort Mason is the doorway to San Francisco. Ride from here across the Great Meadow to the Marina Green and on to Crissy Field promenade, Fort Point and the Golden Gate Bridge.
 
Bicycle etiquette
Share paths safely. Bicycles may not exceed 15 m.p.h. and must slow to 5 m.p.h. around corners and when passing other path users. Yield right of way to pedestrians, strollers and wheelchairs.
 
Accessibility
Nearly all of the paths at Fort Mason are wheelchair accessible. Enjoy views from the Great Meadow or visit the Black Point Battery picnic area and historic site by following a route behind the hostel.
 
History Walk
A free self-guiding booklet may be obtained at building 201 (park headquarters), inside the front entrance, during business hours; open Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. (except holidays).
 
Emergency Information
In an emergency call the Park Communications Center at (415) 561-5510, or dial 911. Cell phone users call (415) 472-0911.
 
End.
 
Walk west up McDowell Road the way you came. In 900 feet, almost one-fifth of a mile, you'll arrive at a wayside along the northern edge of the path.
sites.name: Fort Mason A D 8

sites.audio_description: The dock where the ferry drops off passengers is the lowest point on the island. From there, visitors will climb up the steep, gray cement paths to the various buildings and trails on Alcatraz. An electric tram is also available to transport and deposit visitors to their desired destinations. The buildings on the island all have a somewhat similar look: sand colored facades with simple rectangular windows. Located directly to the left of the dock is Building 64, a large, 4-story sandstone brick building that once provided housing to military officers and their families, and is still used for modern operations on the island.
sites.description:
From its early days as a military fortress and prison, to its most infamous tenure as a federal penitentiary and now its modern incarnation as a cultural attraction, Alcatraz looms large in the American psyche as a place of contradiction, violence and competing historical narratives. 

Welcome to the Rock!
sites.name: Alcatraz Island

sites.description: The Milagra Ridge trail is an easy 1.5 mile loop you can complete in under an hour. The trail, which can be accessed from the entrance off Sharp Park Road or from the parking area at the end of Connemara Drive in Pacifica, will take you through lovely scrub habitat with impressive ocean views.

information.description:
Milagra Ridge is a special place to many people. It's been that way for a long time. Like a lot of places in the region, Milagra Ridge has been home to many cultural groups, beginning with the Ohlone who inhabited the area for thousands of years. 

Approaching modern times, Spanish colonial forces came on the scene in the 1700s, adding a new cultural layer to the landscape. After the Mexican Revolution in 1821, Mexican citizens began using the land for ranching. A short time later in 1846, the US went to war with Mexico, leading to the Bear Flag Revolt, an event that resulted in the declaration of an independent California Republic for a brief time before the territory was incorporated into the US. 
 
During World War II, the US Army built a gun battery at Milagra to protect the coast from enemy invasion  In 1953, a Nike missile launch site was installed during the Cold War. In 1987, Milagra Ridge had a chance to mellow out and became part of Golden Gate National Recreation Area.
 
Since this site became part of the GGNRA, the Park and the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy have transformed this site by working with volunteers to remove invasive plants such as jubata grass and various species of brooms.  Their work has created more space for endangered San Bruno elfin butterflies, endangered mission blue butterflies, and threatened California red-legged frogs--all of which inhabit different areas of this 240 acre site.
information.name: History of Milagra Ridge

sites.name: Milagra Ridge Trailhead

sites.description:
The freshwater pond and streams inland from this bridge are home to the California red-legged frog, a threatened species native to the state and the largest native frog in the western US. In the winter, the park puts up "Slow down for frog crossing" signs here. This species  is now eliminated from 70% of its former range from Mendocino County to Baja, California. The 1880s saw a huge demand for frog legs which led to an over-harvesting of frogs for consumption. Modern threats to the species come from human activity related to agriculture, development, timber harvest and the introduction of non-native predators like bullfrogs. Red-legged frogs are between two and five inches in length with a reddish underbelly and legs, and prefer slow-moving or standing deep ponds and streams. They can live up to 10 years.

To the next tour point: Look for signs on the right for the Coastal Trail, which will lead you up through the riparian glade and back to the Visitor Center.
sites.name: California red-legged frogs

sites.description: On clear days, Sweeney Ridge sports breathtaking views of Montara Mountain, the Pacific Ocean, the San Francisco watershed and the San Andreas Reservoir, which lies within the rift valley of the San Andreas Fault. The San Francisco Bay Portola discovery site and remains on Cold War era Nike missile facilities also lie on the ridge.

information.description:
There are several ways to access the 5.7 combined miles of trails at Sweeney Ridge. Most of the trails are totally exposed, so bring sunscreen! If it's cold and cloudy, bring an extra layer and expect windy conditions. 

Note that it's common for weather to change over the course of an afternoon.
 
Take the Notch Trail from Skyline College and hike south to the ridge where you can take the Sweeney Ridge Trail further south or head west along Mori Ridge Trail.

You can also begin at the trailhead adjacent to the Shelldance Orchid Gardens near CA-1, and climb up to the ridge using the Mori Ridge Trail. From San Bruno, take Sneath Lane to the Sneath Trail.
information.name: Trails at Sweeney Ridge

sites.name: Sweeney Ridge

sites.description: Situated within historic Fort Barry, this [Hostel International](http://www.norcalhostels.org/marin) location and certified green business offers free parking, full kitchens and on-site laundry. The location means easy access to nearby beaches, forests and trails, including a short walk to Rodeo Lagoon and Beach. The seaside town of Sausalito and San Francisco are both five miles away.
sites.name: Marin Headlands Hostel

sites.description: The [Maritime Museum](http://www.maritime.org/index.htm) is your one stop spot for all things naval in San Francisco. In addition to the outdoor waterfront exhibit on Hyde Street Pier, the Visitor Center in the Argonaut Hotel (at the corner of Jefferson and Hyde Streets) has fascinating exhibits on the maritime history of the San Francisco area.
sites.name: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park and Visitor Center

sites.description: Mori Point provides great views of the coast, with Mount Tamalpais visible in the far north and Pedro Point to the south. The area is well known for its spring wildflower displays on the bluffs made of reddish, weathered pillow basalt rocks. The best time for flower viewing is in April.

information.description: During Prohibition In the 1920s, Stefano Mori's son Jack was managing operations at the inn and began serving alcohol at the roadhouse.  Eventually, the Mori family bootlegging operation was so extensive it caught the attention of federal agents. The result was a finish worthy of a Hollywood film, when a shootout took place between "Prohis" and "rumrunners". Jack Mori was arrested in 1923, and federal agents confiscated 24,000 cases of Canadian whiskey from the family farm.
information.name: Speakeasies and bootlegging

information.description: Throughout the 1950s, future head of the Church of Satan Anton LaVey, frequented the area, treating visitors to his talents on the organ at Mori Inn.
information.name: Devil music

information.description: The cult-classic 1971 film Harold and Maude filmed its final scene of a car careening off a cliffside on the bluff here at Mori Point.
information.name: If you want to sing out, sing out!

sites.name: Mori Point

sites.audio_description: Statue of the 900 year old Jedi Master.
sites.description: In this courtyard is a bronze statue atop a water fountain in the likeness of Jedi Master Yoda, who, for 900 years, studied and trained young Jedi knights in the ways of the Force. A native of the remote Dagobah system, Master Yoda’s discipline and role in combating the rise of the Galactic Empire took him throughout the galaxy and has earned him a place of reverence long after his passing.
sites.name: Yoda fountain

sites.audio_description:
The Presidio Officers' Club is a large, sprawling building in the old Spanish mission style, complete with white stucco walls and a red tile roof. In front of the building, just off of the street, is a row of spiky cacti. As you face the Officers' Club from the parking lot directly in front of it, you'll see the entranceway with a pair of heavy brown doors in line with the crosswalk. Mounted on either side of the entrance is a bronze Spanish cannon, weathered to a blue-green patina. The entrance is part of a one-story section of the building that stretches off to the left, with an angled tile roof overhead, and wooden posts every few feet. The roof hangs down past the wall, creating a covered walkway below. To the right of the walkway and entrance the building becomes nearly two stories tall, with a broad, white faced facade facing the street. The facade has three rectangular windows, taller than they are wide, set equidistantly from each other along the first story. At the level of the second story, at the top-center portion of the facade, is a small circular window. 

The facade has squared off sides, and comes together at a point at the top. The red tile roof is angled like that of an A-frame house. The facade is but one side of the building which stretches further back, away from the street, connecting the front of the Officer's Club to the rest of the building in the rear. This section is even taller, reaching a full two stories, and is visible from the parking lot. On the second level is a veranda facing the parking lot. The top section is lined with windows and on the far left, a square tower with two rounded windows and a red tile roof rises above every other part of the building.
sites.description: Located at the Main Post of the Presidio, the [Presidio Officers' Club](http://www.presidio.gov/officers-club) is a great space to enjoy an elegant meal or plan an event. It's also a great place to spend an afternoon taking in the historic and artistic exhibits on display.

information.description:
The building known as the Officers' Club was established in 1776 by the Spanish in the early days of the Presidio. The front of today’s building contains adobe walls from the old Spanish Presidio. Visit the Mesa Room in the club to see the building's history peeled back.

In 1847, the US Army rebuilt the building, which it used from the start of its occupation of the Presidio beginning in 1846. 

In the 1930s, the Works Progress Administration remodeled the Officers' Club once again to resemble the Mission Revival style, characterized by white walls and a red tile roof. The 1970s saw the addition of the bell tower, and more recent modifications have been made to preserve the Spanish colonial style while adding concrete, steel and wood framing. 

The last restoration completed in 2014 sought to highlight historical preservation, and integrate the Officers' Club into a more regular function in modern San Francisco.
information.name: History of a happening place

information.description:
The year is 1776. In one week, some upstarts in Philadelphia will sign the Declaration of Independence. On the West Coast, an expedition of 200 mestizo soldiers and colonists, one priest and 1,000 head of cattle under the command of Juan Bautista de Anza arrive here after traveling from Nuevo España. These colonists establish a military garrison, el Presidio de San Francisco. It's the furthest north the Spanish have spread their forces in the New World.

In the earliest days, Presidio soldiers concerned themselves with forcing the indigenous peoples into newly established Spanish-style communities and protecting the frontier. Thin soil and strong coastal winds made agriculture and cattle grazing difficult, but colonists bent themselves to the task, though their efforts took a toll on the land and their bodies. 
 
In the late 1700s, the bay was the Spanish wild frontier and the Presidio's residents were largely on their own. Supply shipments came at most once a year. In 1792, a British ship sailed to the bay and reported the Spanish fortification was poorly supplied and defended. When Spanish command heard of the British report, they strengthened their holdings on the bay by constructing two new fortifications, Castillo de San Joaquín near Fort Point, and Batería de Yerba Buena, where Union forces would establish Fort Mason in 1864.
information.name: Spanish conquest

information.description:
In the early 1800s, revolts started cropping up across the Mexican countryside in support of a sovereign Mexican state free from Spanish colonial rule, leading to a full-on revolution in 1810. The revolutionaries fought for a decade until Spanish General Agustín de Iturbide switched his allegiance from Spain to Mexico, immediately garnering the support of the rebels. On August 24, 1821, representatives of the Spanish Crown and Iturbide signed the Treaty of Córdoba, formally acknowledging Mexican independence after 300 years of Spanish control. However, when Iturbide was crowned emperor by the newly formed Mexican Sovereign Congress, the move drew harsh criticism which led to Commander Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna and his troops deposing the emperor’s authority, and declaring Mexico a Republic. 

The Mexican Era of the Presidio was characterized by promises from the new government meant to support the outpost that never came to pass. Soldiers were constantly owed back pay, a fact that turned their allegiance from their commanders. Supplies and funds for operations didn't arrive, leading to the troops' inability to enforce their authority in the surrounding areas or even keep Presidio buildings in good repair.
information.name: Mexican Independence and the Presidio’s decline

information.description:
The Heritage Gallery showcases artifacts from the diverse cultures and overlapping historical narratives that describe the complex history of the Presidio in the context of California, the nation and its people. The gallery also features films, images, artifacts and multimedia exhibits. 

Been before? The gallery has short-term as well as permanent displays, so there's always something new to see.
information.name: Heritage Gallery

information.description: Discovering the past is hard, ongoing work. Come take a look at what technicians from the [Presidio Archaeology Lab](http://www.presidio.gov/volunteer/Pages/archaeology.aspx) are doing to make sense of the clues left behind from the original Presidio colonial site. Weekly lab tours are Wednesdays at 1pm. Meet outside the Officers' Club at 9am to see the dig site Monday through Saturday.
information.name: Archaeology Lab

sites.name: Presidio Officers' Club

sites.description:
The Presidio Transit Center located at the Main Post gets visitors, residents and commuters where they're going around the Presidio for free seven days a week. The PresidiGo shuttle starts and stops its route here. 

Before you head out on your day's journey, consider dropping into [Transit Café](http://www.presidio.gov/places/Pages/transit.aspx) for a casual meal or take food out with you for a day spent on-the-go. 

The  café is open weekdays from 7:30 am to 5:30 pm, and Saturdays from 8:30 am to 5:30 pm.
sites.name: Presidio Transit Center & Café

sites.description:
The Presidio Fire Station was the first on any US Army post to house a permanent fire company with trained firefighters. Built in 1917 after fires claimed several Presidio buildings, including the tragic fire that claimed the life of General John Pershing's wife, Frances Warren Pershing, and their three daughters. Frances Pershing's father was Francis E. Warren, a US senator of Wyoming, who, after his daughter's death, pushed for a fire station at the Presidio and on military bases around the country. 

After the Presidio was turned over to the National Park Service in 1994, the firefighters at the Presidio became the only park service firefighters trained in both urban and wildland firefighting. In 2010, the fire station was incorporated into the San Francisco Fire Department.
sites.name: Presidio Fire Station

sites.description: In what used to be a munitions cache, artist Andy Goldsworthy has created a dreamlike space that evokes a sense of wonder and imagination around the natural world of the Presidio. Using a large piece of wood from a felled eucalyptus and clay mixture, a team of 40 volunteers helped Goldsworthy make his creative vision become a reality.
sites.name: Andy Goldsworthy's Tree Fall

sites.description: Housed in historic buildings, the [Fisherman's Wharf Hostel International](http://www.sfhostels.org/fishermans-wharf) offers a range of accommodations including both shared dorms and private rooms. The on-site Cafe Franco, has beautiful bay views and serves up three meals a day. The hostel's friendly staff lead groups on fun activities in the city, and can point you in whatever direction you like during your stay.
sites.name: Fisherman's Wharf Hostel International

sites.description:
_River otters in the Marin Headlands_

River otters became locally extinct in Marin County by 1960, and weren't seen in Marin again until 1987. When otters reappeared, they probably came from a population along the Russian River. Otters can travel up to 25 miles overnight! After they returned to the lagoon, they quickly ate all of the larger fish. Now, the otters are known to swim under unsuspecting waterbirds and pull them under for dinner.

The River Otter Ecology Project with help from NatureBridge is conducting studies to better understand the behavior and health of our local otters including details regarding their range, reproduction and dietary habits. 


_Feathered friends at the lagoon_

Rodeo Lagoon hosts several hundred brown pelicans every fall, making it one of the largest gathering spots for the species in northern California. In addition to pelicans, many aquatic birds make their home by the lagoon, including double-crested cormorants, great blue herons, grebes and egrets.
sites.name: Otters & Birds

sites.description: Lands End Lookout is a great place to begin or end an adventure in this beatific ocean side landscape. Come enjoy a cup of coffee and a treat at the café. Peruse the souvenir shop and bookstore, where you can take a part of this special place home with you.

information.description:
For thousands of years, the Yelamu Ohlone tribe and their predecessors lived at Lands End in seasonal settlements. They lived off the land—making salt, gathering shellfish and hunting seabirds and marine mammals—making use of the resources in a way that worked for generations.
 
When the Spanish settled in the area in 1776, they moved the Yelamu to Mission Dolores. This forced relocation had dramatic consequences for the native people. The Spanish made the Yelamu conform to their own societal norms and exposed them to new diseases such as measles and influenza, resulting in dramatic death tolls. The arrival of European colonists completely obliterated the Ohlone way of life, but they endured in spite of adversity. Today, the Ohlone community is actively revitalizing their traditions, despite the Spanish colonists' systematic attempt to destroy their culture.
information.name: Coast natives

information.description: In the mid 1800s, Lands End was a secluded, inaccessible area that meant a long journey for anyone to come out this way. After California was annexed by the US in 1846, some of the first visitors brave enough to venture here were far out hippie scientist types: naturalists interested in studying marine mammals and other natural wonders native to this unique environment.
information.name: 19th Century naturalists

information.description: The Lands End Lookout Visitors Center provides a recorded audio described tour. This tour provides information about the Visitors Center and surrounding sites. Please request a device from the center staff.
information.name: Audio described exhibit tour

sites.name: Lands End Lookout Visitor Center

sites.description:
Located along a fire road above Rodeo Beach, Battery Townsley is one of only two WWII era batteries in the San Francisco area that contained mammoth 16-inch guns; the other being at Fort Funston, also in the park. These guns together protected an area from Half Moon Bay to Point Reyes, effectively covering the entire sea approach to San Francisco.
The army installed these big naval guns to match those on battleships sailing the Pacific in the late 1930s. For the year following Pearl Harbor, 150 men lived inside this cavernous fortress twenty-four seven. Today you can visit the exhibits inside during open hours. It's a steep climb up the road to Battery Townsley, but worth it for the history lesson and views of Rodeo Beach and the Pacific Ocean.

information.description: 16-inch guns were sixty-eight feet long and could fire a 2,000-pound projectile almost twenty-five miles. The gun tube posted here outside the battery was originally mounted in one of the forward gun turrets aboard the battleship USS Missouri and saw extensive action during World War II. It's identical to the two guns that were mounted here during World War II.
information.name: 16” Gun

sites.name: Battery Townsley

sites.description:
The UN at Muir Woods
The wayside is left of the trail. 
Panel Description
363 words. Graphic panel set into wood frame, 20 inches by 14 inches. 

View from the wayside:
57 words.

Beyond the wayside is a grove of large redwoods, all of which are growing straight except for one which is leaning left at a 45 degree angle. The trees are surrounded by ferns and sorrel. Across the trail directly opposite the wayside is the Franklin Delano Roosevelt memorial plaque, a bronze plate set into a redwood log. 

The plaque reads: 

“Here in this grove of enduring redwoods, preserved for posterity, members of the United Nations Conference on International Organization met on May 19, 1945, to honor the memory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, thirty-first President of the United States, chief architect of the United Nations, and apostle of lasting peace for all mankind.”

The text reads: In 1945, delegates from all over the world met in San Francisco to establish the United Nations. On May 19, they traveled to Muir Woods to honor the memory of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, whose death one month earlier had thrown the world into mourning. President Roosevelt believed in the value of national parks as sources of inspiration and human renewal. He also believed that good forestry practices and sustainable development of natural resources were keystones to lasting peace around the world. Organizers of the event hoped that the profound beauty and serenity of Muir Woods would inspire the delegates to pursue the president’s program for world peace as they met to establish the United Nations.

This panel features a black and white photo of dozens of U.N. delegates standing close together surrounded by redwoods. In front of the delegates stands a small group of men to either side of a veiled sign. Behind these men, is a group of Navy sailors in blue uniforms wearing round, white hats.

Quoted text reads: “...here in such a ‘temple of peace’ the delegates would gain a perspective and sense of time that could be obtained nowhere in America better than in such a forest. Muir Woods is a cathedral, the pillars of which have stood through much of recorded human history…”  --Harold Ickes, US Secretary of the Interior, 1945

End.
sites.name: Muir Woods A D Wayside 13

sites.description: The Warden’s house, a 15-room mansion built in 1921, was home to four wardens between 1934 and 1963. Despite their serious jobs, the wardens knew how entertain, and were known to throw lavish cocktail parties just a few feet from the cellhouse. Despite their neighborly proximity, prisoners were kept off the guest list. The house is considerably less swanky today, as it burned down during the Indian Occupation of Alcatraz.
sites.name: Alcatraz Warden's house

sites.audio_description:
Muir Beach Overlook Road winds its way south west to the overlook parking lot. The parking lot is a semi-circular ring with a circumference of about 500 feet and three rows of parking. The row furthest to the south west is separated from the other two by a grassy median 110 ten feet long north to south and 17 feet wide east to west. Bathrooms are located along the north east edge of the parking lot. Trash and recycling cans are at the center of the bathroom building, against the outer wall.

The south western perimeter of the parking lot is dotted with picnic tables. The Owl Trail begins at the north west corner of the parking lot and continues along the ridge of the cliff. To the south west, there are two short paths that lead from the parking lot to Muir Beach Overlook. The paths come together at a junction in front of a World War Two fire control station dugout. The dugout, or “gopher hole” is a partially submerged cement structure big enough for two men to stand. It resembles a pill, with a one-quarter section missing. Opposite the dugout to the south west are three interpretive wayside panels.

The stair path continues to the south west, passing two more dugouts to the left on the way to Muir Beach Overlook. The corridor to the overlook is very windy. The path down to the overlook is a 500-foot series of stairs with a rail fence to either side. The path is wide enough for three people to walk abreast. On either side are clumps of thick coastal scrub and tall, green cypress trees with needle-covered branches. As you descend, the hillsides recede and the Pacific Ocean takes up more and more of the horizon. At the bottom of the stairs, the overlook itself, is a small, circular clearing with a railing around it. The view offers 180 degrees of the Pacific Ocean, and tall, rocky cliffs to the north and south along the coast.
sites.description:
Muir Beach overlook offers spectacular views of the Pacific and rocky coastal cliffs, but bring a windbreaker! The stair trail out to the furthest lookout point is more than a little blustery, but well worth the view. 

The overlook is a fine place for a picnic, with many tables along the side of the parking lot closest to the coast. Keep your eyes peeled, you may get lucky and catch a glimpse of migrating whales. Enjoy the quiet serenity high above the water, surrounded by cypresses, Douglas firs and chaparral. Be wary of the plants, the poison oak is no joke out here. Plenty of parking.

information.description:
After the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the US went about shoring up its defenses along the California coast, installing several gun batteries north of San Francisco. No batteries were installed at the overlook, but instead a base end "fire control" station was built. 

These stations consisted of two-men dugouts, or gopher holes, where soldiers used massive spotting scopes to keep watch on the ocean horizon for enemy ships. Any sightings could be reported back to a central communications and plotting center, and relayed to nearby gun batteries should their artillery be needed.
information.name: Coastal Defense

information.description:
From the overlook, you'll see rocky coastline, bluffs, sandy beaches, mountain ridges, valleys and peninsulas reaching out into the Pacific. Each of these features are the result and a clue to tumultuous geologic events. The rocks that jut out from the water just beyond the bluffs are called sea stacks. They are resistant basalt formations formed by  millennia of battering ocean waves. The eroded remains of a former bluff edge. 

Further inland, a careful eye will notice massive boulders dotting the hilly landscape. These boulders are part of a geologic phenomena known as melange, a mish-mash of hard ancient sea floor deposits and lava mixed into soft mud deposits. The melange was likely formed by giant earthquakes that tumbled rocks down into a deep sea subduction trench many tens of millions of years ago.

The more recent San Andreas fault line is located just off shore from the overlook. The fault line separates melange rocks of the North American continental plate from Sierran granitic rocks captured by the Pacific Plate in southern California and brought here by movement along the fault. During the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, this part of the fault moved over 20 feet. Point Reyes Peninsula, visible protruding into the ocean to the north on a clear day, is on the west side of the fault and is underlain by granitic rocks on the Pacific Plate.
information.name: Shake, Rattle, and Roll

sites.name: Muir Beach Overlook

sites.audio_description:
At the top of Conzelman Road is Battery Wallace, a historic World War Two outpost. Today, it is an ideal spot for a picnic, with barbecues and picnic tables on-site, with great views of the San Francisco Bay and Golden Gate Bridge beneath the shade of tall, dark green Monterey cypresses. There is ample parking and a bathroom facility with recycling and trash bins. adjacent to the parking area. 

The picnic area is a short walk across a road to Battery Wallace, a cement structure built into the landscape. A cement passageway cuts through a hillside covered in tree litter, with the words “BATTERY WALLACE, 1942” etched into the concrete overpass just as you pass under the hill. The passageway leads to a circular room with a cement floor and walls. There's no concrete at the very center of the room's floor. Instead, there's a circle of bare ground with patchy clumps of grass growing intermittently throughout. As you walk through the passageway, instead of a wall along the far side of the room, there's an open space. A trapezoid shaped opening leads out onto the hillside. On the opposite ridge, a two-level, rectangular structure is visible at about the same elevation as Battery Wallace.
sites.description:
When construction on Battery Wallace began in 1917, making the battery resistant against air strikes was not considered, and the primary weaponry, two 12-inch diameter guns, had no overhead protection against bombers. Despite this flaw, Battery Wallace became instrumental as a defense post during WWII. To give the battery some protection against potential Japanese bomber attacks, the 12-inch guns were buried under thick covers of earth and concrete. 

The vantage point from the battery is now a beautiful spot for a picnic barbecue beneath shaded trees overlooking the Golden Gate. More secluded than many destinations in the Headlands, Battery Wallace has more space to relax and on clear days, spectacular views of the Golden Gate Bridge and San Francisco.
sites.name: Battery Wallace

sites.description: Fort Baker, the final "Post-to-Park" conversion in the Golden Gate National Parks, is a 335 acre former 1905 US Army post located immediately north of the Golden Gate Bridge. There are more than 30 historic army buildings, many clustered around a main parade ground that today, are home to a number of park partners including Cavallo Point Lodge, the US Coast Guard and the Bay Area Discovery Museum. There's also a harbor, several historic gun emplacements and trails.

information.description:
A signpost near the kiosk gives instructions on how to use cellphones to listen to pre-recorded audio with additional information about the history and environment around Fort Baker.

A map of the tour is available through park partners, Bay Area Discovery Museum, Cavallo Point Lodge registration and the Marin Headlands Visitor Center.
information.name: Cell Phone Tour

information.description:
The Coast Miwok ancestral lands include areas north of the Golden Gate, primarily in Marin County and southern Sonoma County including Horseshoe Cove at Fort Baker and Big Lagoon at Muir Beach. The Miwok and their ancestors made their home in these lands for 10,000 years before any European colonists arrived.

Historically, the Miwok were organized into small, politically independent societal groups. These groups were nomadic, moving annually between temporary and permanent village sites determined by seasonal hunting, fishing and resource gathering. Because of their proximity to the Pacific Ocean, the Coast Miwok relied more heavily on resources like kelp and shellfish for food than other native groups in the region.

The Miwoks were spared a few more years of independence from Spanish influence than the Ohlone because they lived further from the Presidio and first missions. But by 1783, several members of the Huimen community, who inhabited the southern-most part of Marin County, came under mission control.

A few years after their arrival to the region, the Spanish began a cultural takeover of the indigenous meant to disrupt the native way of life. By 1810, a combination of indoctrination, slave labor and diseases brought by the Spanish led to severe cultural decimation of the Miwok. Yet, despite this attempt of systematic destruction, the Miwok endured.

Today, the Miwok live throughout the Bay Area and are committed to the preservation and of their culture. Language revitalization, protecting ancestral sites, traditional plant use, storytelling, dance, song, and basket weaving are all aspects of restoration efforts.
information.name: Bay Natives: The Coast Miwok

information.description: Although the Spanish colonized this region in 1776, this area remained largely uninhabited even after the Mexican War of Independence, which was fought from 1810 to 1821. Towards the middle of the 19th century, the grasslands here were gaining recognition as primo territory for cattle ranching. In the late 1830s, one time cabin boy-turned Port Captain William Richardson became the first settler to put down roots in this area north of the Golden Gate. Richardson married the Commandant of the Presidio's daughter, and was awarded a land grant giving him the rights to these lands which he used to establish Rancho Sausalito, his cattle ranching operation. Later, this land would become the site of Fort Baker.
information.name: Mexican Era Rancho Sausalito

information.description: In the mid 19th century, the US army set about modernizing the harbor defenses of San Francisco. The brick forts that had been the standard structures for the first half of the century, were now vulnerable to rifled artillery attack. The army therefore, developed a more modern system that relied on hidden batteries and 'disappearing' guns. At first, the men who operated and maintained this new weaponry, slept in tents, but cold fog and strong winds made more permanent housing a necessity, hence the construction of Fort Baker in 1901.
information.name: Establishing Fort Baker

information.description: As the country began to mobilize for war, the army created the Harbor Defenses of San Francisco, a system with operational command over many San Francisco army posts, including Fort Baker, Fort Barry and Fort Cronkhite. The Harbor Defenses of San Francisco was responsible for ensuring the safety of friendly shipping traffic and defending the coastline from enemy naval attack. The entrance to the bay was lined with underwater mines, which were armed by hand by soldiers here at Fort Baker. Past the mines, closer in to land, was an antisubmarine net protected by the 3-inch rapid fire guns at Battery Yates.
information.name: Fort Baker defenses during WWII

information.description: Much of San Francisco and points north of the bay fall under the realm of the frequent visitor in gray, Karl the Fog. Karl is fond of the Golden Gate Bridge, the bay and large swaths of the city disappear within his dense shroud. The product of cold ocean water and warmer landward moving air coming together at the Golden Gate, when he shows up for several days on end, Karl can feel a lot like the house guest on your couch whose outstayed their welcome. One place Karl stays away from, is Fort Baker, which is protected by the high ridge to the west, that keeps Karl at bay.
information.name: Fogless wonder

sites.name: Fort Baker

sites.description:
During the Civil War most army officers favored the Episcopalian faith, so it was no surprise when a new chaplain arrived at the Presidio in 1863, he was Episcopalian. It's likely that he raised private funds to construct the chapel through the support of the Presidio officers and the Episcopal Diocese.

The chapel was open by the time the Confederacy surrendered on April 9, 1865. The war had cost at least 558,000 lives. Five days later President Lincoln was assassinated. News of both these events reached the Presidio on Easter weekend, overwhelming the new chapel.

In 1952 the chapel went through major remodeling. More alterations were made in 1970. Now, [the Chapel of Our Lady](http://www.presidio.gov/venues/Pages/Chapel-of-Our-Lady.aspx) a beautiful place to get hitched, but this venue is a must, so is flexibility--reservations are taken up to two years in advance.
sites.name: Chapel Of Our Lady

sites.audio_description:
Located on the side of a hill off of Field Road, the Marin Headlands Nike missile site is a flat, paved area with only a few structures and several pieces of old army equipment left over from the days when the site was an active missile launch site.

On approach to SF-88, the official name for the Nike site, you'll come to a ten foot tall chain link security fence with barb wire at the top. The fence goes all the way around the perimeter of the site, and the entrance from the road is a section that must be rolled aside to allow cars or persons inside. Just past the gate is a small, aqua colored booth with two mannequin soldiers inside. The booth has been preserved in a fashion that suggests current usage. The desk is covered in papers and old soda cans. At the desk is a typewriter, and along the shelves to the back, a walkie talkie and a radio. Phones are mounted to the wall between the window panes. A sign is posted that reads in all-capital block letters, “SMOKING PERMITTED WITHIN THIS BUILDING.” The mannequin army men are standing at attention in full uniform facing the entrance.

A paved road takes you further into the site past the security booth to a more centralized parking area in front of a one-story rectangular building reminiscent of a duplex, with two sets of double doors set equidistantly from each other. There are several picnic tables out front between the parking lot and the building, as well as a trash and recycling bin up against the building's facade on the right.

There are two large pieces of radar equipment behind the duplex-looking building. One is on a raised, 10-sided polygon platform. One is a large sphere, covered in an army green tarp, a missile guidance radar. The other is supported by a cylindrical column, and has a shape similar to a rectangular prism, a LOPAR acquisition radar. Opposite the radars are two white, metal rectangular trailers. 

The Nike site isn't immediately visible from other areas close by in the Headlands, but the site, you have panoramic views of the surrounding hills and lowlands.
sites.description:
The Cold War was a tense time between the United States and the Soviet Union, two superpowers vying for global influence. To defend against potential Soviet attacks, the US Army built close to 300 Nike missile launch batteries between 1953 and 1979. The warheads at these sites were armed with nuclear payloads, that, had they ever been used, would have detonated above the California communities where they were located. SF-88 in the Marin Headlands was one such site. Today, GGNRA preserves the site as it was during operations to remind visitors of the physical effects of the Cold War on American landscape.

SF-88 is open Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays from 12:30 - 3:30 PM. On the first Saturday of each month there is an open house with volunteers and Nike Veterans interpreting the history of the base. To confirm hours or if you have any questions, please contact the Marin Headlands Visitor Center at 415-331-1540.
sites.name: Nike Missile Site

sites.description:
Lover's Lane is one of the oldest foot trails in the Presidio, having first been used by US soldiers to catch the trolley line into town so they could visit their sweethearts and families in the late 19th century.

Lovers' Lane is a great place for relaxing one-mile stroll. The trail begins at Funston Avenue and Presidio Boulevard, then crosses a tiny brick footbridge over the creek running down Tennessee Hollow from El Polin spring before climbing the hill to the Presidio Avenue Gate.
sites.name: Lover's Lane

sites.description: Today's marsh at Crissy Field is a recreation of part of a much more extensive wetlands that extended east, to near Fort Mason. The dunes surrounding the marsh are planted with coastal scrub plants that provide a beautiful carpet of flowers in the spring. Efforts to restore this tidal marsh, which feeds into the bay, have been long and arduous because of the environmental damage inflicted by the Army, who used the marsh as a dump site for years before filling it in for the 1915 International Exposition. Thanks to the countless hours and uncompromising efforts of the Golden Gate Parks Conservancy and the National Park Service, the natural beauty and diversity of life of this environment is being restored.

information.description: During the late 1800s when the US Army took over the Presidio, they considered the wetlands as an unhealthy nuisance and attempted to fill the marsh with refuse, wreaking havoc on the natural wetlands. This practice was a stark contrast to how the land is managed today.
information.name: Unsustainable Practice

information.description: In 1915, a big hoopla celebrating the opening of the Panama Canal, went down in San Francisco: the Panama-Pacific International Exposition (PPIE). In preparation for the event, the army was happy to let the city fill 630 acres of tidal marsh, stretching a full three miles from Fort Mason to Fort Point, where 31 nations and several US states built exhibits to dazzle the public, all connected by 47 miles of walkways. This area had a livestock show arena. State and international pavilions stretched eastward and an automobile racetrack lay to the west. The PPIE not only signaled the completion of a major technological achievement, it was also an announcement to the nation and world that San Francisco had rebounded from the devastation of the 1906 earthquake and fire.
information.name: Panama-Pacific International Exposition

information.description: Since the tidal marsh re-opened in 2000, visitors have seen over 120 bird species in the area as well as jack smelt, bay shrimp and Dungeness crabs, a popular food source that may be contributing to the increased number of bird friends. Today the marsh covers 20 acres, stretching over a mile along the Promenade.
information.name: Bringing the marsh back to life

information.description:
During the recreation of Crissy marsh, while the water was still unconnected to the bay, many shorebirds that hadn't been seen in the area for decades began stopping by at this location.

Each year thousands of birds pass through the Presidio along the Pacific Flyway, the migratory bird equivalent of a cross-continent highway that goes all the way from South America to Canada. Birds use the marsh like a rest stop, to give their wings a break, grab a bite and let the kids go to the bathroom.
information.name: Come fly the Pacific skies

information.description: Sometimes Crissy marsh is separated from the bay by the barrier beach for periods lasting several months because there isn’t enough water in the wetlands to keep the channel open. Park scientists monitor the water quality in the marsh. When conditions are deemed too poor, a ditch is dug to reconnect the marsh to the bay.
information.name: How does the marsh water look today?

sites.name: Crissy Marsh

sites.audio_description:
The Golden Gate Plaza is a series of buildings, trails and outdoor displays relating to the Golden Gate Bridge. Facing north from the parking lot, the plaza is in front of you separated by a two lane street. The bathrooms are to your left, on the same side of the street as the parking lot, and the bridge, the bathrooms are on your left. Once you go north and cross the street from the parking lot, you will be in an open plaza, with the orange Welcome Center Information & Store building on your right. Straight ahead is a bronze statue of a man with short, wavy hair wearing a suit. This is Joseph Strauss, the chief engineer of the Golden Gate Bridge. On your left opposite the Welcome Center souvenir store on the way to the Strauss statue, are two panels whose images change depending on how you face them. They feature photographs that show change over time during the construction process of the Golden Gate Bridge. Up above on a hillside straight behind the statue of Strauss is a circular building with glass walls, the Round House Cafe. It's accessible by a ramp that curves around the building's exterior. The different sections of the outdoor plaza area are accessible, and feature descriptive panels about regional history as well as tactile models of the bridge that demonstrate the physics behind its design in addition to 3D maps of area topography. 

Footpaths and bike trails take you from the plaza to the bridge deck and other areas within the Presidio.
sites.description: The plaza is the starting point for all your bridge-related adventures. From here, you can learn about the history of the bridge and its impact on the Bay Area with the help of interactive installations and models, including a cross-section of the bridge's main suspender cable.

information.description:
You can pay to park your car at the plaza, which gives access to the Golden Gate Bridge and the Battery East/San Francisco Bay Trail. Walking across the bridge is not only a popular tourist activity, but plenty of people from around the Bay Area flock everyday for the same chance to bike or walk across the span.
