Depending on weather, the walk across the bridge can afford stunning views of the city and the Marin Headlands, but don't be surprised if you get caught in the Fog Dome!

Walking across the bridge is just one option. The trails from the plaza go in several directions, even leading to Fort Point below. These trails have been recently improved for accessibility and accommodation of cyclists.
information.name: Get Your Nature On: Trails at the Plaza

information.description:
The Welcome Center is your starting point for walking across the Golden Gate Bridge or planning an excursion in nearby parklands. You can ask a ranger about places to visit and pick up all bridge-related souvenirs. It's highly recommended that you take public transit to the Welcome Center, as parking is limited. 

There are several ways you can get to the Welcome Center from San Francisco. 

Downtown, at Main and Folsom or along Mission Street.  (Routes 10, 70, and 101)

Union Square, at 5th Street and Mission.  (Routes 10, 70, and 101)

Civic Center, at 7th Street and Market or McAllister and Polk Street. (Routes 10, 70, 92, 93, and 101)

Along Fisherman's Wharf.  (Routes 2, 4, 8, 18, 24, 27, 38, 44, 54, 56, 58, 72, 74, and 76)

You can also take the PresidiGo shuttles from the Presidio.

Use the transit site to plan your route http://goldengatebridge.org/visitors/directions.php
information.name: Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center

information.description:
The bridge took more than four years to build, from January 5th, 1933 until its official open to vehicular traffic on May 28th, 1937.

The Civil War era building, Fort Point, was slated for demolition in 1933 to make way for the bridge's construction, but Chief Engineer Joseph Strauss put a halt to the plan, citing the fort’s fine masonry as well as its historical significance among the reasons it should remain. The bridge was redesigned with an arch at the south end to accommodate the fort.

In 1967, San Francisco topless star Yvonne D’Angers, aka the Persian Lamb, protested threats of deportation by chaining herself to the bridge.

In 2004, a young deer decided to join the commute, bounding across the bridge in a FasTrak lane before exiting on 19th Avenue and disappearing into the Presidio.

In late August 2005, a 6-foot tall ostrich escaped from a cargo van just in time to jam the evening commute north and south across the bridge.

A bridge spanning the Golden Gate Strait was first proposed in 1872 by railroad tycoon Charles Crocker. At the time, many people thought a bridge across the strait couldn’t be built. The idea wasn't brought up again until 1919, when the San Francisco Board of Supervisors instructed the city engineer to do a study to evaluate the feasibility of such an undertaking.

When it was first being built, the bridge had enemies. Among them, the Southern Pacific Railroad, who had a controlling interest in the ferry that conveyed commuters from Marin County to the city and legendary landscape photographer Ansel Adams and the Sierra Club, both of whom opposed its construction fearing it would ruin the view.

At its opening in 1937, the bridge weighed 894,500 tons. After modifications in 1986, the bridge slimmed down to a lean 887,000 tons. The towers are 746 feet tall, and each have about 600,000 rivets. End to end, including abutments, the bridge is 1.7 miles long. The span across the strait is 1.2 miles long.
 
The main suspension cables, which run the length of the bridge passing over the tops of the towers, are made of galvanized carbon steel wire. Each cable is 36 3/8 inches in diameter and 7,650 feet long. The total length of galvanized steel wire used in both cables combined is 80,000 miles, for a combined weight of 24,500 tons.

The bridge was built to move. At midspan, the bridge can lower as much as 10.8 feet, or rise as much as 5.8 feet. Side to side, the bridge can sway up to 27.7 feet.

The bridge's unique color, "International Orange," was carefully selected by consulting architect Irving Morrow, who picked the it to complement the bridge's environs, highlight its immensity and make it more visible in fog.
information.name: Bridge Trivia

sites.name: Golden Gate Bridge Plaza

sites.audio_description:
Muir Woods National Monument
649 words.

The entrance to Muir Woods National Monument is located along a sharp bend on Muir Woods Road. Limited parking is available in a small lot to the east of the Visitor Center.

Facing west from the parking lot, the plaza is directly ahead of you. The plaza is an open space leading to the Visitor Center, ticket kiosk and entrance to the woods, all to the north. The Visitor Center is to the right of the ticket kiosk, and the entrance to the woods is a few feet further north behind both buildings. Bathrooms are located at the south west corner of the plaza, near the passenger drop off along Muir Woods Road.

In the middle of the plaza is a bronze, three-dimensional tactile model of Muir Woods and the Redwood Creek Watershed. The plaza is lined with wooden benches around its perimeter. To the north, a large wooden sign marks the entrance to Muir Woods, and a lone redwood towers over the shorter canopy of Douglas firs that crowd out the sky. As you pass under the wooden sign the asphalt of the plaza becomes a boardwalk path.

As you pass under the wooden entrance sign, you are immediately surrounded by a dense forest. The main section of Muir Woods is a 1.3 mile loop consisting of the Redwood Creek and Bohemian Grove Trails. The trails are a combination of wooden boardwalks and asphalt that circle around redwood groves and lead back to the Visitor Center and plaza. While you can take either trail to start, the loop is designed to begin with Redwood Creek Trail. From the entrance to the woods, Redwood Creek Trail is the path that forks slightly east, to the right.

Along the Redwood Creek Trail, you will encounter the Muir Woods Cafe and gift shop, Redwood Creek, Founders Grove and Cathedral Grove. Four bridges cross over Redwood Creek from the Redwood Creek Trail. The first three link Redwood Creek Trail to Bohemian Grove Trail to the west. The fourth bridge leads up to the Hillside Trail. Take any of the first three bridges to the Bohemian Grove Trail in order to loop back to the Visitor Center and entrance.

Beginning at the entrance sign to the woods, it is about a one tenth of a mile walk along Redwood Creek Trail to the Muir Woods Trading Company gift shop and cafe. A short series of stairs leads to the cafe and gift shop to the right of the trail. 75 feet further north, an accessible ramp to the right of the trail also provides access to the gift shop, cafe and bathrooms. The stairs and ramp lead to an outdoor patio. The cafe and gift shop are straight ahead, the bathrooms are to the left of the gift shop, which is left of the cafe. Left of the trail, directly opposite the junction that leads to the Muir Woods Trading Company is Bridge 1, which cuts west, or, to the left of Redwood Creek Trail.

Continuing north about two tenths of a mile from the gift shop is Founders Grove, a wider section of the woods that features some of its largest redwoods. These coniferous giants have soft, pulpy bark with a reddish hue, which gives them their name. Park staff lead periodic talks on the history and ecology of Muir Woods in Founders Grove. 

Bridge 1 and Bridge 2 are two tenths of a mile apart. Bridge 2 and Bridge 3 are one tenth of a mile apart. Bridge 3 and Bridge 4 are half a mile apart. Bridge 3 is the final turnaround and connection between the Redwood Creek and Bohemian Grove Trails. Bridge 4 crosses over the creek and leads up to the Hillside Trail. A series of 21 wayside interpretive panels are arranged beginning in the plaza, along the loop trail, Cathedral Grove and the Bohemian Grove Trail.
sites.description: Muir Woods offers an experience available in only a handful of places on Earth. The peaceful groves of old-growth coast redwoods found here are examples of the species _Sequoia sempervirens_, whose only habitat left on the entire planet are in pockets along the northern half of the California Pacific Coast. Muir Woods offers a space for quiet reflection in a filtered light forest environment. The immense height of the redwoods is sure to impress, but perhaps more impressive is the lifespan of these trees. The average age of the trees in Muir Woods is between 500-600 years, though some as old as 700-1,000 have been documented, and in the right conditions, redwoods are capable of living up to 2,000 years. They’re among the oldest living things on the planet, making Muir Woods a world-class destination that's not to be missed. Boasting accessible boardwalk trails and trailheads that lead through the forest to the coast, Muir Woods has adventures for all nature lovers, although dog friends must stay at home.

information.description:
Before the 1800s, California's northern coast was covered in approximately 2 million acres of redwood forests,  just like the one you're standing in now. Development and logging resulted in the loss of 97 % of these trees. The area along Redwood Creek, in what is now known as Muir Woods, may well have been logged too, had it not been so difficult to access. By the early 20th century, Redwood Creek contained one of the last uncut old-growth redwood stands in the Bay Area. Now, it’s one of the only old-growth coast redwood forest left in the Bay Area, and one of the last on the entire planet.

The preservation of Muir Woods is due to the efforts of Congressman and business mogul William Kent. Encouraged by his wife, environmentalist and women’s rights activist Elizabeth Thacher Kent, the couple purchased 611 acres in the region in 1905. They promptly donated half the acreage to the Federal government to ensure its protection. Three years later, president Theodore "Teddy" Roosevelt declared the site a National Monument, and suggested naming the woods after Kent. Kent declined the honor, giving instructions for the woods to be named after legendary environmentalist, philosopher and all around cool historical dude, John Muir. Muir was very grateful for the recognition saying, "This is the best tree-lovers monument that could possibly be found in all the forests of the world."
information.name: Keeping California wild: establishing Muir Woods

information.description: Muir Woods has 6 miles of trails, including half hour, 1 hour and 1 ½ hour loops. There are additional trails that lead from Muir Woods into Mount Tamalpais State Park. Most of the trails in Muir Woods are asphalt or boardwalk, but some that lead far up the canyon are steep, rutted and often muddy.
information.name: Get your nature on: trails in Muir Woods

information.description: Some know him as 'Karl,' a thick gray fog who haunts the city and North Coast, especially during the summer. Karl is sometimes seen as a nuisance, but without him, we wouldn't have the redwoods. When inland temperatures are high, we get a visit from Karl, who comes in from over the ocean, providing a beneficial source of cooling moisture that collects in the forest greenery, and drips down to the forest floor. Karl plays a key role in supporting the forest. The moisture he brings during summer dry periods accounts for about 40 percent of the redwoods' moisture intake. Redwoods can move hundreds of gallons of water daily along their trunks from roots to crown. This water transpires through the trees' foliage, returning to the atmosphere.
information.name: Can’t see the forest for the fog

information.description: [One Tam](http://www.onetam.org/) is a community-based initiative to ensure the preservation of Mount Tamalpais mountain for the next century. ONE Tam raises awareness for the need to maintain the long-term health of the mountain, engage more volunteers in caring for its treasured resources and renew the spirit of philanthropy that was fundamental to keeping Mt. Tam unspoiled over the last one hundred years. ONE Tam is a partnership between the following awesome organizations, dedicated to preserving wild areas in an increasingly digital age: California State Parks, Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, Marin County Parks, Marin Municipal Water District and the National Park Service.
information.name: ONE Tam at a time

sites.name: Muir Woods National Monument

sites.audio_description: At the intersection of Field and Bunker Roads, the Marin Headlands Visitor Center is housed within a historic army chapel. Bathrooms are located at the far west side of the parking lot. The Visitor Center is to the east. From the parking lot, you can take the ramp, which curves in a circle around a native plants garden and flagpole flying American flag. You can also take the stairs which lead to the Visitor Center entrance. Both the ramp and the stairs lead to a wooden boardwalk that take you to the landing in front of the entrance and the courtyard below, respectively. The building is symmetrical, with cream colored wood paneling and an orange angled roof. A tall, pointed steeple sits at the top of the roof, centered over the entranceway. A small courtyard stands in front of the stairs and deck leading to the doorway, with a few picnic benches beneath the shade of two large Eucalyptus trees that frame the Visitor Center between them.
sites.description: Housed in an old Army chapel off Field Road in the Fort Barry complex, the Headlands Visitor Center is a great jumping off point for all your GGNRA adventures in and around Marin County. Drop by anytime from 9:30 AM to 4:30 PM for a look at our mini-museum with exhibits detailing the history of the Headlands as well as its ecology, or call (415) 331-1540 during the same hours if you have any questions. The hands-on science exhibit includes feathers, bones and other natural objects to help visitors connect to the exceptional landscape north of the bay.

information.description: Marin Headlands encompasses many histories, from the Coast Miwok, 1800s American settlers, the 150 year-old Point Bonita lighthouse, the US Army and Coast Guard including historic Forts Baker, Barry and Cronkhite, World War II Battery Townsley, and the Cold War era Nike missile site.
information.name: Marin History

information.description: The Headlands offer several walk-in campground for tent camping that require reservations in advance. Contact the Marin Headlands Visitor Center (415) 331-1540 for more information.
information.name: Camping in the Headlands

information.description: The sea cliffs and road cuts of the Headlands have exposed many fine examples of pillow basalt and radiolarian chert. Millions of years ago, these rocks formed at the bottom of the ocean, thousands of miles from the coast. These formations are the result of volcanic activity and the remains of fossilized protozoans, respectively.
information.name: Geology of Marin

information.description: The Marin Headlands is home to a variety of wildlife including deer, pumas, bobcats, foxes, and coyotes. River otters inhabit the freshwater lagoons and streams. Large numbers of water birds (egrets, grebes, brown pelicans) migrate through the Headlands, in addition to some 20,000 birds of prey that fly through each year over Hawk Hill.
information.name: Wildlife

information.description: The Headlands, and really, all of Marin County, is a popular pilgrimage site for thousands of wildflower enthusiasts every year. The diversity of species and their abundance from early spring to late autumn is a unique and lovely feature of the region. The wildflowers flourish under the protection and coexistence of perennial bunchgrasses, which can live over 100 years. The state's native grasslands have been severely depleted, due to overgrazing and introduced grasses from Europe, but the areas where the native grasses still grow are home to the majority of California’s rare and endangered species, including the Mission blue butterfly.
information.name: Grasses and wildflowers of Marin

information.description: Headlands weather is characterized by marine atmospheric conditions that produce fog, clouds, and winter precipitation. Despite being relatively damp, gusty Pacific winds prevent dense forests from forming. Winter is dominated by rainstorms which provide the majority of rainfall for the year. The summer tends to be foggy. The warmest months are September and October.
information.name: Climate

information.description: Once a large Army complex built in the early 1900s for soldiers manning the coastal guns, Fort Barry consists today of several buildings along Bunker, Field and Simmonds roads in the Headlands. Today its facilities house GGNRA and park partner operations that include the Headlands Visitor Center, Headlands Center for the Arts, and Marin Headlands Hostel.
information.name: Fort Barry

information.description:
In the 1880s, the Marin Headlands were California's largest producer of fresh milk and butter, and dairies were a prosperous business. Much of their success was the result of a happy coincidence: the arrival of experienced Portuguese dairy farmers. Originally from the Azores, an archipelago of eight rural islands west of Iberian Portugal, these men emigrated to California aboard whaling ships. 

After a long time at sea, arriving in California and the allure of the Gold Rush prompted many Azoreans to "jump ship" in search of a better life. Those who didn't find their fortune in gold were able to use their native dairy experience to get jobs in Marin's newly-established dairy ranches.

Dairy farming was no joke. It took hard work from everyone who lived on the farms--women, men and children--to keep an operation running. Until electricity came in the 1930s, the cows were milked by hand, twice a day, at 4 AM and 4 PM. Depending on the number of cows, each milking time could take up to three hours. In between milking sessions, there was no shortage of chores, from sanitizing and preparing milk for transport, to cleaning barns and equipment, mending fences to fieldwork, gardening, canning and tending livestock.
information.name: Portuguese dairies

sites.name: Marin Headlands Visitor Center

sites.audio_description:
Facing south east from the parking lot, the bathrooms, recycling, trash and call box are all located on the left side of the lot, closest to the bridge that leads you over Big Lagoon to the beach. Outside the bathroom is a 4-sided kiosk. Approaching the kiosk will trigger audio description of its contents. 

Beyond the kiosk is a bench that offers a glimpse of the beach across a willow thicket. The beach is accessible by walking over the boardwalk bridge, which is just under one-fifth of a mile long, and leads you over the light, green willows that comprise Big Lagoon. The railings along the bridge are 4 feet high, made from wood and aluminum. Set into the left-hand wood railing about halfway across the boardwalk is a tactile wayside with four distinct panels. The first is of bird tracks walking across a sand dune. The second is of a western fence lizard perched on a rock. The last two are of native plants, the leafy, vine-like sand verdana, and the round-blossomed, thin-stalked rosilla.

The boardwalk dead ends into a wall of blackberry and coastal scrub plants at the intersection of a dirt path. Go left for the Kaasi Coastal Fire Road, Green Gulch Trail and Dias Ridge Trail. These trails are all dirt, involve some stair climbing and steep inclines. Go right for beach access. An access mat leads you partially onto the sand. 

The beach is a wide and sandy. The shoreline is bookended by two rocky hillocks. Facing the water from the area of the beach where the trail leaves you, the hillock on the far end of the beach is tree-covered, and has several houses built upon it. The adjacent hillock is rocky, and undeveloped. A rutted staircase trail climbs its way over the rocks leading to a vista point that offers a more sweeping view of the Pacific. The water at Muir Beach may change color depending on weather and the time of year, but on sunny days, it's often a shade of aqua.
sites.description: Muir Beach may not be as big as Stinson Beach further north, but it has a lot to offer. Learn about wetlands restoration efforts at Big Lagoon. Challenge yourself with a steep climb up a rocky trail to get a better view of the beach from atop the cliffs. Or just lay about and catch up on some beach reading. Dog friends on leashes are cool to hang, but leave your horse at home.

information.description: The waters of Redwood Creek flow through Muir Woods and enter the ocean at Muir Beach. They're home to coho salmon, fish friends who use the creek for breeding. The coho population here is endangered, and has experienced a 90 percent population decline over the last 30 years, a result of human induced habitat disruptions and changes in natural conditions. Efforts are underway to improve habitat conditions and reduce the future stress on this and other native fish friend.
information.name: Restoring the watershed: Redwood Creek

sites.name: Muir Beach

sites.description: Once known as McDowell Hall, this beautiful structure was built in 1855 and was home to commanding officers before serving as the Fort Mason Officers' Club from 1943 until 2003. Today, the General's Residence is managed by the Fort Mason Center and is a great event or wedding venue with commanding views of the Hyde Street Pier and San Francisco Bay.
sites.name: Fort Mason General's Residence

sites.audio_description:
From the PresidiGo stop on Mason Street, walk north through the crosswalk and turn right onto the paved path that parallels Mason Street. Walk down the path 425 feet, just under one tenth of a mile, until you reach a unpaved path on your left. Follow the path, which cuts north west through a Cypress Grove, one tenth of a mile to the Crissy Field Center, an education center committed to discussing issues caused by the intersection of environmental and urban needs through a multicultural lens.
 
The Crissy Field Center is a segmented building, with alternating sections with tall ceilings that draw back at a downward angle towards the back of the building, and linking corridors with lower ceilings. The Center's all-glass façade gives an open feeling the building, and its reddish-orange siding is reminiscent of the Golden Gate Bridge. Leading up to the building is a series of terraces, with stairs in between them and The Beach Hut Cafe is part of the same building, located on its northern side. In front of the entrance to the Beach Hut is a patio area with several large, green chairs and tables. In front of the Center is a green lawn and at its western edge closest to the parking lot, a row of tall, metal poles: vertical-axis wind turbines.
sites.description:
The [Crissy Field Center](http://www.parksconservancy.org/programs/crissy-field-center/?referrer=https://www.google.com/) is known for its youth engagement programs, a partnership between Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy and the National Park Service. These programs are designed to teach leadership skills on environmental topics to kids who typically have little experience in parks. Programs involve participants in the outdoors, lab projects and the classroom. The Crissy Field Center works with schools and community centers to offer field trip and camp opportunities at low or no cost to participants. 

In the coming years, the center will be moving back to its original Building 603, where it was located before the Presidio Parkway project began.

information.description:
With environmental education and youth leadership programs empowering new generations to become advocates for parks, and an infrastructure that’s a certified LEED Platinum green building, the Crissy Field Center is green inside and out. Educational programs empower students to grow healthier communities for a more environmentally just society.

The building's components were manufactured off-site, greatly reducing the amount of construction waste here at Crissy Field. During construction, contractors used an on-site solar generator that provided electricity for their tools.

Much of the Center is made up of creatively reused and repurposed materials. The raised flooring, came from a Hewlett-Packard facility. The redwood siding is re-milled lumber salvaged from an old railway tunnel in Marin County.

More than 35% of the building is made of recycled content. This includes the steel frame (95% recycled), in addition to the light gauge steel walls, roof panels, ceiling tiles and carpet tiles (77% recycled).
information.name: Green inside and out

sites.name: Crissy Field Center

sites.description:
Wayside Panel: First Stewards-Panel Description
340 words.

View from the wayside:
61 words.

A mix of green willows, stubby coyote brush and tall dune grasses make up the wetland before you. In the distance, the slope of a hill, red and green from the thick coverage of poison oak, separates the wetland from the beach. Even further away, you can see houses on a hillside on the other side of the beach parking lot.

The text reads: 

For thousands of years, the Coast Miwok thrived on this floodplain—where fresh waters and salt waters meet. They lived in more than 600 small family settlements along the coast where creek and ocean resources were most abundant. The Coast Miwok hunted, fished and harvested many of the plants growing in the area for food, medicine and other conveniences. They created a harmonious connection with nature through acute management of the landscape and by aligning their activities with the seasons.

Through keen observation, experimentation and patient long-term relationships with plants and animals, the Coast Miwok developed deep ecological knowledge—which they passed down from generation to generation. Although European settlement in the late 1700s forced them off the land, and their traditional society came to an end, they are actively engaged with the site today. Descendants of the Coast Miwok participate in research, education and preservation of sacred sites.

End text.

At the bottom of the panel is a series of three images. Starting on the left, the first image is an illustration of a fish dam composed of a triangular fence with a pointed net at its tip. The net and fence are in the water. Several fish are swimming inside the trap.

The text reads: 

Coast Miwok families built uyu (communal fish dams) to catch kaasi (salmon) to share. The dams also allowed fish to move through the tcok (creek).

End text.

Next is a photograph of man wearing sunglasses in front of tall marsh grass holding a plant.

The text reads: 

Nick Tipon, of Federated Indians of Graton Rancheria leads an indigenous plant tour. FIGR gained federal tribal status recognition in 2000. 

End text. 

The last image is a photograph of a basket with a spiraling pattern of dark rectangles being held by two hands.

The text reads:

Plentiful sapa (tule) and luma (willow) enabled women and men to create cooking and seed collecting baskets, kole-kotcha (shelters), boats and mats. today these plants are re-emerging in the landscape as part of the restoration work. 

End.
sites.name: Muir Beach A D  First Stewards

sites.audio_description:
Facing the San Francisco Bay, the National Parks Headquarters can be found in the Whalen Building, directly to the right of the Great Meadow. From the Franklin and Bay Street entrance, continue straight on Franklin Street, then turn left at the stop sign at MacArthur Avenue. Free visitor parking is available in front of the Whalen Building, which houses The Presidio Trust and Parks Conservancy offices in addition to the National Park Service’s operations. The building is three stories, painted a cream color over brick facade with rows of rectangular windows. Facing the Whalen, there is a flagpole to its right, and palm trees to either side. There is a green grass lawn in front, with a walkway leading from the parking lot to the building’s main entrance, at its center.
End.
sites.description:
The William J. Whalen Building is the National Park Service headquarters for the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. Stop into the front office for maps and park info.
 
In 1902, the army constructed this building as the post's army hospital, complete with a 12-bed ward. After four years the army brass were already considering it for major re-tooling since most wounded soldiers were being cared for at the new and larger Letterman Army Hospital in the Presidio. The army then used this building as a kind of a glorified closet for storage, temporary barracks and performing non-essential tasks. That all changed in 1912, when the army constructed a major depot on Fort Mason's shoreline, for the conveyance of cargo and troops. Suddenly, the building had purpose again: to serve as the headquarters for the new shipping center, that 20 years later, was renamed the San Francisco Port of Embarkation.
sites.name: Park Headquarters

tours.description: The Rodeo Lagoon tour takes you on a 1.6 mile loop from the Marin Headlands Visitor Center around Rodeo Lagoon to Rodeo Beach, through Fort Cronkhite and back around to the Visitor Center. Along the way, learn about endangered native species plant and animal species, beach geology and a portion Headlands history.
tours.name: Rodeo Lagoon

tours.description: Over the centuries, San Franciscans and visitors from all over have traveled to this panoramic display of peninsular delight. This tour will take you on a 1.5 mile loop from the Visitor Center, through Sutro Heights down to Ocean Beach, around the Cliff House to the ruins of Sutro Baths and back up to the USS SF Memorial and Visitor Center parking lot. Along the way, you'll learn about the people and places that have contributed to the character of Lands End as a place of fun and recreation which endures to this day.
tours.name: Lands End: A History of Recreation

tours.description: Take a short walk to the cliffs overlooking the Pacific Ocean, great for whale watching. Along the way, enjoy restored California red-legged frog pond habitat, and views of the coast and surrounding hillsides. Early spring can be a good time for wildflowers, which grow along the point.
tours.name: Mori Point: Protecting A Seaside Landscape

tours.description: An audio described tour of interpretive waysides and kiosks at East Beach and Crissy Field. Audio described content is intended for visitors who are blind or have other vision disabilities.
tours.name: East Beach and Crissy Field Audio Described Wayside Tour

tours.description: An audio described tour of interpretive  kiosks and waysides around the Ka'asi Way trail loop at Muir Beach. Audio described content is intended for visitors who are blind or have other vision disabilities.
tours.name: Muir Beach Audio Described Tour

tours.description: An audio described tour of interpretive waysides and kiosks throughout Muir Woods. Audio described content is intended for visitors who are blind or have other vision disabilities.
tours.name: Muir Woods Audio Described Wayside Tour

tours.description: An audio described tour of wayside and kiosk panels at upper and lower Fort Mason. Audio described content is intended for visitors who are blind or have other vision disabilities.
tours.name: Fort Mason Audio Described Wayside Tour
Muir Beach Overlook Audio Described Tour

tours.description: This walking tour starts in the Langdon Court parking lot. It's an approximately 1.5 mile loop with varied elevation that will take you along a beautiful scenic trail highlighting historical and natural points of interest. Watch your footing along the cliff and be mindful of poison oak. There are no bathrooms or water stations along the trail.
tours.name: Batteries to Bluffs
